revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=March 2013}} {{Infobox football match | title = 2009 Egypt v Algeria football matches | image = | caption = | event = [[2010 FIFA World Cup qualification]]
[[2010 FIFA World Cup qualification – CAF Third Round|Tiebreaking play-off]] | team1 = [[Egypt national football team|Egypt]] | team1association = {{flagicon|EGY|size=30px}} | team1score = 0 | team2 = [[Algeria national football team|Algeria]] | team2association = {{flagicon|ALG|size=30px}} | team2score = 1 | details = Algeria qualify for the [[2010 FIFA World Cup|2010 World Cup]] | date = 18 November 2009 | stadium = [[Al Merreikh Stadium]] | city = [[Omdurman]] | man_of_the_match1a = [[Antar Yahia]] ([[Algeria national football team|Algeria]]) | referee = [[Eddy Maillet]] ([[Seychelles Football Federation|Seychelles]]) | attendance = 35,000 | weather = | previous = | next = }} [[File:Algeria fans in Boston celebrating victory over Egypt.jpg|right|thumb|250px|Algerian celebrations in the city of [[Boston]]]] There were disturbances before and after two international [[association football]] matches between [[Egypt national football team|Egypt]] and [[Algeria national football team|Algeria]] in November 2009, leading to diplomatic tensions between Egypt, Algeria, and Sudan. The matches were in [[2010 FIFA World Cup qualification - CAF Third Round#Group C|Group C]] in [[2010 FIFA World Cup qualification (CAF)|the CAF section]] of [[2010 FIFA World Cup qualification|the qualifying competition]] for the [[2010 FIFA World Cup]]. The first match, the final scheduled match in Group C, took place in [[Cairo]] on 14 November, with Egypt winning 2–0. The result left Egypt and Algeria tied for first place in Group C, necessitating a [[One-game playoff|playoff match]] in a neutral country. This took place in [[Omdurman]], [[Sudan]] on 18 November, with Algeria winning 1–0 and thus qualifying for the World Cup final tournament in South Africa in June 2010. ==Rivalry== The countries are both in North Africa, only separated by [[Libya]], and football matches between them are fiercely contested [[local derby|local derbies]].{{cite web|url=http://thelede.blogs.nytimes.com/2009/11/13/egypt-and-algeria-brace-for-match-of-hate-sequel/ |title=Violence Flares Ahead of Algeria-Egypt Soccer Match |last=Mackey |first=Robert |date=13 November 2009 |work=The New York Times|accessdate=27 November 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091117173035/http://thelede.blogs.nytimes.com/2009/11/13/egypt-and-algeria-brace-for-match-of-hate-sequel/ |archivedate=17 November 2009 |deadurl=no |df= }}{{cite news |url=http://www.edition.cnn.com/2009/SPORT/football/11/20/egypt.algeria.inside.story/index.html |title=Egypt versus Algeria: Inside the storm |last=Montague |first=James |date=20 November 2009|publisher=[[CNN]] |accessdate=27 November 2009|location=Cairo| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20091130054513/http://edition.cnn.com/2009/SPORT/football/11/20/egypt.algeria.inside.story/index.html| archivedate= 30 November 2009 | deadurl= no}} Although both have long been among Africa's stronger sides, each had experienced a long drought without World Cup qualification: Algeria since [[1986 World Cup|1986]] and Egypt since [[1990 World Cup|1990]]. In 1989, Egypt beat Algeria in [[1990 FIFA World Cup qualification (CAF)#Final round|a decisive qualifying match]] for the [[1990 World Cup]]. Player [[Ayman Younes]] later said, "It was a battle, not a football match." Algerians felt the Tunisian referee was biased; fans rioted in the stands.{{cite web |url=http://www.worldsoccer.com/features/egypt_against_algeria_revives_some_bitter_memories_part_one_by_james_montague_features_290898.html |title=Egypt against Algeria revives some bitter memories |last=Montague |first=James |publisher=[[World Soccer Magazine|World Soccer]] |accessdate=27 November 2009| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20091117201441/http://www.worldsoccer.com/features/egypt_against_algeria_revives_some_bitter_memories_part_one_by_james_montague_features_290898.html| archivedate= 17 November 2009 | deadurl= yes}} An Algerian player attacked an Egyptian fan.{{cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JTQbpQheqn4 |format=[[YouTube]] |first=Amr |last=el-Khaky |location=Cairo |publisher=[[Al Jazeera English]] |date=14 November 2009 |accessdate=1 December 2009 |title=Rivalries persist at Cairo football match }} Algeria's [[Lakhdar Belloumi]] was convicted [[trial in absentia|''in absentia'']] for a glass attack which blinded Egypt's team doctor in one eye. He remained subject to an [[Interpol]] arrest warrant, although he claimed goalkeeper [[Kamel Kadri]] had been the true perpetrator. For political analyst [[Ziad Majed]], the tension dates from [[Gamal Abdel Nasser]] days when he sent Egyptian teachers to help arabize Algeria after its independence. These teachers contributed to the rise of political Islam in Algeria, ultimately leading to the Algerian civil war.{{cite news |url=http://ziadmajed.blogspot.com/2009/11/blog-post_24.html |title=Algeria - Egypt... France - Ireland|last=Majed |first=Ziad |date=24 November 2009 |work=nowlebanon|accessdate=28 November 2009}} On the other hand, Khaled Diab suggests the 1989 match was the key moment for Egypt–Algeria rivalry, and that it is mainly confined to football rather than a reflection of deeper enmity;{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2009/nov/07/algeria-egypt-world-cup-football |title=Algeria and Egypt play political football |last=Diab |first=Khaled |date=7 November 2009 |work=The Guardian |accessdate=28 November 2009 | location=London| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20091110035740/http://www.guardian.co.uk/commentisfree/2009/nov/07/algeria-egypt-world-cup-football| archivedate= 10 November 2009 | deadurl= no}} he notes [[Gamal Abdel Nasser]] supported [[Algerian War|Algeria's independence war]] against France, and suggests memory has faded in Algeria of [[Anwar El Sadat]]'s unpopular [[Camp David Accords]] with [[Israel]]. On the other hand, Brian Oliver and James Montague point to other football controversies before 1989. In the 1950s, an [[National Liberation Front (Algeria)|Algerian National Liberation Front]] football team toured Africa to publicise [[Nationalism and resistance in Algeria|its independence campaign]], but were forbidden from playing in Egypt.{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/blog/2009/oct/10/egypt-algeria-repeat-hate-match |title=Twenty years on, the 'hate match' between Egypt and Algeria is on again |last=Oliver |first=Brian |date=10 October 2009 |work=The Sport Blog |publisher=The Guardian |accessdate=27 November 2009 | location=London| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20091014153243/http://www.guardian.co.uk/football/blog/2009/oct/10/egypt-algeria-repeat-hate-match| archivedate= 14 October 2009 | deadurl= no}} At the [[1978 All-Africa Games]], Algerian police attacked Egyptian players and fans during their match against [[Libya national football team|Libya]]. There were brawls at a qualifier for the [[Football at the 1984 Summer Olympics|1984 Olympics]]. ==Blida match== Algeria's home match against Egypt in the 2010 qualifiers took place in June 2009 without any incident being reported. Rather, to cool down animosity between the two countries, the Egyptian team was received with flowers at the airport. Diplomatic agreement, with personal intervention from Algerian president [[Abdelaziz Bouteflika]], included lifting the Interpol warrant on Belloumi and compensating the Egyptian team doctor. Both teams prepared for the match away from the pressure of intense local fans; Egypt in [[Oman]], Algeria in France.{{cite news |url=http://www.echoroukonline.com/eng/index.php?news=6727|title=2010 World Cup : Algeria, Egypt face off in a classic North African derby |last=B. |first=Med. |work=[[Echorouk]] online |accessdate=2 December 2009}} Algeria coach [[Rabah Saadane]] wept at a press conference, expressing fear for his family's safety in the event of defeat.{{cite web|url=http://www.goal.com/en/news/1863/world-cup-2010confederations-cup/2009/06/05/1306308/world-cup-qualifying-preview-algeria-egypt |title=World Cup Qualifying Preview: Algeria – Egypt |last=Ayari |first=Rami |date=5 June 2009 |work=Goal.com |accessdate=2 December 2009 }} 5,000 security personnel turned [[Blida]] into a "virtual military base".{{cite news |url=http://www.alarabiya.net/articles/2009/06/07/75162.html |title=Egypt faces Algeria in tense World Cup qualifier |last=Belmary |first=Ramadan |date=7 June 2009 |publisher=[[Al Arabiya]] |accessdate=2 December 2009 |location=Algiers }} Minors were barred from the stadium unless they had a ticket. Algeria won 3–1.{{cite web|url=http://www.goal.com/en/news/1863/world-cup-2010/2009/06/07/1311469/world-cup-2010-egypt-humbled-by-three-goal-algeria |title=World Cup 2010: Egypt Humbled By Three-Goal Algeria |last=Pedroncelli |first=Peter |date=7 June 2009 |work=Goal.com|accessdate=2 December 2009 }}
{{football box |date = 7 June 2009 |time = 20:30 [[UTC+1]] |team1 = {{fb-rt|ALG}} |score = 3–1 |report = [https://www.fifa.com/worldcup/preliminaries/africa/matches/round=252295/match=300070353/report.html Report] |team2 = {{fb|EGY}} |goals1 = [[Karim Matmour|Matmour]] {{goal|60}}
[[Abdelkader Ghezzal|Ghezzal]] {{goal|64}}
[[Rafik Djebbour|Djebbour]] {{goal|77}} |goals2 = [[Mohamed Aboutrika|Aboutrika]] {{goal|86}} |stadium = [[Stade Mustapha Tchaker]], [[Blida]] |attendance = 26,500 |referee=[[Daniel Bennett (referee)|Daniel Bennett]] ([[South African Football Association|South Africa]]) }}
==Cairo match== The lead-up to the crucial match was hyped.{{cite news |url=http://weekly.ahram.org.eg/2009/972/fr2.htm |title=Mother of all matches |last=Abdel-Ghani |first=Alaa |date=12–18 November 2009 |work=[[Al-Ahram]] weekly online |accessdate=1 December 2009 |location=Cairo | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20091117112729/http://weekly.ahram.org.eg/2009/972/fr2.htm| archivedate= 17 November 2009 | deadurl= no}} Egyptian blogger and woman's rights activist, [[Dalia Ziada]], said the match gave Egyptians an opportunity to unite and forget about [[Religion in Egypt|sectarian tension]], [[Economy of Egypt|economic difficulties]], and [[Politics of Egypt|politics]].{{cite news |url=http://bikyamasr.com/?p=5757 |title= A soccer match or national hope: Egypt vs. Algeria |last=Ziada |first=Dalia |date=14 November 2009 |work=Bikya Masr |accessdate=1 December 2009}} In October, insults were traded on internet sites,{{cite news |url=http://www.timeslive.co.za/sport/soccer/article192345.ece |title=Egypt, Algeria go to war |last=Zayan |first=Jailan |author2=AFP |date=12 November 2009 |work=[[The Times (South Africa)|The Times]] |publisher=[[Avusa]] |location=Johannesburg |accessdate=1 December 2009 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20091115094604/http://www.timeslive.co.za/sport/soccer/article192345.ece| archivedate= 15 November 2009 | deadurl= yes}} and Egyptian [[hacker (computer security)|hacker]]s made a [[denial-of-service attack]] on the website of Algerian newspaper ''[[Ech-Chorouk El-Youmi]]''; an Algerian hacker retaliated by crashing the websites of the [[President of Egypt]] and Egyptian newspaper ''[[Al Ahram]]''.{{cite news |url=http://bikyamasr.com/?p=5391 |title=Egypt, Algeria duke it out online ahead of big match |last=Mason |first=Joseph |date=2 November 2009 |work=Bikya Masr |accessdate=27 November 2009| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20091112022105/http://bikyamasr.com/?p=5391| archivedate= 12 November 2009 | deadurl= no}} Both countries' governments appealed for calm.{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/africa/8353159.stm |title=Egypt, Algeria appeal for calm |date=10 November 2009|publisher=[[bbc.co.uk]]|accessdate=27 November 2009| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20091113164232/http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/africa/8353159.stm| archivedate= 13 November 2009 | deadurl= no}} Media in both countries alluded to the 1989 match. Editorialist Mohamed El Dahshan reported, "In the two days preceding the game, Egyptians celebrated as if they had already won."{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2009/nov/16/egypt-algeria-football-qualifier |title=Egypt's football party gets out of hand |last=El Dahshan |first=Mohamed |date=16 November 2009|work=The Guardian |accessdate=28 November 2009 | location=London| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20091119101221/http://www.guardian.co.uk/commentisfree/2009/nov/16/egypt-algeria-football-qualifier| archivedate= 19 November 2009 | deadurl= no}} [[Ahmed Shobair]] stated that rumours started on the internet were being propagated by the [[mainstream media]]. When the Algerian team arrived in Cairo on Thursday 12 November, the bus carrying the team to its hotel was stoned, breaking windows and injuring three players and one official.{{cite news |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/hotStocksNews/idUSLC7252320091112 |title=Algeria footballers hurt ahead of Egypt game |last=Lowe |first=Christian |author2=Louise Ireland |date=12 November 2009 |publisher=Reuters |accessdate=27 November 2009 |location=Algiers | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20091115131833/https://www.reuters.com/article/hotStocksNews/idUSLC7252320091112| archivedate= 15 November 2009 | deadurl= no}} Egyptian media alleged that the attack had been staged by the Algerians to have the match moved to a neutral venue.{{cite web |url=http://goal.com/en/news/1863/world-cup-2010/2009/11/12/1621214/egypt-reacts-to-algeria-attack-claims |title=Egypt Reacts To Algeria Attack Claims |last=Macdonald |first=Ewan |date=12 November 2009 |publisher=Goal.com |accessdate=27 November 2009| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20091203135734/http://www.goal.com/en/news/1863/world-cup-2010/2009/11/12/1621214/egypt-reacts-to-algeria-attack-claims| archivedate= 3 December 2009 | deadurl= no}} The [[police escort]] of one van and several motorcycle outriders was criticised as insufficient.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/aponline/2009/11/17/sports/AP-SOC-John-Leicester-171109.html |title=Egypt-Algeria: When Fair Play Died |last=Leicester |first=John |author2=Associated Press |date=17 November 2009 |work=New York Times |accessdate=27 November 2009}} Egypt's leading state-owned daily ''[[Al-Ahram]]'' charged on Friday that it was the Algerian players, not stonethrowers, who had caused the damage to the bus. "The bus carrying the team from the airport to the hotel was at the centre of a strange incident in which some of the players started to smash the vehicle's windows claiming that they were the target of stonethrowing", the paper reported. The independent daily ''[[Al-Shuruq]]'' went further, saying the whole episode was a "complete fabrication." Citing a "senior security source", the paper said the windows of the bus were smashed "from the inside not the outside as claimed by Algerian team members." It accused the players of a "complete fabrication intended to serve as an excuse in the event that they lose" Saturday's key decider for next year's World Cup finals in South Africa.[https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5jpx0j26RGheW0iTMq-K9FkjCBLig Egypt press says Algerian team faked bus attack], by Ines bel Aiba, AFP, 13-11-2009 The independent ''[[Almasry Alyoum|Al-Masry Al-Youm]]'' newspaper acknowledged that some "kids" had thrown stones but charged that the Algerian players had then put on a "display of histrionics pretending to be scared and injured, and smashing up the bus's windows and seats." The state-owned ''[[Al Gomhuria]]'' said the players had even assaulted the bus driver. Counterclaims included footage shot by [[Canal+]] for its documentary about the Algerian team{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/8359265.stm |title= World Cup footballers under attack |date=13 November 2009|publisher=[[BBC.co.uk]] |accessdate=27 November 2009| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20091121163905/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/8359265.stm| archivedate= 21 November 2009 | deadurl= no}} and cellphone footage shot by [[Rafik Saïfi]].{{cite web |url=http://goal.com/en/news/1863/world-cup-2010/2009/11/12/1621127/video-algeria-player-rafik-saifi-produces-video-of-bus |title=Algeria Player Rafik Saifi Produces Video Of Bus Attack |date=12 November 2009 |publisher=Goal.com |accessdate=27 November 2009 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20091203090819/http://www.goal.com/en/news/1863/world-cup-2010/2009/11/12/1621127/video-algeria-player-rafik-saifi-produces-video-of-bus| archivedate= 3 December 2009 | deadurl= no}} FIFA observer Walter Gagg said, "We saw that three players had been injured — [[Khaled Lemmouchia]] on the head, [[Rafik Halliche]] above the eye and [[Rafik Saïfi]] on the arm."{{cite news|url=http://bikyamasr.com/?p=5768 |title= Late goal gives Egypt enough for win, World Cup playoff |date=15 November 2009 |work=Bikya Masr |accessdate=1 December 2009}} The initial reporting following the incident likely led to further poisoning the build-up to Saturday's game. The pre-match atmosphere in Egypt had already surged to feverish heights amid an unprecedented level of tension between the North African rivals. [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Egypt)|Egyptian foreign ministry]] spokesman Hossam Zaki had specifically called for responsible coverage by both countries' media as the two governments issued joint appeals for calm. Egyptian and Algerian media "hold a responsibility in this regard and must work to maintain the strong ties between both countries and should not fuel disagreements that are unrelated to sports and sportsmanship", Zaki said. That same evening just outside Cairo, Algeria's "king of rai" [[Khaled (musician)|Cheb Khaled]] performed alongside Egyptian star [[Mohamed Mounir]] to a packed audience of nearly 45,000 people, according to organisers. "Long live Egypt, Arab country, long live Algeria, Arab country", Cheb Khaled shouted to the crowd, with little apparent impact on home fan passions ahead of the game. [[Egyptian Football Association]] board member Mahmoud Taher later indicated that "all Algeria players are safe. They were not hurt. Algeria is trying to blow things out of proportion. The bus is damaged from inside, so it is obvious that they were the ones who did that to escalate the matter. FIFA has not contacted Egypt as recently reported, and there aren't any intentions to call off the game."[http://new.filgoal.com/English/News.aspx?NewsID=61503 No Algerian players were injured - EFA], by Hatem Maher, FilGoal.com, 12-11-2009 Khairi Morsi, the Egyptian driver who drove the Algerian delegation's bus, said the Algerian team had assaulted him. He indicated to Modern Sport TV that "they also shattered the windows from inside when they saw some Egyptian people around the bus." On Friday 13 November, FIFA declared the match would go ahead as scheduled, but "asked the Egyptian Football Association and the highest national authorities through the relevant ministries to provide written guarantees that confirm the implementation of the necessary additional safety and security measures at any time for the Algerian delegation."{{cite web|url=https://www.fifa.com/worldcup/news/newsid=1133115.html |title=Egypt-Algeria Media Statement |date=13 November 2009 |publisher=FIFA |accessdate=27 November 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091116171840/http://www.fifa.com/worldcup/news/newsid%3D1133115.html |archivedate=16 November 2009 |deadurl=no |df= }} Lemmouchia and Halliche played with bandaged heads. Team doctor Michel Gaillaud said the players were mentally unfit and the match should not have gone ahead.
{{football box |date = 14 November 2009 |time = 19:30 [[UTC+2]] |team1 = {{fb-rt|EGY}} |score = 2–0 |report = [https://www.fifa.com/worldcup/preliminaries/africa/matches/round=252295/match=300070345/report.html Report] |team2 = {{fb|ALG}} |goals1 = [[Amr Zaki|Zaki]] {{goal|3}}
[[Emad Moteab|Moteab]] {{goal|90+5}} |goals2 = |stadium = [[Cairo International Stadium]], [[Cairo]] |attendance = 75,000 |referee = [[Jerome Damon]] ([[South African Football Association|South Africa]]) }}
[[Ech-Chorouk El-Youmi|Ech-Chorouk]] reported that six Algerian fans were killed in the chaos that followed the match.{{cite web |first=Amro |last=Hassan |location=Cairo |url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/babylonbeyond/2009/11/egypt-algerian-ambassador-summoned-to-clarify-post-football-match-incidents.html |title=Algerian ambassador summoned to clarify post-football match incidents |date=17 November 2009 |accessdate=20 November 2009 |work=Babylon & Beyond |publisher=[[The Los Angeles Times]] | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20091121004552/http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/babylonbeyond/2009/11/egypt-algerian-ambassador-summoned-to-clarify-post-football-match-incidents.html| archivedate= 21 November 2009 | deadurl= no}} This was denied by Algeria's ambassador in Cairo, Abdel Qader Hadjar, who said only eleven people had been injured.{{cite web |first=Amro |last=Hassan |location=Cairo |url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/babylonbeyond/2009/11/egypt-ambassador-in-algeria-recalled-on-the-background-of-football-violence.html |title=Cairo recalls its ambassador to Algeria after soccer violence |date=17 November 2009 |work=Babylon & Beyond |accessdate=20 November 2009 |publisher=[[The Los Angeles Times]]| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20091122033752/http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/babylonbeyond/2009/11/egypt-ambassador-in-algeria-recalled-on-the-background-of-football-violence.html| archivedate= 22 November 2009 | deadurl= no}} Egypt's Health Ministry reported 20 Algerians and 12 Egyptians injured. [[Reda City 16]], a well-known Algerian rapper, claimed his brother had died in the Cairo incidents. His claims, made on a [[YouTube]] video posting, were disseminated by the Ech-Chorouk newspaper's internet site.{{cite web|url=http://thelede.blogs.nytimes.com/2009/11/18/egypt-and-algeria-bring-soccer-war-to-sudan/ |title=Egypt and Algeria Bring Soccer War to Sudan |last=Mackey |first=Robert |date=18 November 2009 |work=The New York Times|accessdate=27 November 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091122023508/http://thelede.blogs.nytimes.com/2009/11/18/egypt-and-algeria-bring-soccer-war-to-sudan/ |archivedate=22 November 2009 |deadurl=no |df= }} There were attacks on Egyptian interests in Algeria after the match. [[EgyptAir]]'s Algiers bureau was broken into and a "serious" amount of damage done and the office was closed due to health and safety concerns. Stones were hurled at other buildings. The headquarters of [[Djezzy]], an Algerian subsidiary of the Egyptian [[Orascom group]], was vandalised and looted.{{cite news |url=https://af.reuters.com/article/sportsNews/idAFJOE5AF0TO20091116 |title=Offices of Orascom Telecom unit in Algeria attacked |date=16 November 2009 |publisher=Reuters |accessdate=27 November 2009 |location=Algiers }} Allegedly related was the Algerian government's demand from Orascom for US$596m in back taxes.{{cite news |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/technology-media-telco-SP/idUSLJ46654120091120?sp=true |title=Egypt recalls Algiers envoy after soccer loss |last=Saleh |first=Yasmine |author2=Shaimaa Fayed |date=19 November 2009 |publisher=Reuters |accessdate=27 November 2009}}{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2009/nov/20/egypt-algeria-riots-world-cup |title=Crackdown in Cairo as football violence erupts |last=Shenker |first=Jack |date=20 November 2009 |work=The Guardian |accessdate=28 November 2009 |location=Cairo| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20091123151044/http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2009/nov/20/egypt-algeria-riots-world-cup| archivedate= 23 November 2009 | deadurl= no}} An Egyptian plane sent to Algeria to "rescue" citizens was refused permission to land. In [[Marseille]], 500 police were deployed to quell disturbances by Algerian youths, making eight arrests.{{cite news |url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/sport/football/article6920020.ece |title=Bitter rivals Egypt and Algeria battle for place in World Cup finals |last=Dart |first=Tom |date=17 November 2009 |work=The Times |accessdate=28 November 2009 | location=London}} As a result of these events, on 18 May 2010, the [[FIFA Disciplinary Code|FIFA Disciplinary Committee]] sanctioned and fined the [[Egyptian Football Association]] for not adopting the necessary measures to prevent the assault on the bus of the [[Algeria national football team|Algerian delegation]] on the way from the airport to the hotel on 12 November 2009. The report would also admonish the Egyptian Football Association for failures in maintaining security and order in the [[Cairo International Stadium]] for the game between Egypt and Algeria held on 14 November 2009. This would result in a two-game ban for the Egyptian national football team whereby the first two home matches of the preliminary competition for the [[2014 FIFA World Cup]] in Brazil would be played at a location at least 100 kilometres away from Cairo.[https://www.fifa.com/worldcup/organisation/media/newsid=1213553/ Egypt to play two matches outside Cairo], by FIFA.com, 18-05-2010 ==Omdurman match== The teams finished level on 13 points and level on all [[2010 FIFA World Cup qualification#Tiebreakers|tiebreakers]]: [[goal difference]] in all group matches (+5); goals scored in all group matches (9); points in all Algeria–Egypt matches (3); and goal difference in all Algeria–Egypt matches (0). (The [[away goals rule]] was not used as a group-stage tiebreaker.{{cite book|url=https://www.fifa.com/mm/document/tournament/competition/fifa_wc_south_africa_2010_regulations_en_14123.pdf |title=Regulations 2010 FIFA World Cup South Africa |page=21, §17.6 |chapter=Preliminary draw, format of play and group formation – preliminary competition |accessdate=2009-06-12 |date=July 2007 |format=PDF |work=FIFA.com |publisher=FIFA |location=Zurich, Switzerland |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070926230651/http://www.fifa.com/mm/document/tournament/competition/fifa_wc_south_africa_2010_regulations_en_14123.pdf |archivedate=26 September 2007 |df= }}) The teams met in a one-game play-off to decide the qualifier. To determine the match venue, each team selected a country other than their own (Algeria selected [[Tunisia]] and Egypt selected [[Sudan]]). After Sudan was drawn in a lottery on 11 November,[https://www.fifa.com/worldcup/news/newsid=1132049.html#sudan+host+possible+play Sudan to host possible play-off], FIFA.com, 11 November 2009. the [[Al Merreikh Stadium]] in Omdurman was selected by FIFA as the venue for the play-off. [[Reuters]] reported that 15,000 police were mobilised for the match.{{cite news |url=https://af.reuters.com/article/sportsNews/idAFJOE5AH0AG20091118?sp=true |title=Sudan readies for trouble ahead of World Cup decider |last=McDoom |first=Opheera |author2=Andrew Heavens |date=18 November 2009|publisher=Reuters |accessdate=27 November 2009|location=Khartoum}} Embassies advised their nationals to avoid the stadium area; government offices and schools closed early. Scuffles leading to minor injuries were reported. On Monday 16 November, [[Al Jazeera]] reported that Algerian fans had stoned a bus carrying the Egyptian players from a training session, without causing injury.{{cite news |url=http://www.ennaharonline.com/en/sports/2446.html |title=Egyptian team bus stoned in Khartoum |date=17 November 2009 |work=Ennahar online |accessdate=1 December 2009 |location=Khartoum | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20091120074703/http://www.ennaharonline.com/en/sports/2446.html| archivedate= 20 November 2009 | deadurl= no}} The following day, Sudan President [[Omar al-Bashir]] hosted a function in the [[Presidential Palace]] in [[Khartoum]], in which [[Fédération Algérienne de Football|Algerian FA]] head [[Mohamed Raouraoua]] snubbed his Egyptian counterpart [[Samir Zaher]].{{cite news |url=http://www.ennaharonline.com/en/sports/2459.html |title=Raouraoua: " I refused to shake hands with Zaher because he was responsible for the incidents of Cairo " |date=19 November 2009 |work=Ennahar online |accessdate=1 December 2009}} Each team's fans were allocated 9,000 tickets, with the stadium capacity reduced from 41,000 to 36,000; there were fears of ticketless fans congregating outside. Although the countries' own blocks were strictly segregated,{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2009/nov/18/algeria-egypt-world-cup-qualifier |title=Arab unity put to severe test as Egypt and Algeria contest World Cup qualifier |last=Black |first=Ian |date=18 November 2009|work=The Guardian |accessdate=28 November 2009 | location=London| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20091121043740/http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2009/nov/18/algeria-egypt-world-cup-qualifier| archivedate= 21 November 2009 | deadurl= no}} many Algerian and Egyptian fans purchased tickets allocated to the home Sudanese.{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2009/nov/18/world-cup-algeria-egypt-play-off |title=Algeria rejoice as Antar Yahia kills off Egypt's World Cup hopes |last=Copnall |first=James |date=18 November 2009 |work=The Guardian |accessdate=28 November 2009 |location=Khartoum | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20091121115543/http://www.guardian.co.uk/football/2009/nov/18/world-cup-algeria-egypt-play-off| archivedate= 21 November 2009 | deadurl= no}} Locals estimated the actual attendance at up to 50,000.{{cite news |url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/sport/football/article6922441.ece |title=Algeria gain revenge for 20 years of hurt after Antar Yahia breaks Egypt's hearts |last=Jacob |first=Gary |date=19 November 2009|work=The Times |accessdate=28 November 2009 | location=London}} ===Details=== {{Football box | date = {{Start date|2009|11|18|df=y}} | time = 20:30 {{flagicon|CMR}} Evarist Menkouande ([[Cameroonian Football Federation|Cameroon]])
{{flagicon|SEY}} Jason Damoo ([[Seychelles Football Federation|Seychelles]])
'''[[Assistant referee (association football)#Fourth official|Fourth official]]:'''
{{flagicon|}} |style="width:60%; vertical-align:top;"| '''Match rules''' *90 minutes. *Seven named substitutes. *Maximum of three substitutions. |} Egyptian news media ran many stories about attacks that allegedly happened in Sudan.{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/aponline/2009/11/22/world/AP-ML-Egypt-Algeria-Rivalry.html|title=Egypt's Media Stoked Soccer Fan Anger With Algeria |last=Associated Press |date=22 November 2009 |work=New York Times |accessdate=27 November 2009}} ''[[Al-Ahram]]'', a state-owned Egyptian newspaper, reported that buses designated for Egyptian fans to be taken to the airport had been destroyed, forcing them to walk there under escort of the Sudanese army.{{cite news |url=http://weekly.ahram.org.eg/2009/974/sp1.htm |title=Broken in every sense |last=Morsy |first=Ahmed |date=26 November – 2 December 2009 |work=Al-Ahram weekly online |accessdate=1 December 2009 |location=Cairo }} Egypt's foreign ministry spoke of "Egypt's extreme displeasure with the assaults on Egyptian citizens who went to Khartoum to support the Egyptian team". Algerian diplomats said later that a widely broadcast video showing hundreds of Algerian fans brandishing knives had in fact been taken at an Algerian club match several years earlier. According to ''[[Al-Ahram]]'', Sudanese diplomats suggested "scores" of Egyptians had been attacked and "a few" hurt. Egypt's health ministry later said there had been 20 minor injuries.{{cite news |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/africaCrisis/idUSMCD671034 |title=Sudan offers to mediate Egypt-Algeria soccer row |last=McDoom |first=Opheera |author2=edited by David Stamp |date=26 November 2009 |publisher=Reuters |accessdate=1 December 2009 |location=Khartoum | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20091130174314/https://www.reuters.com/article/africaCrisis/idUSMCD671034| archivedate= 30 November 2009 | deadurl= no}} ''[[The New York Times]]'' reported "no widespread rioting.".{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/11/19/sports/soccer/19khartoum.html |title=A Soccer Match in Sudan Includes Soldiers and Guns |last=Gentleman |first=Jeffrey |date=19 November 2009 |work=The New York Times |page=A6 |accessdate=1 December 2009| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20111123125239/http://www.nytimes.com/2009/11/19/sports/soccer/19khartoum.html| archivedate=23 November 2011| deadurl= no}} After the loss of the match, the Egyptian Football Association (EFA) filed a complaint with [[FIFA]] against the Algerian football delegation. The EFA indicated that "Egyptian fans, officials and players put their lives at risk before and after the game, under threat from weapons, knives, swords and flares." The statement also threatened with the Egyptian football team's withdrawal for two years from all international competitions as a sign of protest.[http://www.goal.com/en/news/1863/world-cup-2010/2009/11/19/1635199/egypt-issue-fifa-complaint-against-algeria-threaten The Pharaohs have reacted angrily to events in Sudan...], by goal.com, 19-11-2010 On 18 May 2010, FIFA announced that the conditions for opening disciplinary proceedings had not been met and closed the complaint. About 12,000 Algerian fans celebrated on the [[Champs-Élysées]] in Paris and a lot more across France. However, among the numerous celebrating crowd, some offenders made the most of the situation to loot one supermarket and torch cars. There were 150 arrests across France.{{cite news |url=http://www.france24.com/en/node/4928981 |title=French riots after Algeria-Egypt match |publisher=[[France 24]] |accessdate=1 December 2009 |author=AFP | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20091122082741/http://www.france24.com/en/node/4928981| archivedate= 22 November 2009 | deadurl= no}}{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2009/nov/22/france-algeria-paris-riots-football |title=Why French Algerians' football celebrations turned into a battle |last=Hussey |first=Andrew |date=22 November 2009 |work=The Observer |accessdate=1 December 2009 | location=London| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20091125140123/http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2009/nov/22/france-algeria-paris-riots-football| archivedate= 25 November 2009 | deadurl= no}} Egypt's ambassador to the UK claimed thousands of fans had to flee to the airport for safety.{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2009/nov/24/algeria-egypt-football-violence |title=Letters: Football fallout |last=Elbadri |first=Mohamed |date=24 November 2009 |work=The Guardian |accessdate=28 November 2009 | location=London}} Sudan summoned the Egyptian ambassador to protest at the media coverage of the Sudanese hosting of the match. That evening, that over 1,000 Egyptians protested near the Algerian embassy in [[Zamalek]], Cairo, burning flags, shouting anti-Algerian slogans and damaging cars and shops.{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/8369983.stm |title=Egypt-Algeria World Cup anger turns violent in Cairo |date=20 November 2009 |work=news.bbc.co.uk |publisher=BBC |accessdate=27 November 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091125174132/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/8369983.stm |archivedate=25 November 2009 |deadurl=no |df= }}{{cite news|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/middle_east/article6926078.ece |title=Egypt erupts in anti-Algeria riots after World Cup football defeat |last=Frenkel |first=Sheera |date=21 November 2009|work=The Times |accessdate=28 November 2009|location=Cairo }} The Interior Ministry said 11 police and 24 protesters were injured, and 20 people arrested.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/aponline/2009/11/20/world/AP-ML-Egypt-Algeria-Soccer-Row.html?scp=7 |title=Egyptian Soccer Fans Riot Against Algeria |last=Associated Press |date=20 November 2009 |work=New York Times |accessdate=27 November 2009 }} ==Subsequent events== On Friday, [[Alaa Mubarak]] telephoned a [[talk show]], saying "We are Egyptian and we hold our head high, and whoever insults us should be smacked on his head."{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/11/21/world/africa/21egypt.html |title=This Time, Egyptian Riot Over Soccer, Not Bread |last=Slackman |first=Michael |author2=Mona el Naggar |date=21 November 2009 |work=New York Times |page=A4 |accessdate=27 November 2009| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20111128110407/http://www.nytimes.com/2009/11/21/world/africa/21egypt.html| archivedate=28 November 2011| deadurl= no}} [[Hosni Mubarak]] said on national television that he would not condone the "humiliation" of Egyptians abroad. However, the Foreign Ministry said the government would not "tolerate violations against Algerian interests", suggesting a clampdown on protests. Diplomats meeting to repair relations the next week reportedly characterised the dispute as "ultimately a fight among soccer fans" that "was picked up and inflamed by some elements in the media".{{cite news |url=http://weekly.ahram.org.eg/2009/974/eg7.htm |title=Start of the second half |last=Ezzat |first=Dina |date=26 November – 2 December 2009 |work=Al-Ahram weekly online |accessdate=1 December 2009 |location=Cairo | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20091202080505/http://weekly.ahram.org.eg/2009/974/eg7.htm| archivedate= 2 December 2009 | deadurl= no}} An article in ''al-Ahram'' suggested that the Egyptians attending the match were mainly wealthy people who could afford to travel, rather than "the really tough fans" who could have defended themselves against assaults.{{cite news |url=http://weekly.ahram.org.eg/2009/974/fe1.htm |title=Ready, steady, defend |last=Rashed |first=Dena |date=26 November – 2 December 2009 |work=Al-Ahram weekly online |accessdate=1 December 2009 |location=Cairo }} The two sides met again in Angola in January, for the [[2010 Africa Cup of Nations]] semi-finals. Egypt cruised to a 4–0 victory, en route to an unprecedented 7th tournament win, in a hotly tempered match where Algeria had three players red carded.{{cite web |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/africa/8483733.stm |title=Algeria 0-4 Egypt |last=Fottrell |first=Stephen |date=28 January 2010 |work=[[BBC Sport]] |accessdate=13 October 2010 }} Match referee [[Coffi Codjia]] was indefinitely suspended by the [[Confederation of African Football]] for failing to send off Algerian goalkeeper [[Faouzi Chaouchi]] for headbutting the match official, only awarding the player a yellow card for the incident.{{cite web |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/africa/8490140.stm |title=Referee Bonaventure Koffi Codjia suspended by Caf |date=31 January 2010 |work=[[BBC Sport]] |accessdate=13 October 2010 }} Chaouchi was later one of the players to be dismissed, for a second bookable offence. He received a three match ban by CAF for the headbutt.{{cite web |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/africa/8572117.stm |title=Algeria await Chaouchi appeal |last=Edwards |first=Peirs |date=17 March 2010 |work=[[BBC Sport]] |accessdate=13 October 2010 }} A meeting of Egyptian sports organisations agreed to be "prudent" when hosting events at which Algerians were competing, and not to travel to competitions in Algeria.{{cite news|url=https://news.yahoo.com/s/afp/20091129/wl_africa_afp/sportsegyptalgeriadiplomacy_20091129205804 |title=Egypt not to host handball tournament in Algeria spat |author=AFP |date=29 November 2009 |work=Yahoo! News |accessdate=1 December 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091208005743/http://news.yahoo.com/s/afp/20091129/wl_africa_afp/sportsegyptalgeriadiplomacy_20091129205804 |archivedate=8 December 2009 }} The [[Egypt national handball team|Egyptian Handball Federation]] was due to host the [[2010 African Men's Handball Championship|African Championships in February 2010]]; after a request for postponement was denied by the [[Confédération Africaine de Handball|CAHB]], it withdrew as host, but said it would still field a team. The CAHB canvassed for a new host, with only Algeria volunteering.{{cite news|url=http://teamhandballnews.com/news.php?item.898 |title=Egypt reverses decision: Will host African Championships after all |last=Ryan |first=John |date=6 December 2009|work=Team Handball News |accessdate=13 December 2009}} The Egyptian federation announced it would host the tournament after all. [[FIFA]] opened disciplinary proceedings against the Egyptian FA for its handling of the Algerian team's security in Cairo.{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2009/nov/20/egypt-fifa-algeria-iraq |title=Egypt threaten boycott after violence of Algeria tie |date=20 November 2009 |work=The Guardian |accessdate=28 November 2009 | location=London| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20091124090905/http://www.guardian.co.uk/football/2009/nov/20/egypt-fifa-algeria-iraq| archivedate= 24 November 2009 | deadurl= no}} On 23 November FIFA announced that its Executive Committee would hold an [[extraordinary general meeting]] on 2 December in [[Cape Town]], where members were already due to meet to discuss the seedings for the World Cup, to discuss recent controversies. The Egypt–Algeria match was expected to figure, along with the dispute over [[France vs Republic of Ireland (2010 FIFA World Cup Play-Off)|France's handball goal against Ireland]], and the investigation into a major [[match-fixing]] scam.{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/internationals/8375320.stm|title=Fifa to meet over play-off issues|publisher=[[BBC Sport]]|accessdate=2009-11-23|date=2009-11-23 |archiveurl=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/internationals/8375320.stm |archivedate=2009-11-23}} FIFA's disciplinary committee was asked to launch an investigation; it was expected that the Algerian member of the committee would be [[recusal|recused]]. A report was expected by February 2010; Algeria's place at the World Cup finals was not in jeopardy.{{cite news|url=http://weekly.ahram.org.eg/2009/976/sp2.htm |title=Both will be punished |last=Mazhar |first=Inas |date=10–16 December 2009 |work=Al-Ahram Weekly|accessdate=13 December 2009|location=Cape Town }} On 25 November, 200 Egyptian intellectuals signed a statement condemning the media hype and political manipulation of the dispute.{{cite news |url=http://www.dailystar.com.lb/article.asp?edition_id=1&categ_id=4&Article_id=109146 |title=Egyptian intellectuals condemn politics of soccer violence |author=AFP |date=27 November 2009 |work=[[Daily Star (Lebanon)|Daily Star]] |accessdate=1 December 2009| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20091201012240/http://www.dailystar.com.lb/article.asp?edition_id=1&categ_id=4&Article_id=109146| archivedate= 1 December 2009 | deadurl= no}} [[Bouthaina Shaaban]], an advisor to [[Syria]]n President [[Bashar Assad]], condemned the dispute as distracting Arabs from the [[Israeli–Palestinian conflict]].{{cite news|url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-3811543,00.html |title=Syrian official: Arabs discuss football while Gazans are besieged |date=27 November 2009 |work=Israel News |accessdate=1 December 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091130042413/http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0%2C7340%2CL-3811543%2C00.html |archivedate=30 November 2009 |deadurl=yes |df= }} There were reports that [[Muammar al-Gaddafi]] and [[Israel]] had each offered to mediate in the dispute.{{cite news|url=http://thelede.blogs.nytimes.com/2009/11/25/qaddafi-selected-to-mediate-between-algeria-and-egypt/ |title=Efforts to Defuse Tensions Between Algeria and Egypt |last=Taha |first=Nadia |author2=Robert Mackey |date=25 November 2009 |work=The Lede |accessdate=27 November 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091128104240/http://thelede.blogs.nytimes.com/2009/11/25/qaddafi-selected-to-mediate-between-algeria-and-egypt/ |archivedate=28 November 2009 |deadurl=no |df= }} On 26 November, [[Reuters]] reported that a Sudanese mediation plan was nearing agreement. On 1 December, ''al-Ahram'' reported that a village in [[New Valley Governorate]] had applied to change its name from ''al-Jaza'ir'' ("Algeria") to ''Mubarak al-misriyin'' ("[[Hosni Mubarak|Mubarak]] for Egyptians").{{cite news |url=http://www.adnkronos.com/AKI/English/Sport/?id=3.0.4058772925 |title=Village changes name after Algerian clashes |date=1 December 2009 |publisher=[[Adnkronos]] |accessdate=1 December 2009}} A [[joint venture]] oil company announced on 6 December was seen as heralding a recovery in relations between the two countries.{{cite news|url=http://www.moneycontrol.com/news/business/algeria-egypt-to-form-selena-energy-joint-venture_429282.html |title=Algeria, Egypt to form Selena energy joint venture |date=7 December 2009 |publisher=Reuters |accessdate=13 December 2009 }}{{cite news|url=http://www.africanews.com/site/CairoAlgiers_ties_recovering/list_messages/28412 |title=Cairo-Algiers ties recovering |last=Roble|first=Muhyadin Ahmed |date=7 December 2009 |work=AfricaNews |location=Nairobi, Kenya |accessdate=13 December 2009| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20091210213947/http://www.africanews.com/site/CairoAlgiers_ties_recovering/list_messages/28412| archivedate= 10 December 2009 | deadurl= no}} It was reported that Egypt would not return its ambassador to Algiers unless compensation was paid for damage to Egyptian property in Algeria.{{cite news|url=http://www.iol.co.za/index.php?set_id=1&click_id=85&art_id=nw20091207115259522C811479 |title= Egypt: Algeria must say sorry and pay |author=AFP |date=7 December 2009|work=Independent Online |accessdate=13 December 2009|location=South Africa | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20091212221018/http://www.iol.co.za/index.php?set_id=1&click_id=85&art_id=nw20091207115259522C811479| archivedate= 12 December 2009 | deadurl= no}} ''[[Al-Ahram]]'' reported on 10 December that inflammatory media reports in both countries had been ended by order of the respective Presidents, following mediation by Gaddafi and al-Bashir.{{cite news|url=http://weekly.ahram.org.eg/2009/976/eg1.htm |title=Dangerous games |last=Ezzat |first=Dina |date=10–16 December 2009 |work=Al-Ahram Weekly |accessdate=13 December 2009}} Efforts by the [[United Arab Emirates Football Association|UAE FA]] to broker an accord between the Egyptian and Algerian FAs were endorsed by [[Sepp Blatter]].{{cite news|url=http://www.khaleejtimes.com/DisplayArticleNew.asp?xfile=data/sports/2009/December/sports_December315.xml§ion=sports&col= |title=Blatter Praises UAE Initiative to Solve Egypt-Algeria Row |last=Al Gizouli |first=Hisham |date=12 December 2009 |work=Khaleej Times Online |accessdate=13 December 2009}} ==Analyses== Algeria claimed there was an orchestrated media campaign to damage its reputation and to create a fictitious enemy to Egypt, to rally the masses behind [[Gamal Mubarak]] and give him some legitimacy in his bid to inherit the presidency from his father.{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/8372202.stm|title=Egypt's President Mubarak enters Algeria football row|date=2009-11-21|accessdate=2009-11-21|publisher=[[BBC]]| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20091122051622/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/8372202.stm| archivedate= 22 November 2009 | deadurl= no}} Foreign analysts suggested both governments encouraged protests about football to channel public discontent away from political issues.{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2009/nov/24/egypt-cairo-football-riots |title=Feeble excuses for Egypt's football riots |last=Mayton |first=Joseph |date=24 November 2009 |work=The Guardian |accessdate=28 November 2009 | location=London| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20091127054755/http://www.guardian.co.uk/commentisfree/2009/nov/24/egypt-cairo-football-riots| archivedate= 27 November 2009 | deadurl= no}} Jack Shenker suggests the anger was fomented primarily by the sensationalist media, with belated political endorsement.{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2009/nov/25/egypt-riots-football-world-cup |title=More to Egypt riots than football |last=Shenker |first=Jack |date=25 November 2009 |work=The Guardian |accessdate=28 November 2009 | location=London| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20091128091738/http://www.guardian.co.uk/commentisfree/2009/nov/25/egypt-riots-football-world-cup| archivedate= 28 November 2009 | deadurl= no}} Others saw the violence as an expression of a general public malaise. On 22 November 2009, ''[[The Observer]]'' suggested an opposition backlash was building in Egypt to President Mubarak's stoking of the dispute.{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2009/nov/22/mubarak-adds-fuel-to-fire |title=Mubarak adds fuel to fire as football riots spread |last=Shenker |first=Jack |date=22 November 2009 |work=The Observer |accessdate=28 November 2009 |location=Cairo | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20091125141202/http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2009/nov/22/mubarak-adds-fuel-to-fire| archivedate= 25 November 2009 | deadurl= no}} On 10 December, ''[[The New York Times]]'' made similar observations.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/12/10/world/middleeast/10egypt.html |title=A Nation's Shaken Ego Seen in a Soccer Loss |last=Slackman |first=Michael |date=10 December 2009 |work=New York Times |pages=A14 |accessdate=13 December 2009 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20111202131501/http://www.nytimes.com/2009/12/10/world/middleeast/10egypt.html| archivedate=2 December 2011| deadurl= no}} An [[Arab League]] spokesperson proposed that, in the future, celebrities and political leaders should not attend sensitive matches, lest they feed into public passions.{{cite news |url=http://www.alarabiya.net/articles/2009/11/23/92156.html |title=Egypt & Algeria soccer spat reaches Arab League |last=Belmary |first=Ramadan |author2=translator Sonia Farid|date=23 November 2009|work=[[Al Arabiya]] |accessdate=27 November 2009}} Official planes had carried 200 [[Parliament of Algeria|Algerian MP]]s to the Cairo match, and 133 Egyptian celebrities to the Khartoum match. ==References== {{reflist|2}} {{FIFA World Cup 2010 Qualifiers}} Dispute}} [[Category:2009 in Sudanese sport|Egypt-Algeria World Cup Dispute]] [[Category:2009 in African football|Egypt-Algeria World Cup Dispute]] [[Category:2009–10 in Algerian football|Egypt]] [[Category:2009–10 in Egyptian football|Algeria]] [[Category:2010 FIFA World Cup qualification (CAF)|Egypt-Algeria World Cup Dispute 2009]] [[Category:Algeria–Egypt relations]] [[Category:Association football hooliganism|Egypt-Algeria World Cup Dispute 2009]] [[Category:International association football competitions hosted by Sudan]] [[Category:Foreign relations of Sudan|Egypt-Algeria World Cup Dispute 2009]] [[Category:FIFA World Cup qualification matches|Egypt-Algeria]] [[Category:2009 in Algerian sport]] [[Category:FIFA World Cup controversies|Egypt]] [[Category:2009 controversies|Egypt-Algeria]] [[Category:Egypt national football team matches|Egypt-Algeria World Cup Dispute]] [[Category:Algeria national football team matches|Egypt-Algeria World Cup Dispute]]

page.title: 2015 Oklahoma State University homecoming parade crash

revision.text:
{{Infobox event | title = 2015 Oklahoma State University homecoming parade crash | image = | image_size = | image_alt = | caption = | time = 10:31 a.m. [[Central Time Zone|CDT]] | date = {{start date|2015|10|24}} | location = Hall of Fame Avenue & Main Street, [[Stillwater, Oklahoma|Stillwater]], [[Oklahoma]] | coordinates = {{coord|36|07|36.7|N|97|03|31.3|W|region:XXXX_type:event|display=inline,title}} | type = [[Traffic collision|Vehicle collision]] | theme = | cause = Under investigation | outcome = | reported deaths = 4 | reported injuries = 46 | reported missing = | reported property damage = | burial = | arrests = | suspects = | accused = Adacia Chambers | convicted = | charges = Four counts of [[Murder (United States law)|second-degree murder]], 46 charges of assault<ref name="people1211">{{cite news|last1=Fowler|first1=Tara|title=OSU Parade Crash Suspect Adacia Chambers Found Competent to Stand Trial|url=http://www.people.com/article/osu-parade-crash-suspect-adacia-chambers-found-competent-stand-trial|accessdate=December 24, 2015|work=[[People (magazine)|People]]|date=December 11, 2015}}</ref> | verdict = | convictions = | litigation = }}
The '''2015 Oklahoma State University homecoming parade crash''' was a [[vehicle collision]] that occurred on October 24, 2015, in [[Stillwater, Oklahoma]], when a driver drove into a crowd watching the [[homecoming]] [[parade]] for [[Oklahoma State University–Stillwater]] on the university's campus.<ref name="newspress-osucrash">{{cite news|title=Update: At least three dead, multiple people injured after car plows into Homecoming parade|url=http://www.stwnewspress.com/news/update-at-least-three-dead-multiple-people-injured-after-car/article_8fc4ca56-7a6a-11e5-a6b1-47c936d793c7.html|author=David Bitton|newspaper=[[NewsPress|Stillwater News-Press]]|publisher=[[Community Newspaper Holdings]]|date=October 24, 2015}}</ref> Four people were killed in the crash, and 46 others were reported injured.<ref name="koco-osucrash">{{cite news|title=4th victim, a 2-year-old, dies after OSU homecoming crash|url=http://www.koco.com/news/several-hurt-in-crash-at-osu-parade/36027322|author=Zak Patterson|website=[[KOCO-TV]]|publisher=[[Hearst Television]]|date=October 24, 2015}}</ref><ref name="kfor-osucrash">{{cite news|title=Four dead and dozens injured, one in custody after wreck during OSU homecoming parade in Stillwater|url=http://kfor.com/2015/10/24/two-dead-and-dozens-injured-during-osu-homecoming-parade-in-stillwater/|website=[[KFOR-TV]]|publisher=[[Tribune Broadcasting]]|date=October 24, 2015|accessdate=October 25, 2015}}</ref><ref name="wapo-osucrash">{{cite news|title=Oklahoma State Homecoming shattered as car kills 4 spectators, including 2-year-old|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/early-lead/wp/2015/10/25/oklahoma-state-homecoming-shattered-as-car-kills-4-spectators-including-2-year-old/|author=Cindy Boren|newspaper=[[The Washington Post]]|publisher=[[Jeff Bezos|Nash Holdings, LLC]]|date=October 25, 2015}}</ref>
==Event== The incident occurred at 10:31 a.m. [[Central Time Zone|Central Time]] (1531 [[Universal Coordinated Time|UTC]]), during Oklahoma State University's annual Sea of Orange Homecoming Parade, which was being held that morning, leading up to that day's [[college football|football]] game between the [[2015 Oklahoma State Cowboys football team|Oklahoma State Cowboys]] and the [[2015 Kansas Jayhawks football team|Kansas Jayhawks]]. After the parade had crossed the intersection of Hall of Fame Avenue and Main Streets ({{convert|0.40|mi|km}} east of [[Boone Pickens Stadium]]) on the university campus, where the parade was supposed to conclude, 25-year-old Adacia Avery Chambers – a native of [[Oologah, Oklahoma|Oologah]] and resident of Stillwater – drove her gray 2014 [[Hyundai Elantra]] south on Main at speeds above {{convert|40|mph|kph}} into several barriers used to block off commuter traffic and then proceeded to hit an unmanned [[motorcycle]] belonging to the Stillwater Police Department, which was providing security assistance for the event; Chambers' car then careened into approximately 50 parade spectators before stopping when its two front tires popped the curb on the southwest corner of the intersection.<ref name="newspress-osucrash"/><ref name="kfor-osucrash"/><ref name="wapo-osucrash"/><ref name="cnn-osucrash">{{cite news|title=Police release names of dead, injured from Oklahoma State tragedy – many children|url=http://www.cnn.com/2015/10/24/us/oklahoma-car-into-crowd/|author=Jason Hanna|author2=Kevin Conlon|website=[[CNN]]|publisher=[[Turner Broadcasting System]]|date=October 25, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Oklahoma State copes with losses from Homecoming Parade tragedy|url=http://okcfox.com/news/local/oklahoma-state-copes-with-losses-from-homecoming-parade-tragedy|author=Mireya Garcia|website=[[KOKH-TV]]|publisher=[[Sinclair Broadcast Group]]|date=October 24, 2015|accessdate=October 25, 2015}}</ref>
Local paramedics and firefighters participating in the parade immediately began tending to those who were injured. Three of the victims who were hit by Chambers' vehicle in the collision – 23-year-old Nikita Prabhaker Nakal, a native of [[Mumbai]], [[India]] who was an attending senior at the [[University of Central Oklahoma]] in [[Edmond, Oklahoma|Edmond]]; and husband and wife Marvin Lyle and Bonnie Jean Stone, both age 65 and residing in Stillwater – died at the scene; 2-year-old Nash Lucas, also of Stillwater, suffered severe injuries and died while being treated at [[OU Medicine#The Children's Hospital at OU Medicine|The Children's Hospital at OU Medicine]] in [[Oklahoma City]] hours after the crash (his mother was among those injured in the crash). 47 other people – including nine children between the ages of 1 and 13 – were admitted for various injuries at Stillwater Medical Center; [[OU Medicine#OU Medical Center|OU Medical Center]] and The Children's Hospital in Oklahoma City; and St. Johns Medical Center in [[Tulsa, Oklahoma|Tulsa]]. The intersection was subsequently blocked off by Stillwater and university law enforcement.<ref name="koco-osucrash"/><ref name="wapo-osucrash"/><ref name="cnn-osucrash"/><ref name="newspress-osucrashrelease">{{cite news|title= City of Stillwater releases names and conditions of homecoming parade accident victims|url=http://www.stwnewspress.com/news/city-of-stillwater-releases-names-and-conditions-of-homecoming-parade/article_3b68b3a6-7b22-11e5-8b17-877f937812d8.html|newspaper=Stillwater News-Press|publisher=Community Newspaper Holdings|date=October 25, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Special Centralities from President Betz for Saturday, Oct. 24, 2015|url=http://blasts.uco.edu/centralities/special-centralities-from-president-betz-for-saturday,-oct.-24,-2015.html|website=[[University of Central Oklahoma]]|date=October 24, 2015|accessdate=October 25, 2015}}</ref><ref name="usatoday-osucrash">{{cite news|title=3 dead after driver plows into Oklahoma State homecoming parade|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/sports/ncaaf/big12/2015/10/24/fatal-car-crash-kills-two-at-oklahoma-state-homecoming-parade/74532230/|author=Jim Varney|author2=Trevor Hughes|newspaper=[[USA Today]]|publisher=[[Gannett Company]]|date=October 24, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Oklahoma State University Parade Turns Deadly as Car Crash Kills 4|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/10/25/us/3-killed-as-car-plows-into-crowd-at-oklahoma-state-university.html|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|publisher=[[The New York Times Company]]|date=October 24, 2015|accessdate=October 25, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=UPDATED: OU Medical Center, Stillwater Medical Center release information about patients involved with fatal crash at OSU homecoming parade|url=http://www.ocolly.com/news/article_9e634610-7a91-11e5-b982-23690f141bed.html|newspaper=The O'Colly|publisher=[[Oklahoma State University]]|date=October 24, 2015|accessdate=October 25, 2015}}</ref>
===Legal proceedings=== Chambers was arrested near the crash site by Stillwater Police Department officers present at the scene of the accident on suspicion of [[driving under the influence]]; she was later placed into a detox unit in the [[Payne County, Oklahoma|Payne County]] Jail. Results of blood tests to gauge the levels of any alcohol or narcotic intoxicants in Chambers' body – a requirement for police to administer for "serious" vehicle accidents involving a fatality under Oklahoma state law – revealed she had a blood alcohol level of .01, not enough to be charged with driving under the influence. Chambers was arraigned at Payne County District Court on October 26, with any additional charges against her pending further investigation into the cause of the collision that is presented to the Payne County District Attorney's office.<ref name="usatoday-osucrash"/> Chambers was charged with four counts of second-degree murder and 46 charges of assault.<ref name="people1211"/> Her bail was set at $1 million.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://news.yahoo.com/latest-suspect-oklahoma-state-crash-due-court-062806594.html|title=The Latest: DA says Oklahoma parade deaths seem intentional|publisher=[[Yahoo News]]|date=October 27, 2015}}</ref> Her trial was scheduled to begin January 10, 2017.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.yahoo.com/news/100s-witnesses-expected-oklahoma-parade-crash-trial-135352623.html|title=100s of witnesses named in Oklahoma parade crash trial|publisher=[[Yahoo News]]|date=September 16, 2016|accessdate=December 8, 2016}}</ref> On January 10, 2017, she was sentenced to life in prison after accepting a plea deal.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/news/adacia-chambers-oklahoma-state-homecoming-crash-sentenced/|title=Adacia Chambers sentenced in deadly Oklahoma State homecoming crash|publisher=CBS NEWS|date=January 10, 2017|accessdate=January 11, 2017}}</ref>
On January 10, 2017, Adacia Avery Chambers pleaded no contest to four counts of second-degree murder and 39 counts of assault and battery by means or force likely to produce death. Chambers received life in prison for each murder count, to be served concurrently, and 10 years in prison for each assault count, to also be served concurrently. The plea agreement ensures Chambers will serve a 55-year sentence and will not leave prison until her early 70s, pending parole for both the life sentence and assault sentence.<ref>http://newsok.com/article/5533802</ref>
==Reactions== During a [[press conference]] on the crash held that afternoon, [[Burns Hargis]], president of Oklahoma State University, stated, "Tragically we lost three. I hope we don't lose anymore. [...] The Cowboy family pulls together, unfortunately, we’ve had to do it before, and we're going to do it again." Stillwater mayor Gina Noble, who had served as the parade's [[grand marshal]], later remarked that "We are heartbroken at this tragedy." Noble later commented, "We’ve never seen anything like this. [...] We’re shocked. We are definitely subdued in mood and we’re still trying to understand. [...] We will get through this together and figure out how to help those who need the help."<ref name="usatoday-osucrash"/><ref name="foxnews=osucrash">{{cite news|title=3 dead, 22 injured in crash at OSU parade; woman taken into custody for DUI|url=http://www.foxnews.com/us/2015/10/24/multiple-injuries-reported-in-crash-at-osu-homecoming-parade/|website=[[Fox News Channel|Fox News]]|publisher=Fox News Networks, LLC|date=October 24, 2015}}</ref>
The homecoming football game between [[Oklahoma State Cowboys football|Oklahoma State]] and [[Kansas Jayhawks football|Kansas]] – in which the Cowboys defeated the Jayhawks, 58-10 – was played as scheduled at 2:30 p.m. that afternoon; a [[pep rally]] originally set to be held before the game was cancelled, however. Before the game (which was televised nationally on [[Fox Sports 1|FS1]]), [[Governor of Oklahoma|Oklahoma Governor]] [[Mary Fallin]], an alumna of the university who was in attendance at the game, led players and spectators in a moment of prayer as the [[Flag of the United States|United States flag]] flew at half staff in Boone Pickens Stadium.<ref name="usatoday-osucrash"/><ref>{{cite news|title=OSU-KU game will go on|url=http://newsok.com/article/5455779|newspaper=[[The Oklahoman]]|publisher=The Anschutz Corporation|date=October 24, 2015|accessdate=October 25, 2015}}</ref>
Fallin expressed condolences during a press conference that occurred during [[halftime]] of the game, "Our hearts and prayers go out with those who lost loved ones today, to those that were injured in the tragedy," and referenced the two previous tragedies involving the university during the past 14 years (the [[Oklahoma State Cowboys basketball team plane crash|January 2001 plane crash]] that killed ten members of the [[Oklahoma State Cowboys basketball|Cowboys basketball team]] and the [[Oklahoma State Cowgirls basketball team plane crash|November 2011 plane crash]] that killed four people, including [[Oklahoma State Cowgirls basketball|Cowgirls basketball]] head coach [[Kurt Budke]] and assistant coach Miranda Serna), adding "One thing I do know about Oklahoma people. They’re strong. They're very compassionate. They believe in prayer. They believe in comforting people and helping during a time of crisis and need. We’ll get through this again. But certainly it’s a very painful experience for those of us here, and certainly for all Oklahomans."<ref name="usatoday-osucrash"/>
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
==External links== *[http://edition.cnn.com/videos/us/2015/10/25/oklahoma-state-homecoming-car-crowd-valencia-dnt-nr.cnn Video shows moment of Oklahoma State parade crash]
{{Oklahoma State Cowboys football navbox}}
