The design of steering wheels are free by the manufacturer *'''Safety equipment''': [[Sabelt]] ([[Audi Sport|Audi]])/Schroth ([[BMW Motorsport|BMW]] and [[Mercedes-Benz in motorsport|Mercedes-Benz]]) 6-point seat belt, HANS device =====Engine===== *'''Manufacturers''': [[Audi Sport GmbH|Audi]], [[BMW Motorsport|BMW]] and [[mercedes-Benz in motorsport|Mercedes-Benz]] *'''Configuration''': V8 engine, 90-degree cylinder angle *'''Displacement''': {{Convert|4.0|L|cuin|0|lk=on|abbr=on}} *'''Valvetrain''': 2x[[DOHC]], four-valves per cylinder (32-valve) *'''Pistons''': [[Mahle GmbH|Mahle]] forged aluminium alloy *'''Fuel''': [[Aral AG|Aral Ultimate]] 102 RON unleaded racing gasoline *'''Injector''': Electronic indirect fuel injection *'''Aspiration''': Naturally aspirated, air intake limited by two 29 mm restrictors *'''Power output''': Over {{Convert|500|hp|kW|0|lk=on|abbr=on}} *'''Torque''': Approx. 500 Nm (369 ft lb) *'''Lubrication''': Dry sump *'''Maximum revs''': 9,000 rpm *'''Engine management''': Bosch Motronic MS 5.1 *'''Max speed''': Up to {{Convert|170|mph|kph|0|lk=on|abbr=on}} *'''Cooling''': Single water pump *'''Spark plugs''': [[Robert Bosch GmbH|Bosch]] *'''Ignition''': [[Capacitor discharge ignition|CDI]] coil *'''Exhaust''': Silenced 4-way catalytic converter with side exit. Steel/nickel material *'''Weight''': {{Convert|148|kg|lb|0|lk=on|abbr=on}} ===Comparison with Formula One=== A Deutsche Tourenwagen Masters car is a single-seat touring car racing. For much of their history Deutsche Tourenwagen Masters cars have more different to Formula One cars, although there have traditionally been several key differences between the two. Over the years both Deutsche Tourenwagen Masters and [[Formula One]] race schedules are traditionally held in permanent racing courses. The increased stress and speed of these tracks mean that the cars tended to be heavier, wider and have shorter wheelbases than F1 cars (increasing stability but decreasing agility). When the weight of the driver is factored in, a Deutsche Tourenwagen Masters car weighed over 55% more than a Formula One Car. The minimum weight for a Deutsche Tourenwagen Masters car was adjusted from {{Convert|1080|kg|lb|0|lk=on|abbr=on}} based on the weight of the driver compared to the field average; with the driver included, all cars had a minimum weight of {{Convert|1120|kg|lb|0|lk=on|abbr=on}} (with a Balance of Performance weight allowance range of {{Convert|1095|-|1140|kg|lb|0|lk=on|abbr=on}}. A Deutsche Tourenwagen Masters car piloted by 82 kg [[Maxime Martin]] (the heaviest driver in the series and 10 kg heavier than the field average) had to have weighed at least 1,080 kg when empty. The minimum weight of a Formula One Car, including the driver, currently {{Convert|722|kg|lb|0|lk=on|abbr=on}}. This difference of {{Convert|398|kg|lb|0|lk=on|abbr=on}} is just over 55% of the 2017 F1 car's weight. Beginning in the [[2000 Deutsche Tourenwagen Masters|inaugural season of the reborn DTM]] that Deutsche Tourenwagen Masters cars used the {{Convert|4.0|L|cuin|0|lk=on|abbr=on}} [[naturally-aspirated engine|naturally-aspirated]] 90-degree [[V8 engine]]s but that time in 2000 [[Formula One]] were used the {{Convert|3.0|L|cuin|0|lk=on|abbr=on}} [[naturally-aspirated engine|naturally-aspirated]] various bank angle [[V10 engine]]s until end of 2005. Deutsche Tourenwagen Masters cars had up to {{Convert|460|hp|kW|0|lk=on|abbr=on}} more compared to their Formula One counterparts, as early as in the 70s the cars had in excess of 1,000 hp. Deutsche Tourenwagen Masters cars having {{Convert|460|hp|kW|0|lk=on|abbr=on}} on demand and F1 cars having around 700 hp to 840 hp in 3.5L NA (1989–94) era, around 700 hp to 1000 hp for final specs in 3.0L NA V10 (1995–2005) era and around 770 hp to 840 hp in 2.4L NA V8 (2006–2013) era and currently over 800hp (2017 spec combustion engine alone) with an additional 160hp from the electric motors from their 1.6L V6 turbo-hybrid-electro powerunit.http://www.motorsport-total.com/f1/news/2014/03/wie-viel-ps-hat-der-neue-turbomotor-lauda-outet-mercedes-14030502.htmlhttp://www.formel1.de/saison/reglement/technisches-reglement The turbo used mainly to improve the spectacle rather than lap-times with the so-called 'power-to-pass' or 'push-to-pass' system giving drivers an increased amount of power for a limited duration during the race. Another reason for retaining the turbocharger especially in Formula-1 is the muffling effect it has on the exhaust note, which helps keep the cars inside noise-limits, to meet FIA regulations and rules at the many city street races in European cities on the racing season schedule. Deutsche Tourenwagen Masters cars used unleaded gasoline for fuel rather than leaded gasoline, and refuelling had always been banned during the race since 2012 season. This is a legacy of an incident at the second Hockenheimring race in 2008 that involving [[Marcus Winkelhock]] due to fuel spill after over refuelling. Until 1994, when refuelling was re-introduced to F1 (and banned again from 2010 onwards), the coupling for the refuelling hose was a notable difference between Deutsche Tourenwagen Masters cars (canister refueler) and Formula cars (hose refueler). Refuelling were allowed in DTM from 2000 to 2011 seasons. Deutsche Tourenwagen Masters cars has flat undersides to improve stability. F1 banned sculpted undersides in a bid to lower cornering speeds for 1983. In an effort to create better passing opportunities, the new spec Deutsche Tourenwagen Masters cars being introduced in 2012 will generate nearly 50% of the total downforce of the car with flat underside tunnels versus the front splitter and rear wing. This will reduce turbulent air behind the cars, enabling easier overtaking. Unlike in F1, Deutsche Tourenwagen Masters teams were obliged to [[Formula One#Drivers and constructors|construct their own chassis]] for only main teams, and had tended to buy cars constructed by independent suppliers such as [[Audi]], [[BMW]] and [[Mercedes-AMG]]. However Deutsche Tourenwagen Masters had essentially been a semi-spec series since 2005, with all teams favoring both [[Audi]] and [[Mercedes-Benz]] cars mainly because of [[Opel]]'s withdrawal after 2005 season. The Formula One Car is a more expensive and technology-centric platform than a DTM car. This was even the case during the new coupé era since 2012 season. At this time global automotive manufacturers [[Audi]], [[BMW]] and [[Mercedes-AMG]] vied for dominance. Since Deutsche Tourenwagen Masters's restructuring, a desire to keep costs down and the existence of two car manufacturer helped create a series with far more parity than [[Formula One]] in 2006. For top speeds, Deutsche Tourenwagen Masters cars are slower than [[Formula One]] car in fact (DTM cars have {{Convert|168|mph|km/h|0|lk=on|abbr=on}} in a normal tracks meanwhile [[Formula One car]]s have {{Convert|225|mph|km/h|0|lk=on|abbr=on}} in a high-speed tracks such as [[Autodromo Nazionale Monza|Monza]]). ==Scoring systems== [[File:DTM 2007 Oschersleben.jpg|thumb|230px|Oschersleben 2007: [[Mike Rockenfeller|Rockenfeller]], [[Mika Häkkinen|Häkkinen]] and [[Bruno Spengler|Spengler]]]] This is the evolution of DTM points scoring system history since reborn. ;2000 {| class="wikitable" style="font-size:85%; text-align:center" |- ! If there is still a tie, DTM will determine the champion by the most second-place finishes, then the most third-place finishes, etc., until a champion is determined. {{Infobox spaceflight | name = Earth Escape Explorer (CU-E3) | names_list = | image = | image_caption = | image_alt = | image_size = | mission_type = Technology | operator = [[University of Colorado Boulder]] | COSPAR_ID = | SATCAT = | website = | mission_duration = 1 year | distance_travelled = 27 million km (planned) | orbits_completed = | spacecraft = | spacecraft_type = 6U [[CubeSat]] | spacecraft_bus = XB1 (Blue Canyon Technologies) | manufacturer = [[University of Colorado Boulder]] | launch_mass = {{convert|14|kg|abbr=on}} | BOL_mass = | dimensions = 10×20×30 cm | power = | launch_date = 2019{{cite news |url=https://spaceflightnow.com/2017/04/28/nasa-confirms-first-flight-of-space-launch-system-will-slip-to-2019/ |title=NASA confirms first flight of Space Launch System will slip to 2019 |work=Spaceflight Now |first=Stephen |last=Clark |date=28 April 2017 |access-date=29 April 2017}} | launch_rocket = [[Space Launch System|SLS Block 1]] | launch_site = [[Kennedy Space Center|Kennedy]] [[Kennedy Space Center Launch Complex 39|LC-39B]] | launch_contractor = | disposal_type = | declared = | deactivated = | destroyed = | last_contact = | recovery_by = | recovery_date = | decay_date = | orbit_reference = Heliocentric (Earth-trailing) |interplanetary = {{Infobox spaceflight/IP |type = flyby |object = Moon |orbits = |component = |arrival_date = |distance = |periapsis = |apoapsis = |inclination = |apsis = }} | trans_band = Uplink: [[C band (IEEE)|C band]]{{dn|date=December 2017}}
Downlink: [[X band]] | trans_frequency = C band: 5182 MHz
X band: 8447.6 MHz[https://digitalcommons.usu.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=3704&context=smallsat A Deep Space Radio Communications Link for Cubesats: The CU-E3 Communication Subsystem]. John S. Sobtzak, Elie G.Tianang, Varun Joshi, Breana M. Branham, Neeti P. Sonth, Michael DeLuca, Travis Moyer, Kyle Wislinsky, and Scott E. Palo. University of Colorado Boulder. 2017. | trans_bandwidth = | trans_capacity = 13 bits/s (at 27 million km) | trans_coverage = | trans_TWTA = | trans_EIRP = 108 dBm | trans_HPBW = | insignia = | insignia_caption = | insignia_alt = | insignia_size = }} '''Earth Escape Explorer''' ('''CU-E3''') is a [[nanosatellite]] of the 6-Unit [[CubeSat]] format that will demonstrate long-distance communications while in [[heliocentric orbit]]. [https://www.colorado.edu/cubequest/ CU Earth Escape Explorer]. University of Colorado Boulder. 2017. The ''Earth Escape Explorer'' spacecraft is a student-driven effort at [[University of Colorado Boulder]] to design and build the spacecraft as part of the NASA CubeQuest Challenge. It will be one of thirteen CubeSats to be carried with the [[Exploration Mission 1|Orion EM-1 mission]] into a [[heliocentric orbit]] in [[cislunar space]] on the maiden flight of the [[Space Launch System]], scheduled to launch in 2019.{{cite web |url=https://www.nasa.gov/press-release/three-diy-cubesats-score-rides-on-nasa-s-first-flight-of-orion-space-launch-system |title=Three DIY CubeSats Score Rides on NASA's First Flight of Orion, Space Launch System |publisher=NASA |first1=Gina |last1=Anderson |first2=Molly |last2=Porter |date=8 June 2017}} ==Objectives== The CU-E3 team is pursuing four different CubeQuest prizes: Largest aggregate data volume; most error-free data blocks; the most distant communications from Earth; and spacecraft longevity.[https://www.coloradospacenews.com/cube-quest-challenge-team-spotlight-cu-e3/ Cube Quest Challenge Team Spotlight: CU-E3]. ''Colorado Space News''. 2017. ==Design== Once deployed in the vicinity of the Moon, CU-E3 will use a lunar [[gravity assist]] to propel itself into [[heliocentric orbit]], trailing the Earth and slowly distancing itself over time. By the end of its one-year mission, CU-E3 is planned to be as far as 27 million kilometers from Earth. The spacecraft will use a commercial 6U CubeSat satellite body ([[Satellite bus|bus]]) called XB1, measuring about 10×20×30 cm. The mass is about {{convert|14|kg|abbr=on}}.[http://space.skyrocket.de/doc_sdat/cu-e3.htm CU-E3]. Gunter Dirk Krebs, ''Gunter's Space Page. 2017. Electric power will be provided by [[Solar panels on spacecraft|solar panels]] and stored in rechargeable [[Lithium battery|lithium batteries]]. ;Communications The mission is focused upon advancing [[Outer space|deep space]] CubeSat communication techniques using an innovative [[reflective array antenna]], an [[X band]] transmitter for downlink and a [[C band (IEEE)|C band]] transmitter for uplink. The antenna array is "planar", meaning all of the elements are in one plane, yet provide a large aperture for [[beam steering]] and make possible high data rates. ATLAS Ground Networks will be the ground station for their uplink and downlink communications. Their telecomm package is called High-Rate CubeSat Communication System (HRCCS). ;Propulsion CU-E3 does not feature an on board propulsion system, and will be using [[solar radiation pressure]] for [[reaction wheel]] desaturation and [[attitude control]] (orientation). ==See also== ;The 13 CubeSats flying in the Exploration Mission 1 *[[Lunar Flashlight]] will map exposed water ice on the Moon *[[Near-Earth Asteroid Scout]] by NASA is a [[solar sail]] spacecraft that will encounter a [[near-Earth asteroid]] *[[BioSentinel]] is an [[astrobiology]] mission *[[SkyFire (spacecraft)|SkyFire]] by [[Lockheed Martin]] *[[Lunar IceCube]], by the [[Morehead State University]] *[[CubeSat for Solar Particles]] (CuSP) *[[Lunar Polar Hydrogen Mapper]] (LunaH-Map), designed by the Arizona State University *[[EQUULEUS (spacecraft)|EQUULEUS]], submitted by [[JAXA]] and the [[University of Tokyo]] *[[OMOTENASHI]], submitted by JAXA, is a lunar lander *[[ArgoMoon]], designed by [[Argotec]] and coordinated by [[Italian Space Agency]] *[[Cislunar Explorers]], Cornell University, Ithaca, New York *Earth Escape Explorer (CU-E3), University of Colorado Boulder *[[Team Miles]], by Fluid & Reason, LLC. Florida ==References== {{reflist}} {{Moon spacecraft}} {{Future spaceflights}} [[Category:CubeSats]] [[Category:Missions to the Moon]] [[Category:Proposed space probes]] [[Category:2019 in spaceflight]] [[Category:2019 in the United States]]

{{Infobox criminal | name = Elmer Edward Solly | image = Edward Solly mugshot.jpg | image_size = | alt = 2001 mugshot of Elmer Edward Solly | caption = | birth_date = {{Birth date|1945|09|05}} | birth_place = | death_date = {{Death date and age|2007|11|30|1945|09|05}} | death_place = [[New Jersey]] | death_cause = | resting_place = | residence = | nationality = American | other_names = Daniel "Danny C" Catalano | occupation = | known_for = | height = | weight = | criminal_charge = [[Manslaughter]] | penalty = | conviction_status = | motive = | conviction = | time_at_large = 27 years | escaped = June 1974 | escape_end = May 10, 2001 | country = | states = | apprehended = | imprisoned = | footnotes = }} '''Elmer Edward Solly''' (September 5, 1945 – November 30, 2007) was convicted of [[manslaughter]] in 1970 for the death of two-year-old Christopher Welsh. Solly escaped from custody in 1974 and spent the next 27 years living under numerous [[pseudonym]]s. At the time of his arrest in May 2001, he was living in [[Florida]] as Daniel "Danny C" Catalano, a supposed former member of the [[United States|American]] [[rock 'n' roll]] group [[Sha Na Na]]; in fact, he never had any ties to Sha Na Na.<ref name="tisch">{{cite news |first=Chris |last=Tisch |author2=Graham Brink |title=27 years on lam, felon's gig is up |url=http://www.sptimes.com/News/051201/TampaBay/27_years_on_lam__felo.shtml |publisher=''[[St. Petersburg Times]]'' |date=2001-05-21 |accessdate=2007-08-11}}</ref><ref name="moran">{{cite news |first=Robert |last=Moran |title=Sha Na Na impostor lived a lie for years |url=http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_qn4196/is_20010524/ai_n10690510 |publisher=''[[Philadelphia Inquirer]]'' |date=2001-05-24 |accessdate=2007-08-11 }} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref>
==Manslaughter conviction and escape== On the evening of July 25, 1969, Solly, in a drunken rage, severely beat his girlfriend's two-year-old son, Christopher Welsh, who died of his injuries. Solly turned himself in to local police a few days later. He was convicted of manslaughter on April 16, 1970, and incarcerated at [[New Jersey State Prison|Trenton State Prison]]. While Solly was in Trenton State Prison, his mother and grandmother began a letter-writing campaign alleging mistreatment on the part of prison guards.<ref name="njdoc">{{cite web |url=http://www.pdcbank.state.nj.us/corrections/NJDOC_newsletter/Issue2No2_SpringFall_2001/html/newsltr_ManOnTheRun.html |archive-url=https://archive.is/20070810225515/http://www.pdcbank.state.nj.us/corrections/NJDOC_newsletter/Issue2No2_SpringFall_2001/html/newsltr_ManOnTheRun.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2007-08-10 |title=After 27 years, escaped murderer apprehended, returned to New Jersey |accessdate=2007-08-11}} </ref>
As a result of the campaign, Solly was transferred to medium-security [[Leesburg State Prison]] in 1974. There, he befriended a prison [[psychologist]], who convinced officials to allow Solly to visit his mother. During the third visit, in June 1974, Solly was accompanied only by the psychologist. Solly asked to be allowed to visit his girlfriend, and he used the opportunity to escape.<ref name="tisch" /><ref name="cbs">{{cite news |url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2004/07/08/48hours/main628273.shtml |title=The Great Pretender: Fugitive Steals Identity Of Doo-Wop Group's Lead Singer |accessdate=2007-08-11 | work=CBS News | date=July 8, 2004}}</ref> His escape was not reported to police for six hours, giving Solly sufficient time to disappear.<ref name="courttv">{{cite episode|title=Head Cases |url=http://www.courttv.com/onair/shows/the_investigators/g_p_episodes/head_cases.html |series=The Investigators |network=[[Court TV]] |airdate=2007-08-11 |minutes= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060205071245/http://www.courttv.com/onair/shows/the_investigators/g_p_episodes/head_cases.html |archivedate=2006-02-05 |df= }}</ref>
==As a fugitive== Immediately after his escape, Solly began using a series of assumed identities to evade capture. In 1975, he was arrested in [[Philadelphia]] for receiving stolen goods, but because he used a fake name, police did not realize who he was. Similarly, he provided a fake name when he was stopped for a traffic violation in 1979 and avoided detainment.<ref name="moran" /> Detectives had few leads in the case, and received no cooperation from Solly's family, particularly his mother, Edna Bolt, who consistently denied knowing her son's whereabouts. Eventually, Solly's escape was considered a [[cold case (criminology)|cold case]].<ref name="njdoc" />
Solly eventually made his way to Florida, where he assumed the identity of [[Vincent Taylor (musician)|Vinnie Taylor]], lead guitarist of the [[rock 'n' roll]] revival group [[Sha Na Na]]. The real Taylor died of a heroin overdose in 1974, but using forged documents, including a [[Social Security number|Social Security card]], a [[birth certificate]], and a [[baptism]] certificate, Solly successfully passed himself off as Taylor.<ref name="moran" /><ref name="cbs" /> Solly, posing as Taylor, claimed that Taylor's death had been staged and so he took on the new [[stage name]] of Daniel "Danny C" Catalano, and began performing and recording under that name.<ref name="tisch" /> Sha Na Na discovered the fraud and demanded that Solly cease performing as Danny C. When Solly refused, the group considered filing a lawsuit, but decided not to do so in order to deny Solly the free publicity the case would generate.<ref name="tisch" />
==Investigation and capture== In 1999, [[New Jersey State Police]], Louis Kinkle, and [[Cumberland County, New Jersey|Cumberland County]] Sheriff's Office investigators reopened the Solly case. They enlisted the aid of [[Forensic science|forensic artist]] [[Frank Bender]], who used 25-year-old photographs of Solly to create an image of what he would look like currently. In March 2000, Edna Bolt died, after which other members of Solly's family began cooperating with investigators. Bolt's husband Harry told police that Solly was living in Florida as a singer using the name Danny C. A web search revealed a website for Danny C, billing himself as the "Bad Boy" of Sha Na Na. The site featured a picture of Danny C that closely resembled the image produced by Bender.<ref name="cbs" /><ref name="courttv" />
Based on this information, authorities traveled first to [[Orlando, Florida|Orlando]] and then to [[St. Pete Beach, Florida|St. Pete Beach]].<ref name="tisch" /> They discovered Solly fishing on a pier near his apartment complex. [[United States Marshals Service|U.S. Marshals]] arrested Solly on May 10, 2001, and he was returned to New Jersey on May 18. He was convicted on October 5 for his 1974 escape and was incarcerated at Riverfront State Prison in [[Camden, New Jersey|Camden]] to serve that sentence and the remainder of his manslaughter sentence. Solly was granted [[parole]] in August 2003 for good behavior and time served. He was last reported to be living in a [[Welfare (financial aid)|welfare]] motel in New Jersey before his death.<ref name="cbs" />
==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20110523220743/https://www6.state.nj.us/DOC_Inmate/details?x=1210965&n=0 Information on New Jersey Department of Corrections site] *{{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/*/www.shananadannyc.com |date=* |title=Danny C's website }} *[http://www.dvrbs.com/people/CamdenPeople-EdwardSolly.htm]
==Notes and references== {{Reflist}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Solly, Elmer Edward}} [[Category:1945 births]] [[Category:American escapees]] [[Category:2007 deaths]] [[Category:Escapees from New Jersey detention]] [[Category:American people convicted of manslaughter]] [[Category:Impostors]]
