{{Use dmy dates|date=June 2017}} {{good article}} {{Infobox officeholder |name = Euclid Tsakalotos
{{small|Ευκλείδης Τσακαλώτος}} |honorific-suffix = [[Member of Parliament|MP]] |image = Euclid Tsakalotos.jpg |office = [[Ministry of Finance (Greece)|Minister of Finance]] |primeminister = [[Alexis Tsipras]] |term_start = 23 September 2015 |term_end = |predecessor = [[George Chouliarakis]] |successor = |primeminister1 = [[Alexis Tsipras]] |term_start1 = 6 July 2015 |term_end1 = 28 August 2015 |predecessor1 = [[Yanis Varoufakis]] |successor1 = [[George Chouliarakis]] |office2 = [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Greece)|Alternate Minister for International Economic Relations]] |primeminister2 = [[Alexis Tsipras]] |minister2 = [[Nikos Kotzias]] |term_start2 = 27 January 2015 |term_end2 = 6 July 2015 |predecessor2 = |successor2 = |office3 = Member of the [[Hellenic Parliament]]
for [[Athens B]] |term_start3 = 6 May 2012 |term_end3 = |birth_date = {{birth year and age|1960}} |birth_place = [[Rotterdam]], [[Netherlands]] |death_date = |death_place = |party = [[Syriza]] |spouse = [[Heather D. Gibson|Heather Gibson]] |alma_mater = [[The Queen's College, Oxford|Queen's College, Oxford]]
[[Institute of Development Studies]]
[[Mansfield College, Oxford]] |signature = Euclid Tsakalotos Signature.jpg |module = {{Infobox economist |embed = yes |institutions = [[University of Kent]] {{small|(1989–1993)}}
[[Athens University of Economics and Business]] {{small|(1993–2010)}}
[[National and Kapodistrian University of Athens|University of Athens]] {{small|(2010–present)}} |field = [[Monetary economics]]
[[Managerial economics]]
[[National accounts]]}} }} '''Euclid Tsakalotos''' ({{lang-el|Ευκλείδης Τσακαλώτος}}, officially Ευκλείδης Στεφάνου Τσακαλώτος,[http://www.hellenicparliament.gr/vouleftes/viografika-stoicheia/?MPId=94978a5c-ac45-4d1d-a7da-eebb0784b82e Hellenic Parliament: MPs' contact details] Note: Modern Greek middle names are typically a [[patronymic]] in the [[Genitive case#Greek|genitive case]]; thus, ''Stefanou'' from his father's name, ''Stefanos''. transcr. ''Efklidis Stefanou Tsakalotos'', {{IPA-el|efˈkliðis steˈfanu t͜sakaˈlotos}}; born 1960) is a left-wing Greek economist and politician who has been [[Ministry of Finance (Greece)|Minister of Finance of Greece]] since 2015. He is also a member of the Central Committee of [[Syriza]] and has represented [[Athens B]] in the [[Hellenic Parliament]] since [[Greek legislative election, May 2012|May 2012]]. Tsakalotos was born in [[Rotterdam]], [[Netherlands|the Netherlands]], but moved to the United Kingdom at a young age. He went to [[St Paul's School, London|St Paul's School]] in London before studying [[Philosophy, Politics and Economics]] at [[The Queen's College, Oxford]]. He went on to complete a master's degree at the [[Institute of Development Studies]], attached to the [[University of Sussex]] and returned to Oxford to complete a [[Doctor of Philosophy|doctorate]] in economics under the supervision of [[Włodzimierz Brus]], which he did in 1989. From 1989 to 1993, Tsakalotos worked at the [[University of Kent]], where he met his partner, [[Heather D. Gibson]]. He moved to Greece, and taught at the [[Athens University of Economics and Business]] from 1994 to 2010, becoming a professor of economics. Since 2010, he has been a professor of economics at the [[National and Kapodistrian University of Athens]]. He has written a number of books in both Greek and English and has been published in a range of different academic journals. A student member of the [[Communist Party of Greece (Interior)|Communist Party of Greece]], Tsakalotos joined [[Synaspismos]] in the early 1990s and was elected to the Central Committee of Syriza in 2004 shortly after their formation. He was first elected as a Member of the Hellenic Parliament for Athens B in the May 2012 legislative election and has been re-elected in every election since. In [[Shadow Cabinet of Alexis Tsipras|opposition from 2012 to 2015]], he was Syriza's shadow finance minister. When [[First Cabinet of Alexis Tsipras|Syriza entered government]] in January 2015, Tsakalotos was appointed as an Alternate Minister within the [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Greece)|Ministry of Foreign Affairs]]. In April, he took over as head of Greece's negotiating team on the [[Third Economic Adjustment Programme for Greece|third bailout package]]. On 6 July 2015, following [[Yanis Varoufakis]]'s resignation, Tsakalotos was appointed as Minister of Finance. He was [[Second Cabinet of Alexis Tsipras|re-appointed in September 2015]] following the [[Greek legislative election, September 2015|snap legislative election]]. == Early life and education == Tsakalotos was born in [[Rotterdam]], the [[Netherlands]], in 1960. He is the son of Stefanos Tsakalotos, a civil engineer who worked in the shipping industry, and the family relocated to the United Kingdom in 1965 when the younger Tsakolotos was five years old.Κατσαντώνη, Χριστίνα, "[http://www.thetoc.gr/magazine/eukleidis-tsakalwtos-o-anthrwpos-sti-skia-tou-gbaroufaki ΕυκλειδηΣ ΤσακαλωτοΣ: Ο ανθρωποΣ στη "σκια" του Γ.Βαρουφακη]", ''The Times of Change Magazine'' Τρίτη, 07 Ιουλίου 2015. Retrieved 7 July 2015 He attended [[St Paul's School, London]] from 1973 to 1978.{{efn|Some sources also claim that Tsakalotos attended [[Eton College]].{{cite news|last1=Savaricas|first1=Nathalie|title=Greece debt crisis: Euclid Tsakalotos – the new finance minister with one of the most challenging jobs in the EU|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/europe/greece-debt-crisis-euclid-tsakalotos--the-new-finance-minister-with-one-of-the-most-challenging-jobs-in-the-eu-10370108.html|accessdate=7 July 2015|work=[[The Independent]]|date=6 July 2015}}}} In St Paul's School's [[alumni magazine]], he praised his former schoolmaster Keith Perry, saying that the teacher did "much to bolster [his] self-confidence".{{cite news|last1=Rayner|first1=Gordon|title=Profile: Euclid Tsakalotos, the Leeds United fan now in charge of saving the euro|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/greece/11724425/Profile-Euclid-Tsakalotos-the-Leeds-United-fan-now-in-charge-of-saving-the-euro.html|accessdate=12 October 2015|work=The Daily Telegraph|date=7 July 2015}} During his time at the school, he co-founded its Economics and Politics Society (known as Polecon) with his close friend Owen Tudor, who now works for the [[Trades Union Congress]]. Tsakalotos went on to read [[Philosophy, Politics and Economics]] at [[The Queen's College, Oxford]]. Whilst at the Queen's College, Tsakalotos was an admirer of both [[Gerald Cohen]] and [[Andrew Glyn]], a [[Marxism|Marxist]] [[Political philosophy|political philosopher]] and [[Marxian economics|Marxian economist]] respectively, who both taught at the university. He also took part in student protests against [[Margaret Thatcher]]'s [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative]] government. During his time at university, he became a supporter of [[Irish republicanism]], a view he expressed in his visit to the [[Sinn Féin]] [[ardfheis]] in March 2015.{{cite news|url=https://www.spectator.co.uk/2015/07/charles-moores-notes-why-the-greek-no-is-a-great-moment-for-socialism/|title=Why the Greek No is a great moment for socialism|date=11 July 2015|work=The Spectator|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|last1=Moore|first1=Charles|accessdate=16 October 2015}} One of his university friends at this time, [[Yannis Stournaras]], later became a Greek finance minister and served as Governor of the [[Bank of Greece]]. Following graduation, he completed a master's degree (MPhil) at the [[Institute of Development Studies]], attached to the [[University of Sussex]]. He then returned to Oxford to complete a [[Doctorate of Philosophy|doctorate]] (DPhil) in economics, studying at [[Mansfield College, Oxford|Mansfield College]]. He completed this doctorate in 1989 under the supervision of [[Włodzimierz Brus]], with his thesis, ''[[Alternative Economic Strategies: The Case of Greece]]'', later being published as a book.{{cite web|title=Alternative economic strategies: the case of Greece / Euclid Tsakalotos|url=http://catalogue.nla.gov.au/Record/1521330|website=National Library of Australia|accessdate=27 August 2016}}{{cite web|url=http://www.mfa.gr/en/leadership/the-deputy-ministers/alternate-foreign-minister-for-international-economic-relations.html|title=Alternate Foreign Minister for International Economic Relations|website=[[Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Greece)|Ministry of Foreign Affairs]]|accessdate=8 July 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150628003554/http://www.mfa.gr/en/leadership/the-deputy-ministers/alternate-foreign-minister-for-international-economic-relations.html|archivedate=28 June 2015}}Tsakalotos, Euclid, Heather Gibson, ed., ''Alternative Economic Strategies: The Case of Greece'' ([[Aldershot]], Avebury Publishers: 1991), {{ISBN|1856281833}}{{rp|ix}} == Academic career == After the completion of his doctorate, Tsakalotos entered into an academic career. His first role was as a research associate at the [[University of Kent]], from 1989 to 1990. From October 1990 to June 1993, he taught at the university as a lecturer.{{cite news|last1=Pragnell|first1=Chris|title=University tutor Euclid Tsakalotos has become chief bail-out negotiator for Greece|url=http://www.kentonline.co.uk/canterbury/news/former-lecturer-tasked-with-rescuing-36355/|accessdate=14 August 2015|work=[[Kent Online]]|date=5 May 2015}} In 1993, Tsakalotos and his wife moved to Greece, and in October 1994 he began teaching at the [[Athens University of Economics and Business]]. In September 2010, he became a full professor of economics at the [[National and Kapodistrian University of Athens]], more commonly referred to simply as the University of Athens.[https://uoa.academia.edu/EuclidTsakalotos Euclid Tsakalotos: National & Kapodistrian University of Athens]. uoa.academia.edu. Retrieved 6 July 2015 In his capacity as an academic, Tsakalotos served as a member of the executive committee of the Hellenic Federation of University Teachers' Associations (POSDEP). In the mid-2000s, Tsakalotos led his students in a several months-long protest against proposed reforms to the Greek education system. Thanos Tsouknidas, an accountant that knew Tsakalotos at the time, said: "He was there, involved in the struggle. We were fighting together." His active role in the teachers' union brought him popularity, and according to a former student, his classes were often packed. Tsakalotos has written a number of books and articles on Greek and international economic policies, alone and in cooperation with other academics and writers. He has co-authored a number of works with his wife, who has also served as editor for some of the works that he has written alone.{{efn|Some of Tsakalotos' work has sparked debate in academic circles, leading to some articles being published in response to his work. These include ''Educating Capitalists: A Rejoinder to Wright and Tsakalotos'' by [[Wolfgang Streeck]], as well as ''Tsakalotos on "Homo Economicus": Some Comments'' by Guglielmo Carchedi.{{cite journal|last1=Carchedi|first1=Guglielmo|title=Tsakalotos on 'Homo Economicus': Some Comments|journal=Science & Society|date=July 2006|volume=70|issue=3|pages=370–375}}{{cite journal|last1=Streeck|first1=Wolfgang|title=Educating Capitalists: A Rejoinder to Wright and Tsakalotos|journal=Socio-Economic Review|year=2004|volume=2|issue=3|pages=425–438|url=http://www.mpi-fg-koeln.mpg.de/people/ws/downloads/Educating%20Capitalists.pdf|accessdate=17 September 2016}}}} == Early political career == As a student at the University of Oxford, Tsakalotos joined the [[Communist Party of Greece (Interior)]], a [[Eurocommunism|eurocommunist]] party that had split from the main [[Communist Party of Greece]], a [[Marxism–Leninism|Marxist–Leninist]] party, in 1968. In the early 1990s, shortly after moving to Greece, Tsakalotos became a member of [[Synaspismos]], a radical left-wing political party, which was to become the largest constituent party of [[Syriza]].{{cite news|last1=Smith|first1=Helena|title=Euclid Tsakalotos: Greece's secret weapon in credit negotiations|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/jun/18/euclid-tsakalotos-greeces-secret-weapon-in-credit-negotiations|accessdate=6 July 2015|work=[[The Guardian]]|date=18 June 2015}} Syriza itself was formed in 2004, ahead of that year's [[Greek legislative election, 2004|legislative election]], as a coalition of 13 left-wing political parties in Greece.{{Cite web|url=http://www.workersliberty.org/whogreek|title=Who are the Greek left?|date=22 May 2012|website=Workers' Liberty|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=18 March 2017}} Tsakalotos was elected to their Central Committee in December 2004.{{el}} [http://www.syriza.gr/page/boyleytes.html The Greek Government] syriza.gr. Retrieved 6 July 2015{{cite news|title=Euclid Tsakalotos: Bye bye creative vagueness, hello method and detail!|url=http://en.protothema.gr/euclid-tsakalotos-bye-bye-creative-vagueness-hello-method-and-detail/|accessdate=16 August 2015|work=Protothema|date=29 April 2015}} However, he also remained a prominent member of Synaspismos and served on both their Central Political Committee and their Political Secretariat until a July 2013 party congress, during which Syriza voted to become an independent political party and for all component parties to disband, including Synaspismos.{{cite news|last1=Skordas|first1=Aggelos|title=Euclid Tsakalotos: Who Is the Greek Economist that Sidelined Superstar Yanis Varoufakis|url=http://greece.greekreporter.com/2015/04/28/euclid-tsakalotos-who-is-the-greek-economist-that-sidelined-superstar-yanis-varoufakis/|accessdate=10 August 2015|work=Greek Reporter|date=28 April 2015}}{{Cite news|url=https://socialistworker.org/2013/07/30/the-battle-for-syriza-goes-on|title=The battle for SYRIZA goes on|last=Panos|first=Petrou|date=30 July 2013|work=Socialist Worker|access-date=18 March 2017|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}} Shortly after Syriza was formed, Tsakalotos stood as their candidate for the prefecture of [[Preveza (regional unit)|Preveza]] in the 2004 legislative election. The [[Greek government-debt crisis]] effectively began in 2009 and was a backdrop for Tsakalotos' involvement in the creation of Syriza's economic policy. Tsakalotos has been credited as the "brains behind" the policy, and as a member of Syriza's "economics quartet", alongside [[John Milios]], [[Giorgos Stathakis]] and [[Yannis Dragasakis]].{{cite news|url=http://www.grreporter.info/en/who_hiding_behind_economic_programme_syriza/7063|title=Who is hiding behind the economic programme of SYRIZA|date=5 June 2012|work=GR Reporters|accessdate=11 September 2015}} He has also been credited as one author of Syriza's [[Thessaloniki Programme]], a manifesto which proposed a set of policies oriented towards reversing [[Austerity|austerity measures]] while maintaining a [[balanced budget]].{{cite news|title=Debate on Wed. as Greece heads into yet another … election|url=http://en.protothema.gr/debate-on-wed-as-greece-heads-into-yet-another-election/|accessdate=11 September 2015|work=Protothema|date=8 September 2015}} == In opposition (2012–2015) ==
{{Reduced pull quote|left|Some things which are now seen as unrealistic will change with the political balance of forces.|Euclid Tsakalotos|[[London School of Economics|LSE]] meeting}}
In the [[Greek legislative election, May 2012|May 2012 legislative election]], Tsakalotos was elected as a Member of the [[Hellenic Parliament]] (MP) representing [[Athens B]], the largest electoral district in Greece. The election saw Syriza win 16.8% of the vote, placing second behind [[New Democracy (Greece)|New Democracy]], who won 18.8% of the vote, and ahead of [[PASOK]], with 13%. [[Alexis Tsipras]], the party leader, was unable to form a coalition, but also refused to enter into one with PASOK, forcing the country to new elections in [[Greek legislative election, June 2012|June 2012]], where Tsakalotos won re-election as an MP. Tsakalotos said that Syriza had a focus on the [[European Union]], and told ''[[The New York Times]]'' that a Europe imposing austerity on its citizens for the actions of banks "isn't the Europe that the original inspirators of Europe imagined".{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/05/12/world/europe/in-greece-leftist-party-syriza-upends-politics.html|title=Leftist Party's Rise Upends Greek Political Order|last=Donadio|first=Rachel|date=11 May 2012|work=The New York Times|access-date=18 March 2017|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}} New Democracy won a plurality of seats in June 2012 and formed a coalition government with PASOK and [[Democratic Left (Greece)|Democratic Left]], making Syriza the largest opposition party with 78 seats.{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/06/18/world/europe/greek-elections.html|title=Supporters of Bailout Claim Victory in Greek Election|last=Donadio|first=Rachel|date=17 June 2012|work=The New York Times|access-date=18 March 2017|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}} Tsakalotos' role in opposition was as the spokesperson for economic affairs in Tsipras' [[Shadow Cabinet of Alexis Tsipras|shadow cabinet]].{{cite news|title=SYRIZA's shadow cabinet to exercise 'hands-on opposition'|url=http://www.ekathimerini.com/142852/article/ekathimerini/news/syrizas-shadow-cabinet-to-exercise-hands-on-opposition|accessdate=10 July 2015|work=Ekathimerini|date=4 July 2012}} In opposition from 2012 to 2015, Tsakalotos was a key proponent of Syriza's economic policy. He argued that Greece needed something similar to the [[Marshall Plan]], with a payment scheme that took into account the strength of the economy. He told [[Bloomberg News]] that "People say that we are responsible for the situation we find ourselves in. OK, sure. But I think that Germany will find it hard to argue that in 1953 [at the time of the [[London Agreement on German External Debts]]] they were completely blameless."{{Cite news|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2012-05-30/alexis-tsiprass-conquest-of-greece|title=Alexis Tsipras' Conquest of Greece|last=Faris|first=Stephen|date=1 June 2012|work=Bloomberg News|access-date=18 March 2017|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}} He appeared in various international media as a spokesperson for Syriza and making the case for their policies: among others, he was interviewed on ''[[Lateline]]'', an Australian news programme on [[Australian Broadcasting Corporation|ABC]],{{Cite news|url=http://www.abc.net.au/lateline/content/2012/s3503667.htm|title=Greece 'can do better' than German deal|date=15 May 2012|work=Lateline|access-date=18 March 2017|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}} by [[Special Broadcasting Service|SBS]], another Australian news channel,{{Cite web|url=http://www.sbs.com.au/news/insight/tvepisode/exit-greece|title=Exit Greece|date=22 May 2012|website=SBS|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=18 March 2017}} was quoted by the [[BBC]] and [[Bloomberg News|Bloomberg]],{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-21140766|title=EU viewpoints on Cameron's Europe speech|date=24 January 2013|publisher=BBC News|access-date=18 March 2017|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}} and also appeared in an [[Intelligence Squared]] debate arguing for the motion '[[Angela Merkel]] is Destroying Europe'.{{cite web|title=Angela Merkel is Destroying Europe|url=http://www.intelligencesquared.com/events/angela-merkel-is-destroying-europe/|website=[[Intelligence Squared]]|accessdate=14 August 2015}} September 2013 saw his book, co-authored with [[Christos Laskos]], published by [[Pluto Press]]. ''[[Crucible of Resistance]]'' was described as offering "badly needed correctives" to the prevalent ideas on the Greek situation.{{Cite news|url=http://souciant.com/2014/01/inside-merkels-greece/|title=Inside Merkel's Greece|date=15 January 2014|work=Souciant|access-date=18 March 2017|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}} The book addressed why the [[European debt crisis]] began, with a particular focus on Greece. It argued that the idea Greece was exceptional was a myth and that the crisis had revealed the inadequacies of [[neoliberalism]] and [[social democracy]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.plutobooks.com/display.asp?K=9780745333809|title=Crucible of Resistance|website=Pluto Press|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=18 March 2017}} Tsakalotos was criticised by elements of the Greek media in 2013 when he was accused of living a wealthy lifestyle while criticising austerity in public. He was dubbed the 'aristocrat of the left', and one newspaper published front-page criticism arguing that Tsakalotos' own family wealth came from investments made by companies such as [[JPMorgan Chase]] and [[BlackRock]]. In December 2014, the Hellenic Parliament did not approve the new [[President of Greece|President]] with the supermajority required, and so a [[snap election]] was called for the end of January 2015.{{Cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/greece/11315842/Greece-to-hold-snap-elections-as-parliament-refuses-to-approve-new-president.html|title=Greece to hold snap elections as parliament refuses to approve new president|last=Waterfield|first=Bruno|date=29 December 2014|work=The Daily Telegraph|access-date=18 March 2017|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}} A few days before the 2015 election took place, Tsakalotos was quizzed on Syriza's economic policies by a number of economists, debt campaigners and investment analysts at the [[London School of Economics]]. Tsakalotos said there was a need for [[fiscal space]], meaning 6–7 billion [[Euro]]s a year to spend on an expansionary [[fiscal policy]]. He also said that they would cancel the austerity budgets already agreed with the [[European Union]] (EU) and [[International Monetary Fund]] (IMF), pay back the loans from the IMF and focus on rescheduling and [[Write-off|writing off]] the loans from the EU.{{cite web|last1=Roberts|first1=Michael|title=Syriza, the economists and the impossible triangle|url=https://thenextrecession.wordpress.com/2015/01/21/syriza-the-economists-and-the-impossible-triangle/|website=Michael Roberts Blog|accessdate=14 August 2015|date=21 January 2015}}{{cite web|last1=Mason|first1=Paul|authorlink1=Paul Mason (journalist)|title=Inside Syriza's economic brain|url=http://blogs.channel4.com/paul-mason-blog/Greece-syriza-election/2941|website=Channel 4 News|accessdate=14 August 2015|date=20 January 2015}} ==First term in government (2015)== === Alternate Minister and bailout negotiator === In the [[Greek legislative election, January 2015|legislative election]] on 25 January 2015, Syriza won a near-majority of seats, with 149 out of 300, and so formed a coalition with the right-wing anti-austerity party [[Independent Greeks]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/jan/25/greece-election-vote-austerity-leftwing-syriza-eu|title=Greece elections: anti-austerity Syriza party sweeps to stunning victory|last=Henley|first=Jon|date=26 January 2015|work=The Guardian|access-date=18 March 2017|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}} Tsipras became [[Prime Minister of Greece|prime minister]] and formed his [[First Cabinet of Alexis Tsipras|cabinet]] on 27 January, appointing Tsakalotos as Alternate Minister for International Economic Relations, subordinate to the [[Minister for Foreign Affairs (Greece)|Minister for Foreign Affairs]], [[Nikos Kotzias]].{{cite news|last1=Cosgrave|first1=Jenny|title=Euclid Tsakalotos, the new 'friendly face' of Greece?|url=https://www.cnbc.com/id/102650151|accessdate=6 July 2015|publisher=CNBC|date=6 May 2015}} Tsakalotos described his role as follows: "[It] means coordinating our approach to promoting exports and attracting investment. It also means upgrading our economic diplomacy which needs to go beyond traditional sectors, for instance exporting olive oil and importing capital goods."{{cite news|title=An Interview with Euclid Tsakalotos|url=http://opclub.stpaulsschool.org.uk/file/Euclid-interview-from-OPN-Spring-2015.pdf|accessdate=19 June 2016|work=Old Pauline News|date=April 2015}} [[File:Euclid Tsakalotos Gerry Adams 2015.jpg|300px|thumb|Euclid Tsakalotos with Gerry Adams at the Sinn Féin ardfheis in March 2015.]] Tsakalotos represented Syriza at the Sinn Féin ardfheis on 7 March 2015 and gave a speech on the conference floor, during which he said that both Sinn Féin and Syriza are "part of a great realignment in European politics" towards left-wing anti-austerity parties. The leader of Sinn Féin, [[Gerry Adams]], embraced Tsakalotos on the stage following the speech.{{cite news|last1=Minihan|first1=Mary|title=Syriza appeals for European solidarity at Sinn Féin ardfheis|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/news/politics/syriza-appeals-for-european-solidarity-at-sinn-f%C3%A9in-ardfheis-1.2130771|accessdate=7 July 2015|work=The Irish Times|date=7 March 2015}} Tsakalotos then spent several hours afterwards in talks with senior members of Sinn Féin.{{cite news|last1=McCann|first1=Eamonn|title=Late-night talks may have shaped Sinn Fein stance|url=http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/opinion/columnists/eamonn-mccann/latenight-talks-may-have-shaped-sinn-fein-stance-31056270.html|accessdate=16 October 2015|work=The Belfast Telegraph|date=11 March 2015}} The ''[[Financial Times]]'' later commented on this, saying it was a "moment of bonding" between Syriza and Sinn Féin.{{cite news|last1=Boland|first1=Vincent|title=Sinn Féin's alliance with Syriza shows shift in leftwing politics|url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/bd3b96aa-24ba-11e5-bd83-71cb60e8f08c.html|accessdate=15 August 2015|work=Financial Times|date=7 July 2015}} Tsakalotos began to gain a more prominent role in the renegotiations with Greece's creditors over a new bailout plan, which at the time were being led by Yanis Varoufakis, the [[Ministry of Finance (Greece)|Minister of Finance]]. On 27 April, Tsakalotos was the made the coordinator of the Greek team negotiating with the creditor's representatives over this new bailout plan. This move was largely seen as sidelining [[Yanis Varoufakis]], the [[Minister of Finance (Greece)|Minister of Finance]], but the markets reacted positively.{{cite news|last1=Cassidy|first1=John|title=Sidelining Varoufakis Won't Solve Greece's Real Problem|url=http://www.newyorker.com/news/john-cassidy/sidelining-varoufakis-wont-solve-greeces-real-problem|accessdate=14 December 2015|work=The New Yorker|date=28 April 2015}}{{cite news|last1=Chrysopoulos|first1=Philip|title=Varoufakis Downsized as Tsipras Forms New Greek Negotiating Team|url=http://greece.greekreporter.com/2015/04/27/varoufakis-downsized-as-tsipras-forms-new-greek-negotiating-team/|accessdate=6 July 2015|work=Greek Reporter|date=27 April 2015}} In June 2015, lenders warned that time was running out for a deal to be agreed on a new bailout plan. On 17 June, Tsakalotos warned that Greece would not be able to repay its €1.6bn loan from the IMF at the end of the month unless a new bailout plan was agreed.{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/business/2015/jun/24/greece-fortnight-crisis-timeline|title=Timeline: Greece's fortnight of crisis|last=Kollewe|first=Julia|date=25 June 2015|work=The Guardian|access-date=18 March 2017|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}} The deadline for the renewal of Greece's bailout package was also looming at the end of June. On 26 June, an emergency cabinet meeting led to the calling of a [[Greek bailout referendum, 2015|referendum on the bailout deal]] proposed by the creditors. [[Capital control]]s and a [[bank holiday]] were announced on 28 June, with the Eurozone refusing an extension of the bailout plan and Greece defaulting on its loan to the IMF on 30 June.{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/business/2015/jun/29/greece-crisis-timeline-the-weekend-that-rocked-the-eurozone|title=Greece crisis timeline: the weekend that rocked the eurozone|last=Allen|first=Katie|date=29 June 2015|work=The Guardian|access-date=18 March 2017|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-33325886|title=Greece debt crisis: Eurozone rejects bailout appeal|date=30 June 2015|publisher=BBC News|access-date=18 March 2017|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}} === Minister of Finance === The bailout referendum on 5 July resulted in a 'No' vote to the adoption of the bailout package. The following day, Varoufakis resigned as finance minister. As he left the finance ministry, he suggested that Tsakalotos was likely to succeed him, and Tsakalotos was subsequently sworn-in later that day.{{cite news|last1=Platzos|first1=Kostis|title=Greece's Varoufakis hints Tsakalotos to take over as finance minister|url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/2015/07/06/us-eurozone-greece-varoufakis-sec-idUKKCN0PG16S20150706|accessdate=15 August 2015|agency=Reuters|date=6 July 2015}}{{cite news|last1=Khan|first1=Mehreen|title=Meet Euclid Tsakalotos, the man who has replaced Yanis Varoufakis as Greece's new finance minister|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/economics/11566624/Euclid-Tsakalotos-Yanis-Varoufakis-Greece-new-finance-minister.html|accessdate=6 July 2015|work=The Telegraph|date=6 July 2015}} In the process of this, Tsakalotos relinquished his previous ministerial position of Alternate Minister for International Economic Relations.{{cite news|last1=Leivada|first1=Danae|title=Can Greece's New Finance Minister Succeed Where Varoufakis Couldn't?|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2015/07/07/euclid-tsakalotos-greece_n_7743926.html?1436295540?/?clear|accessdate=8 July 2015|work=The Huffington Post|date=7 July 2015}} Tsakalotos was noted for his differences with Varoufakis, for example, the ''Financial Times'' noted that he "could hardly be more different from his flamboyant predecessor".{{cite news|last1=Hope|first1=Kerin|title=Change of style at the Greek finance ministry|url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/2785fdc2-2400-11e5-9c4e-a775d2b173ca.html|accessdate=6 August 2015|work=Financial Times|date=6 July 2015}} At a press conference shortly following his appointment, Tsakalotos said: "I cannot hide from you that I am quite nervous. I am not taking on this job at the easiest point in Greek history."{{cite news|last1=Kambas|first1=Michele|last2=Galloni|first2=Alessandra|title=New Greek finance minister is a change of style, not substance|url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/2015/07/06/eurozone-greece-minister-idUKL8N0ZM3VT20150706|accessdate=15 August 2015|agency=Reuters|date=6 July 2015}} Tsakalotos' first official meeting as Minister of Finance was on 7 July and was an emergency meeting of the [[Eurogroup]] following the vote in the referendum. Tsakalotos brought a note with him that reminded him to display "no triumphalism" after the 'No' vote in the Greek bailout referendum.{{cite news|last1=Treanor|first1=Jill|title=Greece's new finance minister has to remind himself: 'No triumphalism'|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/jul/07/greeces-new-finance-minister-has-to-remind-himself-no-triumphalism|accessdate=16 July 2015|work=The Guardian|date=7 July 2015}} Following the talks, he was described as "Much better than Varoufakis".{{cite news|last1=Guarascio|first1=Francesco|last2=Macdonald|first2=Alastair|title=New Greek minister's note to self: 'No triumphalism'|url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/2015/07/07/us-eurozone-greece-triumphalism-idUKKCN0PH2HD20150707|accessdate=15 August 2015|agency=Reuters|date=8 July 2015}} Greece was given 48 hours to agree to a new bailout plan or it would face being [[Greek withdrawal from the eurozone|forced to leave the eurozone]] on 8 July,{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/jul/07/greece-crisis-eurozone-tsipras-banking-collapse|title=Greece given days to agree bailout deal or face banking collapse and euro exit|last=Traynor|first=Ian|date=8 July 2015|work=The Guardian|access-date=18 March 2017|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}} leading to a plan being submitted by the Greek government on 10 July.{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-33472699|title=Greece debt crisis: Eurozone receives economic reform plan|date=10 July 2015|publisher=BBC News|access-date=18 March 2017|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}} In a nine-hour Eurogroup meetings on 11 July, Tsakalotos was noted for his calmness in the "tough, even violent" atmosphere of the talks by observers.{{cite news|last1=Macdonald|first1=Alastair|title='Kindergarten' as weary euro ministers divide over Greece|url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/2015/07/12/uk-eurozone-greece-eurogroup-kindergarte-idUKKCN0PM0M620150712|accessdate=15 August 2015|agency=Reuters|date=12 July 2015}} The government backed the [[Tenth austerity package (Greece)|tenth austerity package]] which went before Parliament on 16 July. The package was the first in a series of prior actions necessary for negotiations to open up over bailout funding worth 86 billion euros.Ovenden, p. 169 The package came in two parts, with the first being approved on 16 July, and the second on 23 July. The legislation included a rise in [[Value-added tax|VAT]] across several goods and services, the abolition of the VAT discount for Greek islands, a corporation tax rise from 26% to 29%, a luxury tax on cars, boats and swimming pools, an end to early retirement by 2022, and an increase in the retirement age to 67.{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-33535205|title=Greece debt crisis: Eurozone deal laws backed by MPs|date=16 July 2015|publisher=BBC News|access-date=18 March 2017|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}} Tsakalotos said on 16 July debate, "I don't know if we did the right thing, however, I do know that we felt like we had no other choice but do what we did."{{cite news|title=Greek finance minister: 'I don't know if we did the right thing' – video|url=https://www.theguardian.com/business/video/2015/jul/16/greek-bailout-finance-minister-vote-video|accessdate=16 July 2015|work=The Guardian|date=16 July 2015}} The contentious vote was opposed by 109 out of 201 members of the Central Committee of Syriza, and 32 Syriza MPs voted against the proposals on 16 July. It also led to a [[First Cabinet of Alexis Tsipras#17 July 2015 cabinet reshuffle|cabinet reshuffle on 17 July]], but Tsakalotos retained his role as Minister of Finance.{{cite news|url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/2015/07/17/us-eurozone-greece-tsakalotos-idUKKCN0PR1UL20150717|title=Greek Finance Minister Tsakalotos to keep post in reshuffle|date=17 July 2015|agency=Reuters|last2=Melander|first2=Ingrid|last1=Maltezou|first1=Renee|accessdate=15 August 2015}} The second set of measures were debated and voted on 23 July, with Tsakalotos beginning the debate, and urging a vote in favour of the measures.{{cite news|last1=Smith|first1=Helena|last2=Wearden|first2=Graeme|title=Greek parliament approves next phase in bailout reforms|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/jul/22/greece-ecb-emergency-assistance-ceiling-raised-bailout-vote|accessdate=6 August 2015|work=The Guardian|date=23 July 2015}} Tsakalotos was criticised for his speech, with Ovenden writing that "[his] argument made him sound little different from the kind of kindergarten exchanges which had characterised Pasok and New Democracy over the years."Ovenden, p. 170 However, the proposals passed parliament, clearing the way for a new bailout deal to be negotiated with Greece's creditors.{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/business/2015/jul/23/greece-debt-crisis-vote-clears-way-for-bailout-talks|title=Greek debt crisis: vote clears way for bailout talks|last=Rankin|first=Jennifer|date=23 July 2015|work=The Guardian|access-date=18 March 2017|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}} A new bailout deal, the [[Third Economic Adjustment Programme for Greece]], was agreed in August 2015, and the first set of measures went to vote on 14 August, in the form of the [[Eleventh austerity package (Greece)|eleventh austerity package]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-33934238|title=Greece crisis: Eurogroup agrees to third bailout|date=14 August 2015|publisher=BBC News|access-date=18 March 2017|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}} Tsakalotos opened the debate, calling the deal a "very tough agreement with many thorns." During the debate, he engaged heavily with the acting President of New Democracy, [[Vangelis Meimarakis]], who criticised Tsakalotos for being "provocative".{{cite news|title=Greece MPs vote on key bailout deal|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-33914956|accessdate=25 June 2016|publisher=BBC News|date=14 August 2015}}{{cite news|title=Fiery all-night debate in Greek parliament before bailout vote|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/video/2015/aug/14/greek-parliament-finance-minister-debate-bailout-vote-video|accessdate=15 August 2015|work=The Guardian|date=14 August 2015}} Towards the end of the debate, [[Zoi Konstantopoulou]], the [[Speaker of the Hellenic Parliament]], raised so many procedural questions and objections that Tsakalotos missed the 9:30 am vote to catch a flight to [[Brussels]].{{cite news|last1=Henley|first1=Jon|title=Alexis Tsipras is down but far from out|url=https://www.theguardian.com/business/2015/aug/14/alexis-tsipras-greece-bailout-vote-new-election|accessdate=15 August 2015|work=The Guardian|date=14 August 2015}} More than 40 Syriza MPs voted against the plans, and it was suggested that Tsipras may resign, bringing the prospect of another snap election in September. In Brussels later that day, final negotiations were concluded for the Third Economic Adjustment Programme for Greece.{{cite news|last1=Chee|first1=Foo Yun|last2=Saeedy|first2=Alexander|title=Tsakalotos says bailout deal will take country forward|url=http://www.ekathimerini.com/200582/article/ekathimerini/business/tsakalotos-says-bailout-deal-will-take-country-forward|accessdate=30 October 2015|work=Kathimerini|date=15 August 2015}} On 20 August, Tsipras announced the resignation of the Syriza-[[ANEL]] government, and that a [[Greek legislative election, September 2015|legislative election was scheduled for 20 September]].{{cite news|title=Greece crisis: PM Alexis Tsipras quits and calls early polls|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-34007859|accessdate=14 September 2015|publisher=BBC News|date=20 August 2015}} Tsakalotos and the rest of the cabinet remained as [[Lame duck (politics)|lame duck]] ministers whilst opposition parties attempted to form their own government. However, the opposition parties failed to form a government and [[Vassiliki Thanou-Christophilou]] was appointed as an interim Prime Minister on 27 August.{{cite news|title=Greece debt crisis: Interim PM Thanou is first woman leader|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-34077933|accessdate=14 September 2015|publisher=BBC News|date=27 August 2015}} On 28 August, Thanou-Christophilou's [[Caretaker Cabinet of Vassiliki Thanou-Christophilou|caretaker cabinet]] was sworn in, with [[George Chouliarakis]] being sworn in as the interim Minister of Finance.{{cite news|last1=Papamiltiadou|first1=Angelika|title=Greece Names George Houliarakis As Interim Finance Minister|url=https://www.marketnews.com/content/greece-names-george-houliarakis-interim-finance-minister|accessdate=14 September 2015|date=28 August 2015}} ==Second term in government (2015–present)== [[File:Tsak ECOFIN 2016.jpg|300px|thumb|left|Tsakalotos at an informal meeting of [[Economic and Financial Affairs Council|ECOFIN]] in [[Bratislava]] on 9 September 2016.]] === Reappointment as Minister of Finance === [[Reuters]] reported that Tsakalotos was considering not running in the September 2015 legislative election, as he did not want to have to implement the bailout agreement.{{cite news|last1=Maltezou|first1=Renee|last2=Babington|first2=Deepa|title=With election near, Tsipras faces widening rift within Syriza|url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/2015/08/28/us-eurozone-greece-syriza-idUKKCN0QX1SF20150828|accessdate=10 September 2015|agency=Reuters|date=28 August 2015}} However, these fears were assuaged by Alexis Tsipras when he said there was no doubt that Tsakalotos would stand in the election.{{cite news|last1=Papadimas|first1=Lefteris|last2=Maltezou|first2=Renee|title=Tsipras softens stand on Greek debt relief before election|url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/2015/08/26/us-eurozone-greece-election-idUKKCN0QV1NI20150826|accessdate=10 September 2015|agency=Reuters|date=26 August 2015}} He also claimed that, during the election campaign, without Tsakalotos' involvement, there would have been no bailout package. In recognition of that, Tsakalotos was made to head the list for Syriza in Athens B. In an interview during the campaign, Tsakalotos admitted that the Greek government had suffered "defeat" during negotiations with creditors, implying that some responsibility for this lay with his predecessor, Varoufakis.{{cite news|last1=Gilson|first1=George|title=Tsakalotos sees prospect of limited improvements to new bailout memorandum|url=http://www.thetoc.gr/eng/economy/article/tsakalotos-sees-prospect-of-limited-improvements-to-new-bailout-memorandum|accessdate=10 September 2015|work=The Times of Change|date=10 September 2015}} Following the re-election of the Syriza-ANEL coalition, Tsakalotos was tipped to resume the role of Minister of Finance,{{cite news|last1=Wearden|first1=Graeme|last2=Smith|first2=Helena|title=Euclid Tsakalotos expected to keep cabinet place|url=https://www.theguardian.com/business/live/2015/sep/21/greek-elections-tsipras-sworn-in-pm-bailout-live#block-55fffe4ee4b00e7fa159820d|accessdate=22 September 2015|work=The Guardian|date=21 September 2015}} however the state media reported that he was reluctant to do so.{{cite news|last1=Maltezou|first1=Renee|last2=Kambas|first2=Michele|title=Tsipras to back Greek bailout with Tsakalotos as finance minister|url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/2015/09/22/eurozone-greece-cabinet-idUKL5N11S0YQ20150922|agency=Reuters|date=22 September 2015}} Nonetheless, he was reappointed as Minister of Finance on 23 September, as part of the [[Second Cabinet of Alexis Tsipras|Tsipras' second cabinet]].{{cite news|title=Greece keeps Euclid Tsakalotos as finance minister after election win|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/sep/23/greece-keeps-euclid-tsakalotos-as-finance-minister-after-election-win|accessdate=11 October 2015|work=The Guardian|date=23 September 2015}} Chouliarakis, the interim Minister of Finance, was retained in the finance ministry as an Alternate Minister of Finance.{{cite news|last1=Smith|first1=Helena|title=Greece: Alexis Tsipras retains economics team in cabinet with unenviable task|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/sep/23/greece-alexis-tsipras-cabinet-unenviable-task|accessdate=11 October 2015|work=The Guardian|date=23 September 2015}} Later in September, in an interview with the ''Financial Times'', Tsakalotos said that it was "absolutely critical that we get something on debt relief." He added: "By the second quarter of 2016, if we get a positive review, bank recapitalisation and debt relief, I don’t see any reason why there shouldn’t be a return to growth." He also said that the new government would make serious attempts to crack down on tax evasion: "It will be a central aspect of our policies, which will determine the success of the government, because it’s the only way the Greek people will accept difficult measures that show we’re all in the same boat."{{cite news|last1=Barber|first1=Tony|last2=Hope|first2=Kerin|title=Greek finance minister upbeat on growth prospects|url=https://next.ft.com/content/956f3cb6-6507-11e5-9846-de406ccb37f2|accessdate=5 June 2016|work=Financial Times|date=27 September 2015}} At the annual meetings of the IMF and the [[World Bank]] between 9 and 11 October 2015, Tsakalotos had a number of meetings with high-level attendees.{{cite news|title=U.S. Treasury Secretary stresses importance of debt relief in meeting with FinMin Tsakalotos|url=http://www.amna.gr/english/article/11592/U.S.-Treasury-Secretary-stresses-importance-of-debt-relief-in-meeting-with-FinMin-Tsakalotos|accessdate=15 October 2015|work=ANA-MPA}}{{cite news|title=Tsakalotos – Lagarde meeting took place in positive climate|url=http://english.capital.gr/News.asp?id=2384012|accessdate=15 October 2015|work=Capital.gr|date=12 October 2015}} On 8 January 2016, Tsakalotos began a tour of European cities, including Rome, Lisbon, Paris, Helsinki and Berlin, meeting with finance ministers, prior to a Eurogroup meeting on 14 January.{{Cite news|url = http://www.ekathimerini.com/204898/article/ekathimerini/news/athens-irked-by-suggestion-review-will-be-drawn-out|title = Athens irked by suggestion review will be drawn out|date = 8 January 2016|work = Kathimerini|access-date = 10 January 2016}} In February 2016, Spyros Economides, Director of the Hellenic Observatory, commented on Tsakalotos' performance as Minister of Finance: "In some ways, he has done an extremely good job because the mess left by his predecessor both in substantive and presentational terms was horrific."{{cite news|last1=MacDowell|first1=Andrew|title=Greek Finance Minister Tsakalotos Grudgingly Placates Creditos|url=http://www.institutionalinvestor.com/article/3524818/asset-management-macro/greek-finance-minister-tsakalotos-grudgingly-placates-creditors.html?ArticleId=3524818#/.V2cWjtQrI1I|accessdate=19 June 2016|work=Institutional Investor|date=1 February 2016}} Tsakalotos visited the [[European Parliament]] in March 2016 and told [[Member of the European Parliament|MEPs]] of the [[European Parliament Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs|Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs]] that he welcomed their role in monitoring the reforms.{{Cite web|url=http://www.europarl.europa.eu/news/en/news-room/20160302IPR16694/greek-finance-minister-euclid-tsakalotos-welcomes-ep-role-in-monitoring-reforms|title=Greek Finance Minister Euclid Tsakalotos welcomes EP role in monitoring reforms|date=2 March 2016|website=European Parliament|access-date=26 January 2017}} === Bailout review and calls for IMF involvement === The first review of the bailout programme carried out by Greece's lenders stalled in February 2016 over pension reforms. Speaking to ''[[Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung]]'', Tsakalotos urged the lenders to complete the review by 1 May as "This question of time is important if we want to move from a vicious to a virtuous circle."{{Cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-eurozone-greece-idUSKCN0W9153|title=Greece urges completion of reform review by May 1|last=Bellon|first=Tina|date=7 March 2016|agency=Reuters|access-date=26 January 2017}} He wrote to other members of the Eurogroup on 6 May to appeal for their support against extra demands for austerity that, he argued, were beyond the mandate of the Greek government.{{Cite news|url=https://blogs.wsj.com/brussels/2016/05/08/greek-finance-minister-appeals-to-eurozone-colleagues-political-empathy-slams-imf-math/|title=Greek Finance Minister Appeals to Eurozone Colleagues' Political Empathy, Slams IMF Math|last=Walker|first=Marcus|date=8 May 2016|work=The Wall Street Journal|access-date=26 January 2017}} Speaking in October 2016, Tsakalotos said that he wanted the IMF to join the bailout programme and that [[Wolfgang Schäuble]]'s position on debt relief for Greece was untenable. Schäuble said that the bailout programme "will work, the IMF will be on board and there won't be much debt relief." However, Tsakalotos said that "Something has to give there, and I think deep down in his heart he understands that. He's a wily politician. He's been around for a long time. I can't believe he doesn't understand you can't have all those three things."{{Cite news|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-10-08/greece-s-tsakalotos-says-german-position-on-debt-is-unrealistic|title=Greece's Tsakalotos Says German Position on Debt Is Unrealistic|last=Argitis|first=Theophilis|date=8 October 2016|work=Bloomberg News|last2=Lacqua|first2=Francine|access-date=25 January 2017}} == Political views == ===Ideology=== Tsakalotos has been described as a "[[Marxist]]",{{cite news|title=Synchronised somersault|url=https://www.economist.com/news/europe/21667963-prime-minister-pivots-away-leftism-and-his-party-follows-synchronised-somersault|accessdate=11 October 2015|work=The Economist|date=26 September 2015}} and Ovenden has written that "While [[John Maynard Keynes|Keynes]] is the main economic reference point for Varoufakis, who opposed the Brussels deal, for Tsakalotos, who signed it, Marx is more that guide to economic and political analysis."Ovenden, p. 173 [[Paul Mason (journalist)|Paul Mason]] described Tsakalotos as a "classic Marxist of the [[New Left]]," continuing that "Tsakalotos comes from that school of Marxism which learned from the 1970s onwards to make compromises with capitalist reality."{{cite news|last1=Mason|first1=Paul|title=Syriza's reshuffle: step forward a non-erratic Marxist|url=http://blogs.channel4.com/paul-mason-blog/syrizas-reshuffle-step-nonerratic-marxist/3613|accessdate=25 June 2016|work=Channel 4 News|date=27 April 2015}} In an interview with the ''Financial Times'' in September 2015, following his re-appointment, he said: "I’m one of the government’s most left-wing ministers, politically speaking. However, I want to do things like the recapitalisation of the banks. I can do things that aren’t particularly left-wing." Tsakalotos is also a leading member of the Group of 53, a prominent faction within Syriza. One report names him as the leader of the Group.{{cite news|last1=Anastasia|first1=Balezdrova|title=The situation is favourable for New Democracy but Greeks may give Tsipras a second chance|url=http://www.grreporter.info/en/situation_favourable_new_democracy_greeks_may_give_tsipras_second_chance/13237|accessdate=20 September 2015|work=GR Reporter|date=4 September 2015}} The Group was founded in mid-2014 and stands ideologically between the Left Platform and Alexis Tsipras's core backers.Ovenden, p. 166{{cite news|last1=Nektaria|first1=Stamouli|title=Greece's Alexis Tsipras Struggles to Keep Syriza Party Together|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/greeces-alexis-tspiras-faces-growing-challenge-of-a-disintegrating-party-1440594654|accessdate=20 September 2015|work=The Wall Street Journal|date=26 August 2015}} After the Left Platform split from Syriza to [[Popular Unity (Greece)|Popular Unity]], the Group of 53 became the most left-wing faction within Syriza. ===Europe=== Tsakalotos has been described as a "Revolutionary Europeanist", as he supports European Union integration but not its capitalist principles. In one article, he wrote: "[the] European Monetary Union has created a split between [the] core and periphery, and relations between the two are hierarchical and discriminatory." Tsakalotos has also advocated for a "change in [the] architecture" of the [[Eurozone]]. He has also suggested that the EU should have a focus on the [[Development economics|development]] of member countries, which is what requires this change in architecture.{{Cite news|url=https://www.opendemocracy.net/can-europe-make-it/euclid-tsakalotos/europe-of-two-narratives|title=A Europe of two narratives|last=Tsakalotos|first=Euclid|date=27 December 2016|work=OpenDemocracy|access-date=18 March 2017|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}} In a May 2012 interview on ''Lateline'', Tsakalotos said: "At the moment the Eurozone is at risk, not because of the Greek radical left – it's at risk because it has an architecture, a financial and economic architecture that is evidently unable to deal with the crisis in the Eurozone, and we think part of the solution is a change in that architecture."{{cite web|title=Greece 'can do better' than German deal|url=http://www.abc.net.au/lateline/content/2012/s3503667.htm|publisher=Australian Broadcasting Corporation|accessdate=19 June 2016}} In 2011, he cited a move towards [[fiscal federalism]] as a potential solution to the EU's economic architecture.{{Cite journal|last=Tsakalotos|first=Euclid|year=2011|title=Contesting Greek Exceptionalism within the European crisis|url=http://www.e-history.eu/files/uploads/Paper_-_2011.05.16.pdf|journal=Hellenic Observatory|pages=2}} ==Personal life== Tsakalotos is married to [[Heather D. Gibson]], a Scottish economist currently serving as Director-Advisor to the Bank of Greece and his ofttimes research and writing partner. They met when Tsakalotos was teaching at the University of Kent and they later married in [[Canterbury]]. The couple has three children and maintains two homes in [[Kifisia]], along with an office in Athens and a holiday home in [[Preveza]], all courtesy of a large estate belonging to Tsakalotos' father. Through his father, Euclid Tsakalotos is the first cousin twice-removed (great-grandnephew) of [[Thrasyvoulos Tsakalotos]], who served as Chief of the [[Hellenic Army General Staff]] from 1951 to 1952.{{cite news|last1=Skordas|first1=Aggelos|title=Euclid Tsakalotos: Who Is the Greek Economist that Sidelined Superstar Yanis Varoufakis|url=http://greece.greekreporter.com/2015/04/28/euclid-tsakalotos-who-is-the-greek-economist-that-sidelined-superstar-yanis-varoufakis/|accessdate=6 July 2015|work=Greek Reporter|date=28 April 2015}} Tsakalotos has been quoted as saying that his great-granduncle fought on the "other side, the wrong side" in the [[Greek Civil War]], and was worried that his great-grandnephew would become a "liberal, [but] certainly not anything further to the left." Tsakalotos is a fan of [[PAOK FC]] and was given a shirt with [[Dimitar Berbatov]]'s name on the back by Alexis Tsipras.{{cite news|title=Dimitar Berbatov brings Greek football to a higher level|url=http://www.grreporter.info/en/dimitar_berbatov_brings_greek_football_higher_level/13245|accessdate=20 September 2015|work=GR Reporters|date=7 September 2015}} When he lived in the UK, he was a supporter of [[Leeds United]]. == Works == ===Books=== * ''[[Crucible of Resistance|Crucible of Resistance: Greece, the Eurozone and the World Economic Crisis]]'' (with [[Christos Laskos]], [[Pluto Press]], London, Chicago: 2013), {{ISBN|074533380X}} * ''22 Πράγματα που μας λένε για την ελληνική κρίση και δεν είναι έτσι'' (''22 Things they tell you about the Greek Crisis which are not so''; with [[Christos Laskos]], KPSM Publications: 2012), {{ISBN|9789606750700}} * ''Χωρίς επιστροφή'' (''No Return''; with [[Christos Laskos]], KPSM Publications: 2011), {{ISBN|9789606750595}} * ''Corporatism and Economic Performance: A Comparative Analysis of Market Economies'' (with Andrew Henley, [[Edward Elgar Publishing]]: 1993) {{ISBN|185278539X}} * ''[[Alternative Economic Strategies: The Case of Greece]]'' (Avebury Publishers, [[Aldershot]]: 1991), {{ISBN|1856281833}} ===Articles and papers=== Tsakalotos has published a number of articles and papers, including several co-authored with his wife, Heather Gibson, and others. He has been published in a range of [[Academic journal]]s, such as the ''[[Cambridge Journal of Economics]]'', the ''[[Oxford Bulletin of Economics and Statistics]]'' and the ''[[Oxford Review of Economic Policy]]''.{{cite web|url=https://uoa.academia.edu/EuclidTsakalotos|title=Euclid Tsakalotos|website=Academia|accessdate=9 September 2015}} For a full list, see the link to his page on [[Academia.edu]] in the ''[[Euclid Tsakalotos#External links|External links]]''. == See also == * [[First Cabinet of Alexis Tsipras]] * [[Second Cabinet of Alexis Tsipras]] * [[Greek government-debt crisis]] ==Notes== {{notelist}} ==References== ===Citations=== {{reflist|30em}} ===Sources=== * [[Kevin Ovenden|Ovenden, Kevin]] (2015). ''Syriza: Inside the Labyrinth''. London: [[Pluto Press]]. {{ISBN|0745336868}}. ==External links== {{Sister project links | wikt=no | b=no | n=no |s=no | v=no | voy=no | species=no |d=Q19428891 | display=Euclid Tsakalotos }} * {{Hellenic Parliament|94978a5c-ac45-4d1d-a7da-eebb0784b82e|cv=el}} * [https://uoa.academia.edu/EuclidTsakalotos Euclid Tsakalotos' publications] at [[Academia.edu]] {{s-start}} {{s-off}} {{s-bef|before=[[Yanis Varoufakis]]}} {{s-ttl|title=[[Ministry of Finance (Greece)|Minister of Finance]]|years=2015}} {{s-aft|after={{nowrap|[[George Chouliarakis]]}}}} |- {{s-bef|before={{nowrap|[[George Chouliarakis]]}}}} {{s-ttl|title=[[Ministry of Finance (Greece)|Minister of Finance]]|years=2015–present}} {{s-inc}} {{s-end}} {{Finance Ministers of Greece}} {{Current Cabinet of Greece}} {{Eurogroup}} {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Tsakalotos, Euclid}} [[Category:1960 births]] [[Category:Academics of the University of Kent]] [[Category:Alumni of The Queen's College, Oxford]] [[Category:Alumni of the University of Sussex]] [[Category:Coalition of Left, of Movements and Ecology politicians]] [[Category:Finance ministers of Greece]] [[Category:Greek economists]] [[Category:Greek expatriates in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Greek government-debt crisis]] [[Category:Greek MPs 2012 (May)]] [[Category:Greek MPs 2012–14]] [[Category:Greek MPs 2015 (February–August)]] [[Category:Greek MPs 2015–]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People educated at St Paul's School, London]] [[Category:People from London]] [[Category:People from Rotterdam]] [[Category:Syriza politicians]] [[Category:Greek expatriates in the Netherlands]]

revision.comment: +[[Category:Economic crises]]; ±[[Category:Economic crises]]→[[Category:Economic crises in Europe]] using [[WP:HC|HotCat]]
revision.text:
'''Europeans for Financial Reform''' ('''EFFR''') is a coalition dedicated to effecting reform in the financial and banking sectors. EFFR was created in Brussels on September 21, 2009, just over a year after the collapse of [[Lehman Brothers]] and the beginning of the [[financial crisis]].<ref>http://www.efinancialnews.com/homepage/content/1055221370</ref>
EFFR pursues a campaign called "Regulate Global Finance Now!", which was launched September 21, 2009. The goals of this campaign are to raise awareness of the need for financial reform and to get governments to do adopt following reforms:
*To regulate speculative funds, such as [[hedge funds]] and [[private equity funds]] *To create a [[financial transaction tax]] *To regulate executive and shareholder bonus and remuneration *To close down [[tax havens]] *To protect consumers from toxic financial products and [[predatory lending]], and *To democratise finance<ref>http://europeansforfinancialreform.org/en/system/files/CALL_TO_ACTION.pdf</ref>
The founding members of the coalition were the [[Global Progressive Forum]], [[European Trade Union Confederation]],<ref>http://www.etuc.org/a/7506</ref> the Foundation for European Progressive Studies, [[Solidar]] and [[UNI Global Union]].<ref>http://europeansforfinancialreform.org/en/node/217</ref>
Europeans for Financial Reform is open to the membership of other NGOs, trade unions and think tanks, as well as individuals. It is not officially linked to any political party, although politicians can join the campaign as individuals. One high-profile politician involved in the campaign is former Prime Minister of Denmark [[Poul Nyrup Rasmussen]]<ref>http://europolitics.abccom.cyberscope.fr/new-coalition-wants-real-financial-reform-art248458-1.html</ref>
Europeans for Financial Reform is associated with its counterpart in the United States, [[Americans for Financial Reform]].<ref>http://www.euractiv.com/en/opinion/ideological-divides-rule-g20/article-185706#</ref>

{{Infobox Song Contest | name = Eurovision Song Contest | year = 1979 | size = 180px | logo = ESC 1979 logo.png | final = 31 March 1979 | presenters = [[Daniel Pe'er]]
[[Yardena Arazi]] | exsupervisor = [[Frank Naef]] | conductor = [[Izhak Graziani]] | director = Yossi Zemach | exproducer = [[Alex Gilady]] | host = [[Israeli Broadcasting Authority]] (IBA) | venue = Ussishkin Auditorium at the
[[International Convention Center (Jerusalem)|International Convention Center]]
[[Jerusalem]], [[Israel]] | winner = {{esc|Israel|y=1979}}
"[[Hallelujah (Gali Atari and Milk & Honey song)|Hallelujah]]" | vote = Each country awarded 12, 10, 8-1 point(s) to their 10 favourite songs | entries = 19 | debut = None | return = None | withdraw = {{esc|Turkey}} | null = None | interval = Shalom '79 ''(Peace '79)'' | opening = | Green = Y | Green SA = | Purple = | Red = | Yellow = Y }} The '''Eurovision Song Contest 1979''' was the 24th edition of the annual [[Eurovision Song Contest]]. It was held on 31 March 1979 in [[Jerusalem]], [[Israel]], following the country's win at the [[Eurovision Song Contest 1978|1978 edition]]. The event was staged at the [[International Convention Center (Jerusalem)|International Convention Center]]. The presenters were [[Daniel Pe'er]] and [[Yardena Arazi]]. The winner was [[Israel]] with the song "[[Hallelujah (Gali Atari and Milk & Honey song)|Hallelujah]]", performed by [[Gali Atari]] and [[Milk and Honey (artist)|Milk and Honey]]. Therefore, this was Israel's consecutive second win, and overall second win, in the contest. 19 countries participated, the 20 countries that took part at the previous 1978 Contest, except for [[Turkey]] which was also going to participate but eventually withdrew its entry for political reasons. [[Yugoslavia]], who missed the 1978 Contest, also didn't want to take part nor transmit the 1979 show for political reasons. As well as being broadcast live in the 19 competing countries, the contest was broadcast in [[Turkey]], [[Romania]], [[Hong Kong]] and [[Iceland]]. As of 2018, it was the last time the contest was held in March. == Location == {{details|topic=the host city|Jerusalem}} [[File:Binyanei-HaUmah.JPG|200px|thumb|left|International Convention Center, Jerusalem – host venue of the 1979 contest.]] Located on a plateau in the [[Judaean Mountains|Judean Mountains]] between the [[Mediterranean Sea|Mediterranean]] and the [[Dead Sea]], Jerusalem is one of the [[List of oldest continuously inhabited cities|oldest cities in the world]]. In the ancient [[cuneiform]], Jerusalem was called "Urusalima", meaning "City of Peace", during the early Canaanite period (approximately 2400 BC).BC The Archaeology of the Bible Lands by Magnus Magnusson. BBC Publications London. 1977. It is considered [[Holy city|holy]] to the three major [[Abrahamic religions]]—[[Judaism]], [[Christianity]] and [[Islam]]. == Format == Each country had a jury who awarded 12, 10, 8, 7, 6, 5, 4, 3, 2, 1 point(s) for their top ten songs. This was the last year in which the points were announced via order of appearance, as opposed to order of preference. The voting was extremely close. Israel gained a good lead in the early stages of the voting, but Spain eventually caught up and took a good lead themselves. At the close of the penultimate jury's votes, Israel were one point behind Spain, and only the Spanish jury had yet to give their votes. Spain ended up giving Israel 10 points, causing the crowd to erupt into enormous cheers. == Participating countries == At one point before the contest [[Turkey]] was going to participate. The country would have appeared 11th on stage (between Israel and France), represented by [[Maria Rita Epik]] and [[21. Peron]] with the song "[[:tr:Seviyorum (şarkı)|Seviyorum]]" ("I'm Loving"). However Turkey was forced to retire from the contest under pressure from Arab states who objected to a predominantly Muslim country taking part in a contest held in Israel,O'Connor, John Kennedy. ''The Eurovision Song Contest: The Official History''. Carlton Books, UK. 2007 {{ISBN|978-1-84442-994-3}} but they however took part in Jerusalem [[Eurovision Song Contest 1999|20 years later]]. === Returning artists === The contest saw the return of four artists who had participated in previous editions of the contest: France's representative [[Anne-Marie David]] was the winner for [[Luxembourg in the Eurovision Song Contest 1973|Luxembourg in 1973]], Netherlands' [[Sandra Reemer|Xandra]] represented the country in [[Netherlands in the Eurovision Song Contest 1972|1972]] and [[Netherlands in the Eurovision Song Contest 1976|1976]], Norway's [[Anita Skorgan]] represented [[Norway in the Eurovision Song Contest 1977|the country in 1977]], and Switzerland's [[Peter, Sue and Marc]] represented the country in [[Switzerland in the Eurovision Song Contest 1971|1971]] and [[Switzerland in the Eurovision Song Contest 1976|1976]]. === Conductors === For each nation's performance, the orchestra was conducted by the following: {{Div col|colwidth=30em}} *{{Esc|Portugal}} - Thilo Krasmann *{{Esc|Italy}} - ''no national representative'' *{{Esc|Denmark}} - [[Allan Botschinsky]] *{{Esc|Ireland}} - Proinnsías Ó Duinn *{{Esc|Finland}} - [[Ossi Runne]] *{{Esc|Monaco}} - Gérard Salesse *{{Esc|Greece}} - Lefteris Halkiadakis *{{Esc|Switzerland}} - [[Rolf Zuckowski]] *{{Esc|Germany}} - [[Norbert Daum]] *{{Esc|Israel}} - '''[[Kobi Oshrat]]''' *{{Esc|France}} - Guy Mattéoni *{{Esc|Belgium}} - [[Francis Bay]] *{{Esc|Luxembourg}} - [[Hervé Roy]] *{{Esc|Netherlands}} - [[Harry van Hoof]] *{{Esc|Sweden}} - [[Lars Samuelson]] *{{Esc|Norway}} - [[Sigurd Jansen]] *{{Esc|United Kingdom}} - [[Ken Jones (music)|Ken Jones]] *{{Esc|Austria}} - Richard Österreicher *{{Esc|Spain|1977}} - José Luis Navarro {{div col end}} == Results == The following tables reflect the confirmed, verified scores, which were adjusted after the live broadcast. During the voting announcement, due to a misunderstanding by the presenter Yardena Arazi, Spain appeared to award 10 points to both Portugal and Israel and these scores were added to the scoreboard. After the programme, verification confirmed that Portugal should only have received six points, leaving the total Portuguese score reduced by four points to 64. {{clear}} {| class="sortable wikitable" |- style="background:#ccc;" ! revision.comment: Adding external links to Association for Talent Development. What Is Facilitation?
revision.text:
{{refimprove|date=April 2018}} '''Facilitation''' in [[business]], [[organizational development]] (OD), and in [[consensus decision-making]] refers to the process of designing and running a successful [[meeting]].
Facilitation concerns itself with all the tasks needed to run a [[productivity (economics)|productive]] and impartial meeting. Facilitation serves the needs of any group who are meeting with a common purpose, whether it be making a decision, solving a problem, or simply exchanging ideas and information. It does not [[leadership|lead]] the group, nor does it try to distract or to entertain. A slightly different interpretation focuses more specifically on a group that is engaged in [[experiential learning]].<ref name=Heron>Heron, J. ''The Complete Facilitator's Handbook'', (1999) Kogan Page {{ISBN|0-7494-2798-1}}</ref> In particular this is associated with [[active learning]] and concepts of [[tutor|tutelary]] authority. This is covered in-depth in the research work of [[John Heron]] at the [[University of Surrey]] and the International Centre for [[Cooperative inquiry|Co-operative Inquiry]].
== Aspects == ;The role of the [[facilitator]] (see below): The role of facilitator only emerged as a separate set of skills in the 1980s. It has similarities to the traditional [[Chair (official)|Chair]] or [[secretary]] roles in a meeting but goes beyond them to actively participate and guide the group towards consensus. ;Setting ground rules: Often disregarded by those untrained in facilitation, setting ground rules is a key component of the facilitation process especially in meetings convened to discuss difficult problems or for training. These rules are usually reiterated in some form at the outset of a facilitated meeting or workshop to ensure participants understand the various roles being employed and the responsibilities accorded to each. Certain aspects feature highly such as: :* being open to suggestions :* building on what is there, not knocking down ideas :* allowing others space (to speak or express themselves) :* mutual respect :* that the facilitator does not own the topic under discussion and the identity of that owner is clear :* rules of engagement such as time-outs and procedures that will be adopted :* how unresolved issues will be captured and dealt with :* Finally it is key that, during the meeting, it is clear that the owner of the topic is not expected to intervene to impose ideas beyond setting out parameters for consideration or to give insight. The facilitator in this respect owns the process of the meeting. These are all closely associated with the idea of facilitation as a tool of (workplace) [[empowerment]].<ref name=Heron/> ;Consulting with the client: A facilitator will work with a client who is someone in an organisation, or diverse group, who is calling them and has invited the facilitator to assist. They will try to understand the purpose and outcome of the meeting by discussing it with the client. ;Making arrangements for the [[meeting]]: The practical arrangements will be arranged or managed by the facilitator. They will also consider in detail the location and layout of the room. They will research the meeting beforehand to understand why it is being held and that all [[Project stakeholder|stakeholders]] are invited and able to attend. ;Setting the [[Agenda (meeting)|agenda]]: They will understand in detail how each item on the agenda is to be tackled and how long it should take. Using specialist techniques they will allow participants to understand all the issues at stake and all alternative courses of action. The Facilitator designs the process (agenda) based on his or her discussions with the participants and the Facilitator's process expertise. ;Understanding group [[Norm (sociology)|norms]]: They will not make assumptions about the way people interact and will try to adapt to the ways of different cultures and organisations. ;Understanding [[group dynamics]]: Whilst tackling the practical aspects of a meeting they remain aware of undercurrents, both verbal and non-verbal, which may indicate problems the group is having. The facilitator may try to assist the group in becoming aware of these.
==The role of the facilitator== :''See [[Facilitator]] for details of exactly how a facilitator might run a meeting.''
It is important to note that the tasks and responsibilities listed below do not need to be covered by a single facilitator. The role of the facilitator is often shared by multiple people, for instance one person may arrange the logistics before the meeting, another person may keep time and monitor the agenda during the meeting, and a third person may be responsible for recording agreements.
*Prior to a meeting, facilitators: ** research the meeting ** find out the purpose and goal (if any) of the meeting ** establish who needs to attend ** draw up a draft agenda and design the group processes to attain the necessary results ** share the agenda with potential attendees, changing it as necessary ** ensure everyone gets fully briefed for the meeting and that everyone knows the purpose and potential consequences of the meeting *During the meeting, facilitators: ** monitor the agenda ** keep time ** manage the group process ** encourage participation from all attendees ** help participants understand different points of view ** foster solutions that incorporate diverse points of view ** manage participant behaviour ** create a safe environment ** teach new thinking skills and facilitate structured thinking activities ** record (with an agreed phraseology) agreements. They may also note unresolved issues for later debate. *The facilitator may write up and publish the results of the meeting to everyone concerned including those who could not attend.
==The form of meeting== A meeting usually means everyone is together in the same room at the same time and this is the major situation in which facilitation is practiced. With the introduction of modern telecommunications the field has grown to embrace other forms of meetings: ;Same time same place: The traditional meeting in a room with all parties present at the same time. ;Same time different place: The teleconference with either all parties at separate locations or with some in geographically dispersed sub meetings, all with audio / video connection. ;Different time same place: A meeting focussing on a particular physical location where people contribute as they pass by. A wall mounted notice board and/or poster display which allows individuals to add comments as they pass is one example . A survey using un-networked computers in a kiosk would also be a "different time same place" meeting. ;Different time different place: Meeting via a web link such as discussion groups, forums, blogs, and [[usenet]]. Specialist web-enabled group decision support software exists. Wikipedia discussion pages fall into this category.
== See also == * [[Dialogue mapping]] * [[Gradients of agreement scale]]

''Creating a Culture of Collaboration'', (2006) Jossey-Bass {{ISBN|0-7879-8116-8}} * Schwarz, R. ''The Skilled Facilitator'', (3rd Edition 2017) Jossey-Bass {{ISBN|978-1119064398}} * Josef W. Seifert: ''Visualisation - Presentation - Facilitation: Translation of the German Classic'' Gabal, Offenbach 2012. {{ISBN|978-3-86936-394-3}} * Spencer, L. ''Winning Through Participation'', (1989) Kendall Hunt Pub. Co. {{ISBN|978-0-8403-6196-7}} * Salas, Tillmann, McKee ''Visualisation in Participatory Programmes'', (1999) Southbound, in association with UNICEF Dhaka, {{ISBN|978-983-9054-45-3}} * Wilkinson, M. ''CLICK: The Virtual Meetings Book'', (2013) Leadership Strategies Publishing {{ISBN|978-0-9722-4585-2}} * Wilkinson, M. ''The Secrets of Facilitation'', (2nd Edition 2012) Jossey-Bass {{ISBN|978-1-1182-0613-3}}
