revision.text:
The '''Portland Chamber Music Festival''' is an annual [[chamber music]] festival located in [[Portland, Maine]]. Founded in 1994 by Jennifer Elowitch (violinist) and Dena Levine (pianist), the festival presents a summer concert series in August at the [[Abromson Community Education Center]].<ref>[http://www.portlandphoenix.com/archive/music/00/08/17/CHAMBER.html The Portland Phoenix, August 2000] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070310184517/http://www.portlandphoenix.com/archive/music/00/08/17/CHAMBER.html |date=2007-03-10 }}</ref> In addition, the festival presents mid-season concerts at SPACE Gallery in Portland and elsewhere in the region.
==External links== *[http://www.pcmf.org/ Official website of the Portland Chamber Music Festival]
The Festival has played to a nationwide audience on National Public Radio; has been awarded three grants from the Aaron Copland Fund for Music for performance of American contemporary music; has been recorded and broadcast by WGBH radio in Boston; and has been featured in both local and national press.
Performers in recent years have included members of the Vermeer, Mendelssohn, Borromeo, and Brentano String Quartets. Resident Composers have included Lee Hyla, Chen Yi, Osvaldo Golijov, Earl Kim, Michael Gandolfi, Melinda Wagner, Peter Child, and many others.
PCMF also hosts an annual free children’s concert, a Young Artist Apprentice Program, and adult chamber music workshops. The Festival also conducts an annual Composer’s Competition, culminating in the winning work’s premiere at a PCMF summer concert.
==References== {{reflist}} * {{Classical music festival}} [[Category:Music festivals established in 1994]] [[Category:Chamber music festivals]] [[Category:Classical music festivals in the United States]] [[Category:Culture of Portland, Maine]] [[Category:1994 establishments in Oregon]]

{{multiple issues| {{cleanup reorganize|date=September 2013}} {{more citations needed|date =February 2010}} }} {{Infobox music festival | music_festival_name = Sawai Gandharva Bhimsen Mahotsav | image = [[File:Sawai Gandharva Bhimsen Mahotsav Logo.jpeg|250px]] | caption= | location = New English School Ramanbaug,
[[Pune]], Maharashtra, India | years_active = 1953 – present | founders = [[Bhimsen Joshi]],
[[Arya Sangeet Prasarak Mandal]] | dates = Traditionally the second weekend of December | website ={{url|sawaigandharvabhimsenmahotsav.com/}} }} The '''Sawai Gandharva Bhimsen Mahotsav''' (formerly known as the '''Sawai Gandharva Sangeet Mahotsav'''{{cite web|url=http://www.dnaindia.com/mumbai/report_sawai-gandharva-mahotsav-renamed_1614706 |title=Sawai Gandharva Mahotsav renamed – Mumbai – DNA |publisher=Dnaindia.com |date= |accessdate=2013-04-27}} and simply known as '''Sawai''') is an annual [[Hindustani Classical Music|Indian Classical music]] festival held in [[Pune]] since 1953. The festival is hosted by the Arya Sangeet Prasarak Mandal (ASPM) and initiated by [[Bhimsen Joshi]] as a memorial music conference commemorating the life and work of Joshi's [[guru]], [[Sawai Gandharva]], the festival's [[namesake]]. While Joshi was leading the organisation of the festival, performing artists received personal invitations from him to perform at it. With an emphasis on [[Hindustani Classical music|Hindustani Classical]] [[Khayal|Khayal music]], instrumentalists, [[Indian Classical dance|dancers]], [[dhrupad]]iyas, [[Bhajans|Bhakti musicians]], [[Ghazal|Ghazal musicians]], [[Qawwali]]yas, and [[Carnatic music]]ians frequent the concert lineup. A younger artist's debut performance at the festival connotes their "arrival" and promise to the Classical music scene of India (most recently including [[Rahul Deshpande]], [[Kaushiki Chakrabarty]], and [[Mahesh Kale]]). Since its inception, the festival has grown into a prominent cultural soiree for Pune's musical connoisseurs, featuring the foremost musicians of traditional Indian musical forms. ==History== The festival was started in 1953 on a small scale, to commemorate the first death anniversary of [[Sawai Gandharva]], the acclaimed Hindustani Classical vocalist of the [[Kirana Gharana]]. Bhimsen Joshi led the organisation of the festival from its beginning until 2002 when his health problems became of concern.{{cite web|url=http://www.hindu.com/thehindu/mp/2002/10/31/stories/2002103100070100.htm |title=Still magical |publisher=The Hindu |date=31 October 2002 |accessdate=2013-04-27}} Joshi's youngest son, [[Shrinivas Joshi]], and senior disciple, [[Shrikant Deshpande]], succeeded him as organisers.{{cite web|agency=Times News Network |url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/Cities/Pune/Sawai_Gandharva_music_fest_to_start_from_Dec_11/articleshow/3753056.cms |title=Sawai Gandharva music fest to start from Dec 11 – The Times of India |publisher=Timesofindia.indiatimes.com |date=25 November 2008 |accessdate=2013-04-27}} Since Joshi's death in 2011, Shrinivas Joshi and [[Anand Deshmukh]] have been the main organisers.{{cite web|url=http://www.indianexpress.com/news/This-year-on--Sawai-will-be-Sawai-Gandharva-Bhimsen-Mahotsav/877938/ |title=This year on, Sawai will be Sawai Gandharva Bhimsen Mahotsav |publisher=Indian Express |date=19 November 2011 |accessdate=2013-04-27}} ==Recent years== The 2009 Festival was postponed to January 2010 due to an [[H1N1]] scare in Pune.{{Cite news|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/pune/Sawai-Gandharva-festival-postponed/articleshow/5158117.cms|title=Sawai Gandharva festival postponed|date=25 October 2009|work=The Times of India}}[http://www.indianexpress.com/news/sawai-gandharva-festival-to-be-held-from-jan/536810/ Sawai Gandharva Festival to be held from January] ''Indian Express''. Heavy rain on 13 December 2014 caused the festival to be postponed until 1 January 2015.{{cite web|url=http://www.sakaaltimes.com/NewsDetails.aspx?NewsId=5760929664306349337&SectionId=4924098573178130559&SectionName=Top%20Stories&NewsTitle=Sawai%20Mahotsav%20postponed|title=Sawai Mahotsav postponed - Sakal Times|publisher=}} When Bhimsen Joshi died on 24 January 2011, the ASPM decided to rename the festival from its original name of 'Sawai Gandharva Mahotsav' to 'Sawai Gandharva Bhimsen Mahotsav' in his honour.{{cite news| url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2011-11-19/pune/30418905_1_kirana-gharana-pt-bhimsen-joshi-festival | work=The Times of India | title=Music fest renamed Sawai Gandharva Bhimsen Mahotsav | date=19 November 2011}} ==Tradition== The Sawai Gandharva Music Festival is conducted every year in the first two weeks of December over three days. In the past, the festival runs through whole the night and the days used to end in the morning. Later on, when [[Pune Municipal Corporation]] set rule to finish the program before 10 pm which leads to change in the schedule of the program. Traditionally, each festival is inaugurated with a tribute honoring [[Sawai Gandharva]], with a [[Shehnai]] musician performing first, in the early morning. During the first two days, programs begin in the late-afternoon and are supposed to officially end by 10 pm. On the third and final day (previously a Saturday, now usually a Sunday), the programme is conducted in two sessions, the first beginning in the early morning continuing until the early afternoon, the second session begins in the early evening and ends at 10 p.m. ===Finale performances=== Tradition was that the finale performance was presented by Bhimsen Joshi. Since his retirement, other members of the Kirana Gharana took on the role, including [[Sangmeshwar Gurav]] in 2005 and leading disciples of Joshi in 2006. The vocalist Prabha Atre has concluded every festival since 2007. The festival officially concludes with the entire audience and remaining performers listening to the [[Thumri]] [[Bhairavi|in Raag Bhairavi]] recording "Jamuna Ke Teer" by [[Sawai Gandharva]], a tune made famous by and signature of his guru, Abdul Karim Khan. ==List of festivals and performances== The Arya Sangeet Prasarak Mandal takes the task of recording details of the festival each year. The festival has been recorded in picture, video and audio, some of which is commercially available. Festivals are listed counter-chronologically. ===1950s=== {{hidden|1st Sawai Gandharva Music Festival (1953){{Citation|last =Deshpande |first =A. P. |title =Swarayadnya: Sawai Gandharva Music Festival's Fifty Years|isbn =978-81-7434-242-3 |publisher =Rajhans Prakashan |pages =78–79 |year =2002}}| * [[Bhimsen Joshi]] (Vocal)

{{Use mdy dates|date=October 2015}} {{Infobox person | name = Stephanie Hannon | image = Stephanie Hannon.jpg | alt = | caption = Stephanie Hannon speaking at an event in November 2015 | birth_name = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1974|10|31}} | birth_place = [[Washington, DC]], [[United States|US]] | death_date = <!-- {{Death date and age|YYYY|MM|DD|YYYY|MM|DD}} (death date then birth date) --> | death_place = | nationality = | other_names = | occupation = [[Chief technology officer|CTO]] of [[Hillary Clinton presidential campaign, 2016]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://fortune.com/2016/08/29/hillary-clinton-cto-stephanie-hannon/|title=5 Things We Learned From Hillary Clinton's Campaign CTO|work=Fortune}}</ref> Product Management Director at [[Google]] | years_active = | known_for = | notable_works = | party = [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] | alma_mater = {{unbulleted list|[[Stanford University]]|[[Harvard University]]}} | residence = [[San Francisco, California]], U.S. }} '''Stephanie Hannon''' (born October 31, 1974) was the [[chief technology officer]] (CTO) of [[Hillary Clinton presidential campaign, 2016|Hillary Clinton's 2016 presidential campaign]]. She was the first woman to hold the title of CTO on a major presidential campaign.<ref name=Rucker>{{cite news|last1=Rucker|first1=Philip|title=Hillary Clinton hires Google executive to be chief technology officer|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/post-politics/wp/2015/04/08/hillary-clinton-hires-google-executive-to-be-chief-technology-officer/|accessdate=April 23, 2015}}</ref><ref name=Aslam>{{cite news|last1=Aslam|first1=Yasmin|title=Hillary Clinton hires first-ever female presidential campaign CTO|url=http://www.msnbc.com/msnbc/hillary-clinton-hires-first-ever-female-presidential-campaign-cto|accessdate=April 23, 2015}}</ref><ref name=Merica>{{cite news|last1=Merica|first1=Dan|title=Google executive to fill Clinton campaign's top tech role|url=http://www.cnn.com/2015/04/08/politics/hillary-clinton-google-staffer-hire-2016-election/|accessdate=April 23, 2015}}</ref> Prior to working for the Clinton campaign, Hannon was [[Google]]'s director of product management for civic innovation and social impact. Her focus was on building tools to help communities respond to natural disasters as well as producing and sharing transparent election results. She worked previously as a product manager on [[Google Maps]] and [[Apache Wave|Google Wave]].<ref name=Rucker /><ref name=Walker>{{cite news|last1=Walker|first1=Alissa|title=Report: Hillary Clinton Just Hired sgt CTO of Her Campaign|url=https://gizmodo.com/report-hillary-clinton-just-hired-a-google-exec-as-cto-1696507258|accessdate=April 23, 2015}}</ref>
==Early life and education==
Hannon was born in [[Washington, DC]], and grew up in [[Reston, Virginia]]. She went to Virginia's chartered [[Thomas Jefferson High School for Science and Technology]]. She earned a bachelor's degree in computer systems engineering and a master's degree in electrical engineering at [[Stanford University]] as well as a master of business administration degree at [[Harvard Business School]].<ref name=Rucker />
==2016 presidential campaign== At the time of Hannon's hiring as campaign CTO, much commentary was made on the significance of a woman holding this position for the first time. The appointment was described as "helping open the door for other women in an industry that has long been a boys club."<ref name=Aslam /> The theme of transcending traditional gender roles was recently the subject of a speech by Clinton to a [[Silicon Valley]] audience, stating her intent to "crack every last glass ceiling".<ref name=Epstein>{{cite news|last1=Epstein|first1=Jennifer|title=Hillary Clinton Explains How She'll 'Crack Every Last Glass Ceiling' in 2016|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/politics/articles/2015-02-25/hillary-clinton-explains-how-she-ll-crack-every-last-glass-ceiling-in-2016|accessdate=April 23, 2015}}</ref>
== References == {{reflist|35em}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Hannon, Stephanie}} [[Category:1974 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:American chief technologists]] [[Category:Harvard Business School alumni]] [[Category:Hillary Clinton presidential campaign, 2016]] [[Category:People associated with the United States presidential election, 2016]] [[Category:Political campaign staff]] [[Category:Stanford University School of Engineering alumni]] [[Category:Women chief technology officers]]
{{compu-scientist-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Ancient Roman religion}} The '''Taurian Games''' (Latin '''''Ludi Taurii''''' or '''''Ludi Taurei''''', rarely '''Taurilia'''<ref>''Taurilia'' is an alternate reading of the relevant passage in [[Livy]], 39.22; it is included as an entry in [[Egidio Forcellini|Forcellini's ''Totius Latinitatis Lexicon'']] (1828), p. 708, and appears in some older editions of Livy and in scholarship from the 19th century. See notes in the 1825 edition of Livy by [[Arnold Drakenborch]] and [[Johann Freinsheim]], [https://books.google.com/books?id=hBpNAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA402&dq=%22ludi+taurii%22&hl=en&sa=X&ei=ds-GT4evCIWL8AHEqtWXCA&ved=0CDIQ6AEwADhQ#v=onepage&q=%22ludi%20taurii%22&f=false p. 402.]</ref>) were games ''([[ludi]])'' held in [[ancient Rome]] in honor of the ''[[Di Inferi|di inferi]]'', the gods of the underworld. They were not part of a regularly scheduled [[Roman festival|religious festival]] on the [[Roman calendar|calendar]], but were held as expiatory rites ''religionis causa'', occasioned by [[Glossary of ancient Roman religion#religio|religious concerns]].<ref>John H. Humphrey, ''Roman Circuses: Arenas for Chariot Racing'' (University of California Press, 1986), p. 543; Robert Turcan, ''The Gods of Ancient Rome'' (Edinburgh University Press, 2000), p. 82. </ref>
''Ludi Taurii'' are recorded in 186 BC as a two-day event.<ref>Livy, 39.22.</ref> [[Varro]] mentions them as occurring in the [[Roman Republic#Late Republic (147 BC - 30 BC)|late Republic]].<ref>Varro, ''De lingua latina'' 5.154.</ref> During the reign of [[Antoninus Pius]], they were held every five years from 140 to 160 AD, within a period beginning on the day after the [[Ides (calendar)|Ides]] of May and continuing through the [[Kalends]] of June.<ref>''[[Corpus Inscriptionum Latinarum|CIL]]'' xiv supp. 4541 (the ''[[Fasti Ostienses]]''); John Briscoe, ''A Commentary on Livy, Books 38–40'' (Oxford University Press, 2008), pp. 19, 294; Humphrey, ''Roman Circuses'', p. 544.</ref> Some scholars extrapolate that like the ''[[lustrum]]'' (purification ritual), the ''Ludi Taurii'' were regularly [[wikt:quinquennial|quinquennial]].<ref>Eckart Köhne, "Bread and Circuses: The Politics of Entertainment," in ''Gladiators and Caesars: The Power of Spectacle in Ancient Rome'' (University of California Press, 2000), p. 9; Humphrey, ''Roman Circuses'', p. 543.</ref> Others caution that the five-year schedule under Antoninus Pius, attested by the ''[[Fasti Ostienses]]'', is never mentioned in other sources. The limited evidence suggests the ''Ludi Taurii'' were important mainly in the context of religious revivalism during the [[Augustus|Augustan]] and [[Antonine]] eras.<ref>Briscoe, ''A Commentary on Livy'', p. 294; Humphrey, ''Roman Circuses'', pp. 543–544.</ref>
The Taurian Games were horse races, or less likely [[chariot races]], on a course around turning posts ''([[metae]])''.<ref>Humphrey, ''Roman Circuses'', p. 544; Varro, ''De lingua latina'' 5.154: "the horses run around the turning posts" ''(equi circum metas currunt)''.</ref> In the 19th century, they were sometimes confused with the archaic Tarentine Games ''(ludi tarentini)'', which were replaced by the [[Saecular Games]].<ref>In 1875 and subsequent editions, [[Leonhard Schmitz]]'s entry on the ''Ludi Saeculares'' in [[Dictionary of Greek and Roman Antiquities|Smith's ''Dictionary of Greek and Roman Antiquities'']] ''(SMIGRA)'' identified the Taurian Games with the ''ludi tarentini''. The identification gained currency in English [[classical tradition|classicizing literary circles]], as indicated in the notes to [[Edward Lytton]]'s translation of [[Horace]]'s [[Carmen Saeculare|Saecular Ode]], published in ''Schiller and Horace'' (Routledge, 1875), pp. 423–424, citing a then-current edition of Smith's ''Dictionary''. By the 1890 edition of ''SMIGRA'', a separate entry for ''[http://artflx.uchicago.edu/cgi-bin/philologic/getobject.pl?c.3:1:139.antiquities Ludi Taurii] {{Webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20120709151634/http://artflx.uchicago.edu/cgi-bin/philologic/getobject.pl?c.3:1:139.antiquities |date=2012-07-09 }}'' had been added, with a few points of dubious factuality (see [http://penelope.uchicago.edu/Thayer/E/Roman/Texts/secondary/SMIGRA*/Ludi_Saeculares.html#noteA Bill Thayer's note] to the entry ''Ludi Saeculares'' in the [[LacusCurtius]] edition of the 1875 ''SMIGRA'', as well as his translation of and note to the entry ''[http://penelope.uchicago.edu/Thayer/E/Roman/Texts/secondary/DARSAG/Taurii_Ludi.html Taurii Ludi]'' in Daremberg and Saglio, ''[[Dictionnaire des Antiquités Grecques et Romaines]]''). The erroneous identification was nevertheless perpetuated in the ''[[Century Dictionary]]'' of 1891 (pp. 6189, 6199) and later editions. As early as 1701, however, [[Thomas Dempster]] had pointed out in his notes to the ''Antiquitatum Romanorum Corpus Absolutissimum'' of [[Johannes Rosinus]] that "many confuse the Taurian with the Saecular games, but they are in error: [the two] are entirely different" (p. 340). [[Ludwig Preller]] recognized the similarities, but suggested that the ''ludi taurii'' were performed irregularly when the Saecular Games would have been untimely; ''Römische Mythologie'' (1881), vol. 1, p. 92.</ref> Horse racing along with the [[propitiation]] of underworld gods was characteristic of "old and obscure" Roman festivals such as the [[Consualia]], the [[October Horse]], and sites in the [[Campus Martius]] such as the [[Tarentum (Campus Martius)|Tarentum]] (where the ''ludi tarentini'' originated) and the [[Trigarium]].<ref>Humphrey, ''Roman Circuses'', pp. 544, 558; Auguste Bouché-Leclercq, ''Manuel des Institutions Romaines'' (Hachette, 1886), p. 549; "Purificazione," in ''Thesaurus Cultus et Rituum Antiquorum'' (''[[Lexicon Iconographicum Mythologiae Classicae|LIMC]]'', 2004), p. 83. See also the [[Lusus Troiae]].</ref> The ''Ludi Taurii'' were the only games held in the [[Circus Flaminius]].<ref>[[Varro]], ''De lingua latina'' 5.154; Lawrence Richardson, ''A New Topographical Dictionary of Ancient Rome'' (Johns Hopkins University Press, 1992), 83; Humphrey, ''Roman Circuses'', p. 543. [[Valerius Maximus]] (1.7.4) is the only ancient source, likely erroneous, to say that the [[Plebeian Games]] were held in the Circus Flaminius, which had no track for the chariot races known to be part of these ''ludi''; see [[T.P. Wiseman]], ''Remus: A Roman Myth'' (Cambridge University Press, 1995), p. 211.</ref>
If the games are [[Etruscan civilization|Etruscan]] in origin, as [[Sextus Pompeius Festus|Festus]] and [[Servius]] claim, ''taurii'' probably comes from the [[Etruscan language|Etruscan word]] ''tauru'', "tomb."<ref>Humphrey, ''Roman Circuses'', p. 544.</ref> The design of the turning posts ''(metae)'' on a Roman race course was derived from Etruscan funerary monuments.<ref>Humphrey, ''Roman Circuses'', p. 15.</ref> Festus, however, offers an [[aition|etiology]] based on Latin ''taurus'', "bull."<ref>Humphrey, ''Roman Circuses'', p. 544.</ref>
==Origin and significance== In the tradition recorded by Festus,<ref>Festus, excerpts of Paulus, p. 479 in the edition of Lindsay.</ref> the games were instituted in the [[Roman Kingdom|Regal period]] when [[Tarquinius Superbus]] was [[kings of Rome|king]]. [[Servius]] also places their origin during his reign.
Fetus explains that the games were performed in honor of the gods below ''(di inferi)''. They were established in response to an epidemic ''(magna … pestilentia)'' afflicting pregnant women, caused by the distribution of the flesh of sacrificial bulls ''(tauri)'' among the people. Servius implies that the ''pestilentia'' was [[infant mortality]]: "each delivery of the women came out badly." The remedy of the games was obtained ''ex libris fatalibus'', "from the books of the fates" (either the [[Sibylline books]]<ref>Briscoe, ''A Commentary on Livy'', p. 294; Auguste Bouché-Leclercq, ''Histoire de la divination dans l'antiquité'' (Jérôme Millon, 2003 reprint, originally published 1883), p. 1024.</ref> or [[Glossary of ancient Roman religion#disciplina Etrusca|Etruscan texts]]<ref>Bouché-Leclercq, ''Histoire de la divination'', p. 1024.</ref>). According to Servius, the ''ludi'' took their name from the word ''taurea'', meaning a sterile sacrificial victim ''([[Glossary of ancient Roman religion#hostia|hostia]])''.<ref>[[Servius Danielis]], note to ''Aeneid'' [http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Serv.+A.+2.140 2.140.]</ref>
Servius gives an alternative version that credits the [[Sabines]] with instituting the games in response to the ''pestilentia'', and characterizes the transferral of the ''lues publica'' (the plague upon the people) onto sacrificial victims ''(hostiae)'' as if it were a [[scapegoat|scapegoat ritual]].<ref>[[William Warde Fowler]], ''The Roman Festivals of the Period of the Republic'' (London, 1908), p. 176; Servius, note to ''Aeneid'' 2.140 ''(alii ludos Taureos a Sabinis propter pestilentiam institutos dicunt, ut lues publica in has hostias verteretur)''.</ref>
Festus also provided an additional explanation of the name as ''taurus'' ("bull") from Varro,<ref>Festus, p. 478 (Lindsay).</ref> preserved only in fragmentary form by the ''Codex Farnesianus''.<ref>Briscoe, ''A Commentary on Livy'', p. 294.</ref> A reconstruction dating back to [[Joseph Justus Scaliger|J.J. Scaliger]]<ref><!--please do not change the irregular italics; see explanation after the quotation-->''Sed Taurios'' ludos Varro ait vocari, quod ''eis ludis discipu''lus pendens a doctore in cr''udo corio tauri'' solitus sit inpelli, atque us''que eo inibi cogi'' docere, quoad consisteret ''atque virtu''te talorum constaret pedu''m firmitas'' (italicized text is reconstructed); in English, "Varro, however, says that the Taurian Games are so called because it was customary at the games for a student, with a boost from his instructor, to be propelled on the raw hide of a bull ''(taurus)'', and to show by the extent of his action how sound he was and how the sureness of his feet 'stuck' by virtue of his heels." ("Stick" here is used in the sense of landing a gymnastics position correctly.) See [[André Dacier]] (1826), [https://books.google.com/books?id=h9YTAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA960&dq=%22appellabantur+ludi%22&hl=en&sa=X&ei=d5uFT6btAsyDtgfepcmJCA&ved=0CEEQ6AEwAzgK#v=onepage&q=%22appellabantur%20ludi%22&f=false pp. 960–961.]</ref> has been taken to mean that youths, under the direction of a coach, engaged in ritual [[gymnastics]] on a raw bull's hide, perhaps to be compared to exercises on a [[trampoline]].<ref>J.D. Guigniaut on Frédéric Cruezer, ''Religions de l'antiquité'' (Paris, 1851) vol. 3, p. 1122.</ref> This view has not attracted wide acceptance, but would suggest that the ritual action countervails infant mortality by affirming the fitness of the youth. Ritually, landing on the bull's skin may mimic the "catching" of a safely delivered newborn.<ref>For more on birthing in the Roman world, see [[Midwifery#History_of_midwifery]] and the birth deities the ''[[di nixi|Nixae]]'', whose altar was located within a complex of sites associated with horse races and underworld gods in the Campus Martius.</ref>
The [[Augustan literature (ancient Rome)|Augustan]] [[Roman historiography|historian]] [[Livy]] has a brief reference to the games as occurring in 186 BC ''per biduum'', for a period of two days, ''religionis causa'', "for the sake of religious scruple." On this occasion, the two-day ''Ludi Taurii'' preceded ten days of ''ludi'' presented by [[Marcus Fulvius Nobilior (consul 189 BC)|Marcus Fulvius Nobilior]] as the result of a [[votum|vow]] in the [[Aetolian War]]. Nobilior's games are notable as the first time a beast hunt ''([[venatio]])'' was staged at Rome. At a [[textual criticism|corrupt transition]] between the two events in Livy's text, the word ''decem'' ("ten") appears, which [[Georg Wissowa]] construed as referring to the ten-member priestly [[collegium|college]] of ''[[decemviri sacris faciundis]]''; he thought these priests were likely charged with organizing the Taurian Games.<ref>[[Georg Wissowa]], ''Religion und Kultus der Römer'' (Munich, 1902), p. 388; noted also by Briscoe, ''A Commentary on Livy'', pp. 294–295.</ref>
Earlier scholars have sometimes taken the adjective ''taurii'' to mean that bulls were part of the games, either in a Mediterranean tradition of [[bull-leaping]], or as an early form of [[bullfighting]].<ref>[[Arnold Drakenborch]] in his 1825 edition of Livy took the ''Taurilia'' as involving actual bull fights (p. 400). See also Guigniaut on Cruezer, ''Religions de l'antiquité'', p. 1122ff.</ref> Because Livy's chronology places the ''Ludi Taurii'' (or in some editions ''Taurilia'') immediately after the news of a victory in [[Roman Spain]], the games have figured in a few efforts to trace the early history of [[Spanish-style bullfighting]].<ref>For instance, Edward Clarke, ''Letters concerning the Spanish Nation'' (London, 1763), pp. 113–115. The effort was derided by [[Charles Sumner]], "Spanish Bull-Feasts and Bull-Fights," ''Quarterly Review'' (1839), p. 385ff., published anonymously and attributed to Sumner by Edward L. Pierce, ''Memoirs and Letters of Charles Sumner'' (Boston, 1893), vol. 2, p. 64.</ref> {{Clear}}

{{use dmy dates|date=May 2018}} {{Infobox Venue | name = '''Teatro La Perla''' | image = [[File:Front Facade of Teatro La Perla, Ponce, Puerto Rico.jpg|200px]] | image_caption = Teatro La Perla | nickname = La Perla | location = Calle Mayor Cantera and Calle Cristina (NE corner)
[[Ponce, Puerto Rico]] | coordinates = {{Coord|18.01200|N|66.61198|W|region:US-PR_type:landmark}} | type = Indoor theater | broke_ground = 1860 | built = 1860-1864 | opened = 28 May 1864Socorro Girón. ''Ponce, el teatro La Perla, y la campana de la Almudaina: Historia de Ponce desde sus comienzos hasta la segunda decada del siglo XX.'' Page 574. Ponce, Puerto Rico: Gobierno Municipal de Ponce. 1992. Impreso por Editora Corripio, C. por A. Santo Domingo, Republica Dominicana. LOC Catalog Number: 85-90989. Registration Number: TX-1-977-212. | expanded = | closed = 1918-1941 (earthquake)
2006-2008 (renovations) | reopened = 2008 | demolished = | owner = Autonomous Municipality of Ponce | former_names = | seating_type = | seating_capacity = 1,047 }} '''Teatro La Perla''' is a historic [[theater]] in the city of [[Ponce, Puerto Rico|Ponce]], [[Puerto Rico]]. Inaugurated in 1864,[http://www.anadon.biz/ponce/ponce.shtml Ponce: La Capital del Sur de Puerto Rico] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061202091238/http://www.anadon.biz/ponce/ponce.shtml |date=2 December 2006 }} Retrieved July 12, 2009. it is the second oldest theater of its kind in Puerto Rico,[http://www.enciclopediapr.org/ing/article.cfm?ref=06121001&highlight=%2Bla%20%2Bperla%20%2Btheater ''La Perla Theater.'' Puerto Rico Encyclopedia.] Retrieved April 16, 2010. but "the largest and most historic in the Spanish-speaking Caribbean."[https://books.google.com/books?id=Wy_BSu4a2EYC&pg=PA192 ''Teatro La Perla.'' Frommer's Puerto Rico. By Darwin Porter and Danforth Prince. Page 182.] Retrieved April 25, 2010.[http://www.frommers.com/destinations/ponce/0328010008.html Frommers. ''Ponce.'' Walking Tours.] The theater was named ''La Perla'' in honor of the [[Virgin of Montserrat]] (Spanish: ''La Virgen de Montserrat''), known as "The Pearl of the Mediterranean."Socorro Girón. ''Ponce, el teatro La Perla, y la campana de la Almudaina: Historia de Ponce desde sus comienzos hasta la segunda decada del siglo XX.'' Page 111. Ponce, Puerto Rico: Gobierno Municipal de Ponce. 1992. Impreso por Editora Corripio, C. por A. Santo Domingo, Republica Dominicana. LOC Catalog Number: 85-90989. Registration Number: TX-1-977-212.[http://www.visitponce.com.asp1-4.websitetestlink.com/docs/SP/ponce_walking_tour.pdf Government of the Municipality of Ponce. Ponce Walking Tour. At VisitPonce.com] {{Webarchive|url=https://www.webcitation.org/5oGUauaLQ?url=http://www.visitponce.com.asp1-4.websitetestlink.com/docs/SP/ponce_walking_tour.pdf |date=16 March 2010 }}[http://www.visitponce.com/ponceCultura.aspx#teatro Government of the Municipality of Ponce. VisitPonce website > Disfrutalo > Ponce es para Ti > Paseo de Arte y Cultura> Teatro La Perla.] It is located in barrio [[Tercero (Ponce)|Tercero]], in the [[Ponce Historic Zone]]. ==Design== The theater was designed in the 1860s by [[Juan Bertoli Calderoni]] (a [[List of people from Ponce, Puerto Rico|Ponceño]] of [[Italian people|Italian]] heritage resident of the city) and it bears a [[Neoclassical architecture|neoclassical]] structure with an impressive six-column entrance. The building was badly damaged by the [[1918 San Fermín earthquake|1918 earthquake]]. However, it was rebuilt in 1940 using the original plans and reopened in 1941 with better acoustics technology. It closed in 2006 for renovations and reopened on March 14, 2008.[http://www.letsgotoponce.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=202&Itemid=81 ''Grand Inauguration for Ponce’s La Perla Theater.'' LetsGoToPonce: Insider's Guide to South Puerto Rico.] Retrieved April 15, 2010. ==History== Teatro La Perla was built under the initiative of [[Francisco Parra Duperón]] and Pedro Garriga in May 1864.{{Cite web | last = Acosta | first = Ivonne | title = Teatro La Perla | language = Spanish | publisher = Fundación Puertorriqueña de las Humanidades | date = September 29, 2008| url = http://www.enciclopediapr.org/esp/article.cfm?ref=06121001 | accessdate = March 16, 2011}} It was inaugurated on 28 May 1864 with the play ''La campana de la Almudaina'' of the [[Majorca]]n writer Juan Palou y Coll by the [[theatrical company]] of Segarra & Argente.Socorro Girón. ''Ponce, el teatro La Perla, y la campana de la Almudaina: Historia de Ponce desde sus comienzos hasta la segunda decada del siglo XX.'' Pages ix and 574. Ponce, Puerto Rico: Gobierno Municipal de Ponce. 1992. Impreso por Editora Corripio, C. por A. Santo Domingo, Republica Dominicana. LOC Catalog Number: 85-90989. Registration Number: TX-1-977-212. Teatro La Perla served as a stage not only to give life to the theatrical artistic culture in the region, but it also served as a place of assembly for those who were dedicated to the social issues in Ponce and in Puerto Rico as a whole. It served this function both at the end of the Spanish regime and in Puerto Rico’s early years as a United States territory.[https://web.archive.org/web/20090831091422/http://www.tourism-puerto-rico.com/citys-and-towns/ponce/ Functional Use of the Theater] In this theater, in 1901, Frenchman Eduardo Hervet showed the first [[silent film]] ever to be run in Puerto Rico.[http://www.cinemovida.net/historia_del_cine_en_puerto_rico Historia del Cine en Puerto Rico] The theater's first illumination technical director was Félix Juan Torres Ortiz.[http://www.periodicolaperla.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=5846:a-punto-de-caramelo-el-festival-de-teatro-luis-torres-nadal&catid=119:articulos&Itemid=342 ''Llega Festival de Teatro Luis Torres Nadal .''] Sandra Torres Guzmán. La Perla del Sur. Ponce, Puerto Rico. Year 32. Issue 1577. Page 24. 19 February 2014. It was reconditioned between 1977 and 1979 at a cost of over $500,000.Carmelo Rosario Natal. ''Ponce En Su Historia Moderna: 1945-2002.'' Published by Secretaría de Cultura y Turismo of the Government of the Autonomous Municipality of Ponce. Ponce, Puerto Rico. 2003. p. 145. ==Capacity and museum== The theatre has a [[seating capacity]] of 1,047 and it is now a regular venue for [[concerts]], [[opera]], [[Play (theatre)|plays]], and various civic and educational activities such as school graduations.[http://www.letsgo.com/14330-puerto_rico-travel-guides-southeast-ponce-c Let's Go:Home > North America > Puerto Rico > Southeast > Ponce : ''Sights.''] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101204180256/http://www.letsgo.com/14330-puerto_rico-travel-guides-southeast-ponce-c |date=4 December 2010 }} Retrieved April 16, 2010. The lobby of the theater has a small [[museum]] dedicated to the history of the building and past shows. ==See also== {{Portal|Puerto Rico|Puerto Rico/Did you know-Puerto Rico?}} * [[List of theaters of Ponce, Puerto Rico]] {{Clear}} {{Historic buildings of the Ponce Historic Zone}} ==References== {{reflist|33em}} ==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20070926234234/http://www.worldisround.com/articles/7100/photo5.html Picture of the Theatre] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20061202091238/http://www.anadon.biz/ponce/ponce.shtml Information on various sites of Ponce] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20070213121115/http://www.planetware.com/ponce/pearl-theater-pr-pr-perla.htm Contact information] * [https://www.flickr.com/photos/11592485@N04/4202456560/in/photolist-7pmFVA-7rL7hx-8Dg2iq-8Dg7r5-7YB3Yq-7YxEmZ-7YxHGx-7YAYbb-7YAYFJ-7YxJV8-7YxL4a-7YxNPx-7YxHXF-7YAV45-7YAXVq-7YxD9T-7YxE2P-7YAWoQ-7YB34N-7YxHbr-7YATR7-7YxPjR-7YB4kA-7YATgS-7YxDyR-7YxErX-7YxHB6-7YAYMh-7YB1M9-7YxJvV-7YxEh2-7YxDT6-7YB2pw-7YAT7Q-7YAVoU-7YxPfH-7YxDNg-7YxKbc-7YAWFj-7YxFcv-7YxLaM-7YxF2R-7YxKSV-7YAWYL-7YxNy2-7YxLt6-7YASrq-7YAYs7-7YASQj-7YxPCK-7YB1fA Damage to Teatro La Perla by the 1918 earthquake] {{coord|18|00|44|N|66|36|43|W|display=title}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Teatro La Perla}} [[Category:Theatres completed in 1864]] [[Category:Theatres completed in 1940]] [[Category:Theatres in Puerto Rico]] [[Category:History of Puerto Rico]] [[Category:Neoclassical architecture in Puerto Rico]] [[Category:Music venues in Puerto Rico]] [[Category:Theatres in Ponce, Puerto Rico]] [[Category:Concert halls in Puerto Rico]] [[Category:Music venues in Ponce, Puerto Rico]] [[Category:Opera houses in Puerto Rico]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox military person |name = Wally Floody |image = |image_size = |alt = |caption = |birth_date = {{Birth date|1918|4|28}} |death_date = {{Death date and age|1989|9|25|1918|4|28}} |birth_place = [[Chatham-Kent, Ontario]], [[Canada]] |death_place = |placeofburial = |placeofburial_label = |placeofburial_coordinates = <!-- {{Coord|LAT|LONG|display=inline,title}} --> |nickname = |birth_name = Clarke Wallace Chant Floody |allegiance = Canada |branch = [[Royal Canadian Air Force]] |serviceyears = 1940–1945 |rank = [[Flight Lieutenant]] |servicenumber = |unit = [[No. 401 Squadron RCAF]] |commands = |battles = [[World War II]] |battles_label = |awards = [[Order of the British Empire]] |relations = |laterwork = Businessman }} Flight Lieutenant '''Clarke Wallace Chant Floody''' {{post-nominals|size=100%|MBE}} (April 28, 1918 – September 25, 1989) was an imprisoned Canadian [[World War II]] pilot who was instrumental in organizing and implementing the "[[Stalag Luft III escape|Great Escape]]" from the German [[prisoner of war]] camp [[Stalag Luft III]].
== Biography ==
Floody was born in [[Chatham-Kent, Ontario|Chatham]], Ontario, and attended [[Northern Secondary School (Toronto)|Northern Vocational School]]. In 1936 he headed north to work at the Preston East Dome Mines in [[Timmins]], Ontario, as a mucker—shovelling the rock and mud into carts to be hauled up to the surface.
At the onset of the war, Floody was working on a ranch in [[Alberta]] when he decided to return home to enlist in the [[Royal Canadian Air Force]] (RCAF). He financed his trip back east by shovelling coal into the boiler of the locomotive for the entire trip back to Toronto. After learning that the RCAF was not quite ready for the huge influx of personnel, Wally and Betty married on May 24, 1940, and moved to [[Kirkland Lake]], where Wally could go back to work in the mines.
In 1940, Floody and his wife were back in Toronto visiting family. Anxious to find out what was happening to his enlistment application, Floody checked with the recruiting office only to find his application was at the bottom of the pile. The reason: he was now married. After convincing the recruiting officer that "My wife backs me in this 100%", he was advised that the train was leaving for the [[BCATP]] [[Brandon Municipal Airport|air station]] in [[Brandon, Manitoba|Brandon]], [[Manitoba]] that evening. After a quick goodbye to his family Floody was on his way to becoming an operational pilot and flying with [[No. 401 Squadron RCAF|No. 401 Squadron]].<ref name="Barbara Hehner">{{cite book |first=Barbara |last=Hehner |title=The Tunnel King: The True Story of Wally Floody & the Great Escape |year=2004 |publisher=Harper Trophy Canada |isbn=0-00-639477-9}}</ref>
Operating from [[RAF Biggin Hill]] in England, his [[Supermarine Spitfire|Spitfire]] was shot down on 27 October 1941<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.aircrewremembered.com/thompson-stanley.html |title=27.10.1941 No. 401 Squadron Spitfire Vb W3601 Fl/Sgt. Thompson |work=Aircrew Remembered |date=2014 |accessdate=November 28, 2015}}</ref> over [[Saint-Omer]], [[France]], where he was met by two German soldiers. He was imprisoned at the POW camp [[Stalag Luft III]] at Sagan (now [[Żagań]], [[Poland]]). There he joined the "X-Organization", headed by [[Roger Bushell]] (codenamed "Big-X"), who put Wally in charge of digging tunnels and their [[camouflage]], for the upcoming escape attempts by [[Commonwealth of Nations|Commonwealth]] and European prisoners.
However, in March 1944, the German guards, always suspicious of escapes, caught the telltale sign of sand being dropped by one of the 'penguins' out the bottom of his pant legs and immediately rounded up Wally and 19 others and transferred them to another camp in Belaria.
The escape of 76 men went ahead on the moonless night of March 24, 1944. Eventually the Germans caught all but three prisoners, and to make an example of them to all the other prisoners, Hitler ordered the execution of 50 of the recaptured Allied officers under the pretext that they were shot while attempting escape. At the end of the war Floody gave evidence about conditions in POW camps at the [[Nuremberg trials]].
On September 22, 1946, two days after Betty's and Wally's first son Brian was born, they received news that Wally had been made a [[Member of the Order of the British Empire]] by King George VI; the citation reading, in part:
{{quote|Flight Lieutenant (F/L) Floody made a thorough study of tunnelling work and devised many different methods & techniques. He became one of the leading organizers and indefatigable workers in the tunnels themselves. Besides being arduous, his work was frequently dangerous....F/L Floody was buried under heavy falls of sand.....but, despite all dangers and difficulties, F/L Floody persisted, showing a marked degree of courage and devotion to duty.''<ref>{{London Gazette |issue=37744 |date=27 September 1946 |page=4901 |supp=y}}</ref>}}
Returning to civilian life he became a businessman and co-founder of the Royal Canadian Air Force Prisoners of War Association. He died on September 25, 1989.
== Feature film involvement == [[File:Steve McQueen and Wally Floody 001.jpg|thumb|right|[[Steve McQueen]] with Wally Floody, while Floody was a technical advisor in production of the film ''[[The Great Escape (film)|The Great Escape]]''.]] In early 1962, Floody received a phone call from director [[John Sturges]].<ref name="Barbara Hehner" /> He told Floody he was planning to make a film based on the book by [[Paul Brickhill]], an Australian flyer and writer who, like Floody, had spent time at Stalag Luft III. After Sturges's assurance that the film was to be as accurate as theatrically possible but true to the efforts of those prisoners and the atmosphere of the camps, Floody agreed to be technical adviser on the 1963 feature film ''[[The Great Escape (film)|The Great Escape]]'' which was filmed on locations in Germany during the summer of 1962. He is popularly considered the real-life counterpart to that film's fictional "Tunnel King", Danny Velinski, played by [[Charles Bronson]].<ref name="TGE">{{cite web |url=http://www.historyinfilm.com/escape/real10.htm |title=History in film – The Great Escape |publisher=Historyinfilm.com |date= |accessdate=2014-08-26}}</ref><ref name="tunnel king">{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/dna/h2g2/A978104 |title=BBC – The Great Escape |publisher=BBC |date= |accessdate=2014-08-26}}</ref>
== References ==
{{reflist}}
== External links ==
* {{cite web |url= http://www.mail-archive.com/nsroots@ednet.ns.ca/msg01860.html |title=Obituary: Wally Floody |work=The Daily Telegraph |location=London, UK |date=September 27, 1989}} * [http://www.rcaf.com/squadrons/400series/401squadron.php RCAF No. 401 Squadron] * {{cite journal |url= https://www.umanitoba.ca/cm/vol11/no5/thetunnelking.html |title=The Tunnel King: The True Story of Wally Floody and the Great Escape |journal=CM Magazine |volume=XI |number=5 |date=October 29, 2004 |first=Ian |last=Stewart}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2013}} {{Use British English|date=October 2013}} {{Infobox organization |name = War Memorials Trust |image = |size = |caption = |abbreviation = |formation = 7 May 1997 |status = [[Charitable organization|Registered charity]] |purpose = protection and conservation of [[war memorial]]s in the UK |location = [[London]] |region_served = UK |membership = 2,755<ref name="charitycommission_a">{{cite web |url=http://apps.charitycommission.gov.uk/Accounts/Ends55/0001062255_AC_20160331_E_C.pdf |page=8 |title= War Memorials Trust: Review of Activities; Administration, publications and PR |publisher=Charity Commission |accessdate = 7 February 2017}}</ref> |leader_title = Patron |leader_name = [[The Duchess of Cornwall|HRH the Duchess of Cornwall]] |leader_title2 = |leader_name2 = |main_organ = |parent_organization = |affiliations = |budget = |website = {{url|1=www.warmemorials.org/}} }}
'''War Memorials Trust''' works for the protection and conservation of [[war memorial]]s in the [[UK]]. The charity provides free information and advice as well as administering grant schemes for the repair and conservation of war memorials.
War Memorials Trust works with other organisations such as [[Historic England]] and [[Historic Environment Scotland]] to better safeguard the future of war memorials in both their social and historical context.
== Objectives == The charity’s four objectives are:
# To monitor the condition of war memorials and to encourage protection and conservation. # To provide expert advice to those involved in war memorial projects, to act as the specialist organisation for war memorial conservation issues and to facilitate repair and conservation through grants schemes. # To work with relevant organisations to encourage them to accept responsibility for war memorials and recognise the need to undertake repair and conservation work. # To build a greater understanding of war memorial heritage and raise awareness of the issues surrounding war memorial conservation.<ref>[https://volunteerteam.london.gov.uk/organizations/index.php?org_id=71 War Memorials Trust.] Team London. Retrieved 2017-02-01.</ref>
== History == War Memorials Trust was registered as a charity on 7 May 1997.<ref name="charitycommission">[http://www.charitycommission.gov.uk/Showcharity/RegisterOfCharities/CharityFramework.aspx?RegisteredCharityNumber=1062255&SubsidiaryNumber=0 War Memorials Trust, Charity framework.] Charity Commission. Retrieved 2012-03-23.</ref> It was originally known as Friends of War Memorials. [[Donald Thompson|Sir Donald Thompson]], then MP for Calderdale, [[Winston Churchill (1940–2010)|Winston S Churchill]], grandson of the wartime Prime Minister, and Ian Davidson, a former Royal Marine, were amongst those involved in founding the charity.<ref>[http://www.warmemorials.org/history/ History.] War Memorials. Retrieved 2012-01-05.</ref> Sir Donald Thompson became the Director-General of the charity and Winston S Churchill the President.
The Trust’s charity deed outlines the aim "… to educate the public and to foster patriotism and good citizenship by remembering those who have fallen in war by preserving and maintaining war memorials."<ref>[http://apps.charitycommission.gov.uk/Showcharity/RegisterOfCharities/CharityFramework.aspx?RegisteredCharityNumber=1062255&SubsidiaryNumber=0 War Memorials Trust, Charity Framework] Charity Commission. Retrieved 2017-02-01.</ref>
At the end of 2004 the Trustees of the charity decided upon a new name, War Memorials Trust, to replace Friends of War Memorials. The change came into effect in January 2005, along with a change of logo.<ref>[http://www.warmemorials.org/logo/ Logo.] War Memorials. Retrieved 2012-01-05.</ref>
== Conservation advice == War Memorials Trust has a conservation team who provide free advice about war memorial issues. In 2015-16 the charity dealt with 595 new cases and 911 general enquiries (2014: 609 new cases, 1,041 general enquiries).<ref>[http://apps.charitycommission.gov.uk/Accounts/Ends55/0001062255_AC_20160331_E_C.pdf Trustees' report and accounts, Review of activities: Conservation, p3.] Charity Commission. Retrieved 2017-02-01.</ref>
Cases that the Trust has recently been involved with include:
* Dalgety Spillers memorial plaques, [[Wisbech]] - Dalgety Spillers memorial plaques were held in storage for a decade. In 2014 a successful approach by War Memorials Trust was made to [[Nestle Purina PetCare]] UK Ltd, into which Dalgety Spillers was subsumed. The memorials were restored and on display for a special rededication ceremony on 11 November 2014.<ref>[http://www.wisbechstandard.co.uk/news/wisbech_factory_staff_join_remembrance_ceremony_as_three_bronze_war_memorials_are_re_dedicated_at_purina_site_1_3847730 ''Wisbech factory staff join Remembrance ceremony as three bronze war memorials are re-dedicated at Purina site''.] Wisbech Standard. Retrieved 2017-03-28.</ref> * [[Todmorden]] Garden of Remembrance – after several years of working with one of their Regional Volunteers concerned about theft of two Grade II listed statues by the sculptor [[Gilbert Bayes]] from the Garden, a grant from War Memorials Trust supported the production of replacements. The reinstated statues were unveiled at a rededication service on 12 October 2014.<ref>[http://www.theargus.co.uk/news/11528403.display/ ''Town-backed £15k project to replace First World War memorials''.] The Argus. Retrieved 2017-03-28.</ref><ref>[http://www.lancashiretelegraph.co.uk/news/todmorden/10633312.Stolen_Todmorden_war_memorials_to_be_replaced/ ''Stolen Todmorden war memorials to be replaced''.] Lancashire Telegraph. Retrieved 2017-03-28.</ref> * [[Chesham]] war memorial – a press story reporting vandalism of the war memorial was picked up by the Trust. The words 'war is not glorious' had been painted onto the plaques and plinth. War Memorials Trust's Conservation Team contacted Chesham Town Council to offer advice about how to remove the [[graffiti]] following best conservation practice to minimise any further damage.<ref>[http://www.getbucks.co.uk/news/local-news/chesham-war-memorial-defaced-disgusting-11271939 ''Chesham War Memorial defaced with 'disgusting' graffiti''.] Get Bucks. Retrieved 2017-03-28.</ref>
== Grant schemes == War Memorials Trust administers grant schemes which between them cover the whole of the UK. These grants are for the repair and conservation of war memorials.<ref>[http://www.theheritagealliance.org.uk/fundingdirectory/main/detail.php?FundCode=WARM Heritage Funding Directory.] Heritage Alliance. Retrieved 2017-02-01.</ref>
In 2015-16 War Memorials Trust managed the following Grant Schemes: * Centenary Memorials Restoration Fund<ref>[https://www.historicenvironment.scot/grants-and-funding/our-grants/centenary-memorials-restoration-fund/ Centenary Memorials Restoration Fund.] Historic Environment Scotland. Retrieved 2017-02-01.</ref> - funded by [[Historic Environment Scotland]] and the Scottish government. In 2015-16, 33 offers were made to the value of £314,025 (2014: 40 offers, £296,945)<ref>[http://apps.charitycommission.gov.uk/Accounts/Ends55/0001062255_AC_20160331_E_C.pdf Trustees' Report and Accounts, Review of Activities: Conservation, p5.] Charity Commission. Retrieved 2017-02-01.</ref> * War Memorials Trust Grants Scheme<ref>[http://apps.charitycommission.gov.uk/Accounts/Ends55/0001062255_AC_20160331_E_C.pdf Trustees' Report and Accounts, Review of Activities: Conservation, p.4.] Charity Commission. Retrieved 2017-02-01.</ref> - funded by First World War Memorials Programme and War Memorials Trust fundraising. Originally named the Small Grants Scheme in 1998 it has evolved over the years. In 2015-16, 100 offers were made to the value of £537,239 (2014: 135 offers, £150,090)<ref>[http://apps.charitycommission.gov.uk/Accounts/Ends55/0001062255_AC_20160331_E_C.pdf Trustees' Report and Account, Review of Activities: Conservation, p5.] Charity Commission. Retrieved 2017-02-01.</ref> * Grants for War Memorials<ref>[http://www.theheritagealliance.org.uk/fundingdirectory/main/detail.php?FundCode=WARM Heritage Funding Directory.] Heritage Alliance. Retrieved 2017-02-01.</ref> - funded by the First World War Memorials Programme and [[Historic England]]. It was first launched in 2000 taking many forms over the years. This scheme did not make any Grant Offers in 2015-16 but historic projects were managed<ref>[http://apps.charitycommission.gov.uk/Accounts/Ends55/0001062255_AC_20160331_E_C.pdf Trustees' Report and Accounts, Review of Activities: Conservation, p4.] Charity Commission. Retrieved 2017-02-01.</ref>
Projects funded by the Trust include: * [[Bootle]] war memorial<ref>[http://www.liverpoolecho.co.uk/news/liverpool-news/historic-bootle-war-memorial-returned-10904354 ''Historic Bootle war memorial to be returned to its former glory''.] Liverpool Echo. Retrieved 2017-03-28.</ref><ref>[http://www.goodnewsliverpool.co.uk/2016/08/31/bootle-war-memorial-rededication-event/ ''Bootle War Memorial Rededication Event''] Good News Liverpool. Retrieved 2017-03-28.</ref> * [[Norwich]] Roll of Honour<ref>[http://www.edp24.co.uk/news/norwich_first_world_war_roll_of_honour_to_have_new_home_on_armistice_day_1_4698756 ''Norwich First World War Roll of Honour to have new home on Armistice Day''.] Eastern Daily Press. Retrieved 2017-03-28.</ref> * [[Cheltenham]] war memorial – awarded £24,400<ref>[https://www.cheltenham.gov.uk/news/article/1704/war_memorial_is_set_to_return_to_its_former_glory_thanks_to_funding_success ''War memorial is set to return to its former glory thanks to funding success''.] Cheltenham Borough Council. Retrieved 2017-03-28.</ref> * [[Far East Prisoners of War|Far Eastern Prisoner of War]] steam locomotive<ref>[http://www.rutland-times.co.uk/news/your-news-a-living-memorial-at-rocks-by-rail-1-6832142 ''Your News: A living memorial at Rocks by Rail''.] Rutland Times. Retrieved 2017-03-28.</ref>
== Current projects and campaigns ==
=== First World War Memorials Programme === This partnership Programme, supported by the UK government through the [[Department of Culture, Media and Sport]], is composed of Civic Voice, Historic England, [[Imperial War Museums]] and War Memorials Trust. The Programme aims to improve public engagement with their war memorials throughout the centenary of the [[World War I|First World War]], as well as to encourage repair and conservation works.<ref>[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/history/world-war-one/10938674/First-World-War-centenary-Crumbling-war-memorials-to-be-conserved-through-3-million-repair-fund.html ''First World War centenary: Crumbling war memorials to be conserved through £3 million repair fund.''] The Telegraph. Retrieved 2017-02-07.</ref>
=== In Memoriam 2014 === [[In Memoriam 2014]] is a partnership between War Memorials Trust and the SmartWater Foundation to protect war memorials with metal elements from theft and damage by marking them with a forensic liquid called [[SmartWater (forensic)|SmartWater]].<ref>[http://www.doncasterfreepress.co.uk/news/crime/free-smartwater-crime-reduction-protection-for-war-memorials-1-6791705/amp ''Free Smartwater crime reduction protection for war memorials.''] Doncaster Free Press. Retrieved 2017-02-01.</ref><ref>[http://www.yorkshirepost.co.uk/news/debate/columnists/frances_moreton_we_must_all_protect_memorials_to_the_fallen_1_3959992 ''Frances Moreton: We must all protect memorials to the fallen.''] Yorkshire Post. Retrieved 2012-03-23.</ref>
Councils that have taken advantage of the scheme include: * Stockton Council<ref>[http://www.stockton.towntalk.co.uk/news/d/25705/smartwater-helps-protect-war-memorials/ '' 'Smartwater' helps protect war memorials''.] Stockton Town Talk. Retrieved 2012-04-10.</ref><ref>[http://www.gazettelive.co.uk/news/teesside-news/2012/03/03/smart-thinking-to-protect-stockton-war-memorials-84229-30447513/ ''Smart thinking to protect Stockton war memorials''.] Evening Gazette. Retrieved 2012-04-10.</ref><ref>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-tees-17221644 ''Hi-tech move to protect Stockton war memorials''.] BBC News. Retrieved 2012-04-10.</ref><ref>[http://www.thenorthernecho.co.uk/news/local/hartlepool/9561772.A_smart_way_to_foil_war_memorial_metal_thieves/ ''A smart way to foil war memorial metal thieves''.] The Northern Echo. Retrieved 2012-04-10.</ref> * Fylde Council<ref>[http://www.lythamstannesexpress.co.uk/news/local/smart-guarding-against-thieves-1-4320396 ''Smart guarding against thieves''.] Lytham St Anne's Express. Retrieved 2012-04-10.</ref> * Ashfield District Council<ref>[http://www.hucknalldispatch.co.uk/news/local-news/protection_for_war_memorials_from_metal_thieves_1_4246373 ''Protection for war memorials from metal thieves''.] Hucknall Dispatch. Retrieved 2012-04-10.</ref><ref>[http://www.thisisnottingham.co.uk/Plaques-marked-stop-scrap-thefts/story-15175704-detail/story.html ''Plaques marked to stop scrap thefts''.] Nottingham Post. Retrieved 2012-04-10.</ref> * Walsall Council<ref>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-birmingham-17479092 ''Barr Beacon in Walsall to get £440,000 revamp''.] BBC News Birmingham and Black Country. Retrieved 2012-04-10.</ref> * Nottinghamshire County Council<ref>[http://www.thisisnottingham.co.uk/Join-Smart-brigade-protect-war-memorial/story-14045165-detail/story.html ''Join the Smart brigade and protect your war memorial''.] Nottingham Post. Retrieved 2012-04-10.</ref> * Derby City Council<ref>[http://www.derbytelegraph.co.uk/action-urged-plan-protect-war-memorials-upsetting/story-15146479-detail/story.html ''Action urged in plan to protect war memorials from 'upsetting' thefts''.] Derby Telegraph. Retrieved 2017-02-07.</ref><ref>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-derbyshire-15635129 ''Derbyshire British Legion backs protecting war memorials.''] BBC News Derby. Retrieved 2012-04-10.</ref> * Ellesmere Town Council<ref>[http://www.bordercountiesadvertizer.co.uk/news/108088/ellesmere-s-smart-respnse-to-pm-s-memorial-concerns.aspx ''Ellesmere's smart response to PM's memorial concerns''.] Border Counties Advertiser. Retrieved 2012-04-10.</ref> * Sutton Council<ref>[http://www.thesouthernreporter.co.uk/community/marker_plan_to_protect_borders_war_memorials_1_1956056 ''Marker plan to protect Borders war memorial''.] The Southern Reporter. Retrieved 2012-04-10.</ref><ref>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-london-15671386 ''Stolen Carshalton war memorial plaques replaced''.] BBC News London. Retrieved 2012-04-10.</ref><ref>[http://www.suttonguardian.co.uk/news/9340599.War_memorials_get_invisible_security_markings_in_campaign_against_metal_thieves/ ''War memorials get invisible security markings as campaign against metal thieves stepped up''.] Sutton Guardian. Retrieved 2012-04-10.</ref>
=== War Memorials Officer campaign === In November 2010, the Trust launched a campaign to identify a War Memorials Officer (WMO) at each local authority in the UK. A WMO is the main point of contact at that council regarding war memorial issues for the public and the Trust. By the end of 2015-16, 290 War Memorials Officers had been identified.<ref>[http://apps.charitycommission.gov.uk/Accounts/Ends55/0001062255_AC_20160331_E_C.pdf Trustees' Report and Accounts, Review of Activities: Conservation, p6.] Charity Commission. Retrieved 2017-02-07.</ref>
=== Learning programme === In August 2011 War Memorials Trust launched its youth focused learning programme, 'We will always remember.' The aim of this programme is to build a greater understanding of war memorial heritage among young people so that they can continue to protect war memorials in the future as custodians. The learning programme provides National Curriculum linked lesson materials for primary and secondary school teachers, and offers talks or assemblies for schools and youth groups such as Scouts, Cadets and Duke of Edinburgh Award participants.<ref>[http://www.learnaboutwarmemorials.org/about/what-do/ ''What War Memorials Trust's Learning Programme does''.] Retrieved 2012-08-29.</ref>
== Membership == War Memorials Trust has a membership consisting of individuals and organisations. On 31 March 2016 the charity had 2,755 members (2014: 2,798).<ref>[http://apps.charitycommission.gov.uk/Accounts/Ends55/0001062255_AC_20160331_E_C.pdf Trustees' Report and Accounts, Review of Activities: Administration, publications and PR, p8.] Charity Commission. Retrieved 2017-02-07.</ref>
== Volunteering == Regional volunteers undertake a range of activities such as monitoring the condition of local war memorials and reporting those at risk to the Trust, researching and applying for the listing of war memorials and promoting the charity by giving talks and organising events.<ref>[http://apps.charitycommission.gov.uk/Accounts/Ends55/0001062255_AC_20160331_E_C.pdf University of Kent.] Retrieved 2017-02-07.</ref> War Memorials Trust had 188 Regional Volunteers throughout the UK on 31 March 2016 (2014: 181).<ref>[http://apps.charitycommission.gov.uk/Accounts/Ends55/0001062255_AC_20160331_E_C.pdf Trustees' Report and Accounts, Review of activities: Volunteers, p7.] Charity Commission. Retrieved 2017-02-07.</ref>
